He acknowledges that proving or disproving the existence of God isn't a scientific question. Therefore, I wish he would have listened to himself and resisted the temptation to add his own theological musings. I found myself impatiently skimming over these parts, trying to find my way back to scientific narrative he had suddenly dropped to indulge in these thoughts. Perhaps that is the real point of the book, but that was not the reason I wanted to read it.Astrophysicist Dr. Alex Filippenko, while he has not written an equivalent general publication book, is equivalently knowledgeable, an excellent teacher, and willing to leave theology out of his lectures, and I'd find some of his work if you're interested in general cosmology and astrophysics without the side of religious politics. There are definitely gems of knowledge and discovery in this book and Dr. Krauss' wry sense of irony and humor is infectious, therefore I'd still say it is worth a read so long as you can either sweep aside the annoyance of having to skip through all the pointless theology deductions and/or desire to read those in addition to the science of "something from nothing"

This is a difficult book. Krauss starts with a description of the universe as we now understand it. Describing the history of cosmology in the few pages he has available is an ambitious task. There are many difficult and non-intuitive concepts involved, and while recent reading enabled me to feel familiar with some of these, I was left short on a few areas (e.g inflation, string theory and flat universes). Since this book is written as an argument for a certain viewpoint, the need to take certain 'facts' on face value felt unsatisfying. The ironically unique, or special, place in space and time we humans have to observe all this is well illustrated. Regardless of ones view on other conclusions he makes, I suspect most would agree that our special place is fairly awe-inspiring.The second half then elaborates on the possibility that the Big Bang event could feasibly have had its origin in nothing. At this point, many of the points become more philosophical, since we don't have physical evidence for what did happen, unlike many of the points made in the first half. There are two main lines of argument here, the first being that what we do know suggests nothing may have the potential, or reality the capability, for something to come of it, whilst the second line tends to be that physically based arguments, even if unprovable, are better than theological ones (since they don't assume 'something' to begin with). Whereas the first half required some background reading to understand the concepts, the second requires a leap of faith (or for some a leap off one onto another perhaps). While non-theists would no doubt accept the arguments easily enough, and theists, like me, find them uncomfortable, the existence of anything if nothing was the starting point must be a difficult jump for anyone.The conclusion, regarding the theological discussion, is that of 'soft' atheism: science does not make belief in God impossible, but it does make disbelief possible; without science everything is miracle, with science perhaps nothing is. Unfortunately, by the time I got to the end the scientific content had become mixed with the philosophical, and it was hard for me to untangle these details. Others may have more luck than I did, but I'm not sure this one has nailed its goal.

"A Universe From Nothing, Why There Is Something Rather Than Nothing" is the first book I read by Lawrence Krauss. It dares to explain big question which only theologians and philosopher tentatively had [sort of] answers. It starts with particles soup in the Big Bang to the first star and other modern cosmological aspects.I admit this book is a bit beyond my comprehensible knowledge of cosmology, but I didn't read it with nothing to remember. I could push through to know a bit of history of modern since after Copernicus and what was behind Einstein's general theory of relativity. The book also indicates that we humans, especially astronomers, are living in a very special time right now since the traces of magnificently cosmological events such as the Big Bang, the picture of the infant Universe etc., haven't been erased yet; beings in the next billions or trillions years won't be as lucky as we.Moreover, some questions which are considered to be the intersection of science and religion are also answered. As the book puts it, sometimes, people point out that science just another kind of faith, but it is not. Scientists change their minds, admit they are wrong, and are happy and eager to throw out ideas that turn out not to work. They don’t presume to know for certain the answers to questions before they ask them. So yes, they have faith that the universe is comprehensible, but the greatest thing about science is that their faith is shakable. At any moment they can give up believing in anything they once believed in, if nature suggests otherwise.Science, as physicist Steven Weinberg has emphasized, does not make it impossible to believe in God, but rather makes it possible to not believe in God. Without science, everything is a miracle. With science, there remains the possibility that nothing is. Religious belief in this case becomes less and less necessary, and also less and less relevant.I may return to this book once I'm more knowledgeable at cosmology so that everything in this book would be more comprehensible for me.

This book has made a serious an rigurous work in showing that for all experimental evidence,including dark matter and dark energy,we live in a plane or euclidean universe expanding forever to infinity.The other part of the book is very especulative,it carries the known physical laws to the very rather unknown extreme.The autor claims that our universo could be created by a bubble of space time , where the dinamical energy and the potential gravitational energy sums zero,oriniginated by a quantum fluctuation of a preexistent quantum gravitational field.But in my humble opinión,perhaps i dont understand deeply the book,there is a great but:for the autor the nothing is not the absolute inexistence of all, is the physical vacuum and is known time ago that it is something permeated by quantum fields and full of pairs of virtual particles created by the quantum fluctuations of the fields,as has been evidenced by the hawking radiation and other ex perimental evidence.Then when the autor claims that the universe is created by nothing ,he is not making reference to absolute nothing or absolute inexistence,it is created by a preexistent quantum gravity field that in this case would be the first motor that is what the autor intends to avoid.How this preexistent quantum gravity field becomes to existence?.This is in my opinión the weak point of the book. PD. I am agnostic and dont believe in inteligent design by no means

Great book. A concise overview of the progress made in the past century, from Hubble and Lemaitre, passing through Einstein and concluding with modern cosmology. All the way from the belief that the Milky Way was all there was in a static Universe, to the expanding Universe we now know we are living in, to talk of the multiverse. All leading into the overwhelming and awe-inspiring conclusion that all of this knowledge - in combination with the best of our knowledge from quantum physics - consistently points towards our Universe very plausibly popping into existence out of nothing - sans deities. Some of the physics might take some patient reading to grasp, but the overall point - we know enough to dispense with the necessity of a supernatural god to create the Universe, the laws of physics are sufficient, is very clearly and elegantly presented.Curiously, Krauss has publicly stated to not have much love for philosophy, and it is precisely the parts where he combines scientific facts with philosophical reflection that shine the most.

This is a very well crafted overview of current developments in cosmology. Among the topics covered are the theoretical background and empirical evidence for the big bang (e.g., the cosmic microwave background radiation and the relative abundances of the light isotopes), the discovery of the accelerating universe, and, with some emphasis, the empirically confirmed prediction that the universe is "flat", which implies that it is a "free lunch", in the sense that the positive energy measured from the presence of matter is roughly balanced by the negative potential energy. Krauss then notes how the measured vacuum energy potential of the universe differs from predictions of theory by 120 orders of magnitude -- the cosmological constant paradox.The only aspect of the book that was a bit tiresome is the author's frequent assertions that belief in God is nixed by these findings. Even persons who are not particularly religious will recognize that the author is off on a tangent here every bit as pedantic as that taken by some religious fundamentalists.

One of the constant counters I receive from debates between myself and the faithful when discussing religion is their propensity to think that something arising out of nothing is absurd without the intervention of a creator. This spontaneous and perhaps counter intuitive notion when posed to a species that evolved to gauge the speed of an approaching predator is of course seemingly absurd on the surface. As it happens of course, there are scientifically verifiable and plausible causes for the spontaneous creation of something from nothing devoid of a divine entity. I would like to recommend this to people who impose a divine creator, however from the two known articulately barbed authors (Krauss and Dawkins), the outright degradation of religion in the beginning and throughout the book (which I loved) may rub some the wrong way. Even so, if you are on the correct side of the religion fence, this book may serve as anti-bullshit cannon fodder for those who attempt to justify their arguments with divine fairy tales.

3 stars because of the way-too-long phrases that he uses, which makes you lose the point in the middle of it. 3 stars because it's surprisingly challenging for our common sense and enriching my cosmological perspective. 3 stars because I've not well-understood all quantum theories that he described, and will most definitely read it one more time in the future.So to sum it up 3 stars would be fair in the moment!! PS. Not recommended unless your knowledge in physics is above average, especially in quantum mechanichs.

What first appears to be an account of the latest in cosmology and particle physics, turns out to be a fairly challenging but ultimately self-serving trek through Krauss's research and an embarrassingly inept argument with theologians/theists about religious belief and the evidence for God. But the book does not work! There is a problem when theologians corner scientists and tell them that they are wrong (about the existence of God, the creation of the universe, etc,); there is also a problem when scientists attack theologians and tell them they are wrong/foolish/misguided/superstitious/stupid! These camps speak different languages and have completely different requirements for proof. What a cocky, presumptuous book. I gave it two stars only because I learned enough to make it a worthwhile read.

Excellent book from Lawrence Krauss. If you are enthusiast of Physics this is definitely book to read. As I have started reading the book I am almost got glued to it, as it gradually picked up and took off very fast in later stages. Each phase, it left with an awe about our universe we live in, narrating how it might have originated and how it would end also( with bit scariness). Things such CMB experiments and the conclusion that let to make the shape of universe are exiting. But the very subject of bring 'something from nothing' as Krauss attempted to do so was not very convincing to me, nevertheless it is seems a possibility that cannot be neglected. Additionally it has encouraged me into learn more physics, which is something resembles like universe itself. The more you learn, things you dont know expands further and recedes fast out of horizon.

A Universe from Nothing describes the latest thinking in physics about the question of why there is something (as in life, the universe and everything) as opposed to nothing at all (as in the vacuum of empty space). I don't want to spoil it, but it involves the negative energy of empty space, quantum fluctuations and an inflationary early universe. Of course, we don't really know what happened, and perhaps we never will. Our best evidence at this point only hints of a possible origin, and the whole thing is difficult to grasp. On a daily basis, even small objects don't just appear out of nowhere ... let alone enough matter to form hundreds of billions of galaxies. Yet that's what quantum theory predicts. As they say .. reality doesn't care if you believe in it.

I really tried to understand this book but it was impossible. When I understood that it was first a youtube talk, I watched that which was much easier to understand.Dr. Krauss takes great care to explain the range of cosmological discoveries in the effort to prove that a universe made from nothing does not require a deity. Unfortunately, I didn't get it and listening and reading all of his cheap pokes and jokes made me more hostel and resistant to his theories. He should take his own advice that proving or disproving the existence of God isn't a scientific question and stick to the science that he knows so well.

I like Lawrence Krauss. He's capable of doing ground-breaking research and then he can turn around and tell me about it with style, clarity, and charm--without making me painfully aware of how little I really know about modern-day physics. There are some pretty tangled sentences in this book, but Krauss' enthusiasm renders them sort of endearing. It's as if he didn't write this book so much as spill it out verbally in a long burst of excitement and inspiration. You can just see him grinning behind some of these pages, saying to you eagerly, "Isn't that just so cool?" It is.

Krauss has written a book for the lay reader about the latest developments in theoretical physics, explaining how the big bang was created from nothing, and has gone onto create all the things that make up the visible universe.He goes on to explain how the universe is expanding, and the methods that they use to ascertain its size, and some of the latest theories, but quantum physics has always been a bit beyond me, and this book has confirmed that I am out of my depth with a lot going on in theoretical physics at the moment.

I loved this book. The topics discussed are mind bending and fascinating. The reason I’m giving 4 instead of 5 stars is the following: if the book is written for lay-people (non-physicists), it’s mighty hard for us to understand in places. The author is often able to break down the concepts and translate the beautiful science into something the rest of us can understand and when he does, it’s brilliant. That being said, this isn’t a book for scientists and there are parts where this reader, at least, would have appreciated a bit more explanation. I’d read it again and again though!

I found this book quite disappointing; not so much because it is a bad book, but because it has been so hyped up. It is an awfully slim volume for the subject matter it claims to discuss, and I soon found the reason why. Rather than being a book on popular science, as it is marketed, the book is really a thinly disguised attack on religion. If you want to learn something about science, skip this book. There are much better books out there for that.

Very interesting explanation of why there need not be (but whose to say there ISn't?) a creator of the universe. It all made perfect sense...except there were still a few parts I--basically a non-scientist, especially a non-theoretical physicist--didn't understand, no matter how many times I backed up and listened again. Still and all, I learned a lot more than I already knew about quantum mechanics and its impact on our universe--past, present and future.

The most amazing science book I have ever read. I realized I didn't really understand a lot of concepts about the universe or understand them in a wrong way. But Krauss explain them in the most "simple" manner that anything as complex as the universe could be explained.

A lot of this went over my head but a couple trillion years from now it won't matter. From a math and physics perspective I don't fully understand but from an English perspective I now have a very basic understanding of "how", not "why" there is something rather than nothing.
This book earned it's 5th star when it expanded far enough in scope to discuss ethics, as well as masturbation. Well done.
My dog ate my book. Literally. Which is completely messed up because it was autographed by Professor Krauss. Ugh. I loved what I had read.
Truly a pleasure to read the articles and speeches of Lawrence Krauss.
“Forget Jesus, the stars died so you could be born.”

As this is a rather weighty book, bear with me in a longer review, if you're interested.Is this book worth your time? And there will be a significant amount of time invested in it, because this isn't light reading.The short answer is that I gave this book five stars because I thoroughly enjoyed it; it made me think, and opened up avenues of thinking - which is what I want from any good book, fiction or nonfiction. Is it well-told? That's what I look for. This book is very difficult to understand; there is no way around that. The concepts discussed are those of astrophysics and cosmology, and if you're daunted by particle physics, quantum theory or general relativity, this book is not for you. About four-fifths of the book is dedicated to explanations leading to and the ultimate answer to the title of the book: why is there something rather than nothing? Laurence Krauss takes the reader step-by-step, chapter by chapter to and through the concept of our universe being a flat universe; he explains how this sort of universe requires a certain set of things to occur or to already have occurred. He explains how a period of rapid inflation and a big bang are consistent with what we now know about and observe in our universe. He explains how fluctuations in either empty space or no space at all could bring about the myriad galaxies and billions of stars we can observe - and that if human beings live long enough, we eventually will not be able to see any longer. Whatever characteristics the universe - or a multiverse - has, following the evidence is exciting and fascinating: and we live in one of the (on a cosmic scale) brief times in history when this evidence can still be observed.These concepts aren't easy to discuss or to understand, much less to explain. I admire Mr. Krauss' ability to deliver most of the explanation to a layperson such as myself so that I can honestly say that I understood about 80% of the content; I'm not sure I can explain it as well as I'd like, which probably means I'd need to re-read certain portions again - if you can't explain it, you might not understand it, as the maxim goes.The last fifth of the book - mostly concentrated in the chapters at the end but also interspersed throughout with connected commentary - is dedicated to the idea that a Creator or a Being outside of time, essentially God, is not necessary. Mr. Krauss is up front about his views in his introduction, and for the most part, he is able to present his views without rancor. There are several occasions, however, where he uses wording that indicates obvious disdain for theological concepts or those who argue for them, on a logical basis. For the reader who identifies with those beliefs and wants to be well-informed scientifically, or who is looking to see where they disagree, this can be off-putting. Final conclusions: this is a fascinating topic - and the book is well-written, for the most part even for those who aren't experts. If you're a person of faith, I recommend struggling and wrestling with this topic the way that Jacob wrestled with the "angel" at Bethel. It's worth your time.

http://thalukinglass.blogspot.in/2014...I like to imagine all of existence as a fully blown balloon twisted in the middle with the opposing ends twisted in directions opposite to each other, so that it looks like a 3D symbol of infinity. One of the ends of that balloon is, of course, our observable universe. I also like to imagine and try to apply characteristics of things observed around in our world to the dynamics of how things play out in the universe. It is something like drawing an analogy between, let’s say gravitational forces of heavenly bodies and attraction between two human beings. I know it will seem absolutely preposterous to draw such an analogy but the reason why I believe so lies in the idea that all that there is, is just one energy, but manifesting itself differently, both characteristically and behaviorally, at different scales and levels. The same energy at heavenly scales becomes the attractive force of gravitation and the same energy at quantum levels becomes the energy of dancing uncertainty. And since energy exists in one end of the balloon (which is observable space), an equal amount of non-energy should also exist on the other end of the balloon so as to balance the ebullience of the energy in the other end. There is something on one side, and there is non-something on the other side and together therefore they make Nothing, but together they are also Everything that there is. Hence, Nothing is Everything, or Everything is Nothing – an upanishadic quote that became the root from which my current imagination of our existence sprouted.But the existence and sustenance of this energy requires a first cause or a creator of this energy or a prime mover of this force which compels this energy to move through shapes, vaccums, objects and creatures. Prevalence of observable and consistent laws acting throughout the universe reveals a picture of a well structured evolution of our universe and therefore does away with the need of the “First Cause” requirement, because if it did exist, then there is absolutely no telling as to when the First Cause could become an intervening cause. This problem is resolved by Deistic arguments that postulate a First Cause that had a role to play only in the beginning and thereafter the universe was left on its own to evolve as it deemed fit on the basis of the laws initially made. But none of that explains where this energy or the “First Cause” really came from? Now let me take you back to my balloon version of existence. We see one side of the balloon twisted in the middle through which energy courses through myriad forms, and therefore we see that there indeed exists something. However for something to exist, there has to be some principle or law, if not purpose or meaning, on which that something comes into existence. Though at this juncture, I was greatly inclined to conclude a first cause principle, Krauss beautifully shows how “nothingness” as opposed to “somethingness” that we see is essentially unstable and a boiling brew from which quantum fluctuations cause virtual particles to pop in and out of existence in such short periods of time that they essentially do not exist. However such virtual particles do exist, according to Krauss. These virtual particles that “live” (speaking simplistically) only for very short durations carry the potential to affect other particles, however microscopically small. What causes these quantum particles to pop in and out of existence? We may not know why they do so or who makes them do so, but they really do so and that fact was figured as a possible reason for the big bang explosion that expanded our universe in every possible direction. This now makes me imagine of universe in another way. It can be like a kettle of boiling water, with the universes in it akin to bubbles that pop in and out existence (albeit over gargantuan periods of time) due to being affected by the way particles in a quantum fire below it interact with it, for however brief periods of time. Call it an inconsistent picture, if you will, because quantum fluctuations occur within the universe (in this case, inside the kettle), than below it, and moreover it again requires a cause, otherwise who would have lit the fire? Regardless of the inconsistencies in the way I paint my universes in the colours of my imagination, I derive utmost pleasure in forming different mental portraits as it makes me really wonder about the fascinating ways in which energy transforms through and takes different shapes. Scientific adventures into metaphysical curiosities are fraught with theoretical incompleteness, but nonetheless have a remarkable potential to boggle a person and cause a mini big bang in his neural activity. I knew my time was well spent in reading Lawrence M. Krauss after I came across this sentence in his book, “A Universe from Nothing: Why there is Somethin grather than Nothing.”“However, a negative charge moving backward in time is mathematically equivalent to a positive charge moving forward in time.”That added force to the way I imagine existence to be, (existence includes the universe and much more apart from it), so that what ever we see or observe, has a direct parallel in another dimension, which we perceive to be opposite to ours, though which ought not to be opposite in its own right. But who am I to clarify any of it further, when even Krauss admitted that Universe behaves very strangely. Despite all of its rationality, logic, and scientifically proved equations, observations and experiments, I believe Krauss avoided dismantling the entire scientific muscle in this arena after calling our times as very propitious for knowing the true nature of our universe. He remarked that scientists in another system trillion years ahead in time will live in a universe that will have inflated so much that their galaxy would be the only one observable to them and all that would be observable apart from that will be empty dark space, thus potentially occluding any evidence of the big bang. I honestly think that the same could be applied to us in much the same vein, that what we are observing about the universe might be completely different from how it must have been 13.72 billions years ago (our estimate of the universe’s age) and all preceding contrary evidence must have gotten occluded? Krauss could have added something to counter this potential line of thinking or if he had put it unconnectedly in some page previously, I failed in figuring so.I like these kind of books chiefly because they help me expand my mind and learn of newer ways of thinking and looking at the world and our universe. This happened after my mind did odd-degrees of somersaults back and forth after reading Hawking's BriefHistory of Time and Sagan's Dragons of Eden. Those two books did not make me a scientist overnight bubbling with a quantum enthusiasm of scientific curiosity, but what they did indeed was to add new dimensions to my creative imagination and this is what I expected out of this book too and was thoroughly not disappointed. I will not end up remembering the scientific logic in the book, but I will be really thankful to the book for adding another image of the universe in my mind (remember the kettle earlier?).Finally, the idea of a universe coming from nothing and going to nothing is an idea that I deeply espouse because that idea provides a sense of closure to me and to know that science is also deeply rooted into unearthing answers to that hypothesis is a very comforting piece of news.

I liked it, but not as much as I wanted to.I'll begin with my gripes and then pivot to what I liked.1) No end notes, no suggestions for further reading, and no bibliographical references of any sort. Personally, I only let Asimov get away with this, and him only barely. Besides, he is dead and cannot hear my complaints.2) No math. This will surely be a plus for many people. Not for me. If you're going to use advanced physics to take a stab at answering an age-old philosophical question, and try to talk people out of their belief in God to boot, doing so by only implicitly relying upon the mathematical models that are so convincing to the author asks, if you will, too much of a leap of faith from the reader. Granted, not everyone wants to learn enough physics to follow modern cosmology (I certainly may not end up with that much background myself). But the social contract of science is "show, don't (just) tell". The advantage over religious truth is that a lay person can take the math to a knowledgeable expert and seek independent verification.Drawback #1 combined with drawback #2 almost knocked this down to 2 stars for me. These are anti-synergetic flaws.3) Richard Dawkins, a man whom I otherwise respect (I've read several of his books, starting with 
The Selfish Gene
 almost 20 years ago), far oversold the virtues of Krauss's book in his afterword. I do not think there is any way this book will end up being regarded as on par with Darwin's 
On the Origin of Species
. See drawback #2. Darwin's work was epochal because he spelled everything out in an empirical avalanche and analytical tour de force. (Caveat: I've only read excerpts of Origin myself.)4) A Universe from Nothing suffers from a semantic problem thrust upon it by the forces it seeks to battle. In Victor Stenger's 
God: The Failed Hypothesis
, the author's case against God depends (as he frankly acknowledges) heavily on how one defines "God". Some people, including friends of mine who identify as Christian, do not consider themselves supernatural theists. Stenger's critique thus fails to resonate with them. Krauss's book has a similar problem in that a great deal depends on what one means, precisely, by "nothing", and in that this concept turns out to be a tricky one when you get quantitative and precise about it. Krauss, too, acknowledges this difficulty. But it is another case where a bit of fundamental philosophical groundwork should have been laid. Platonic "realists", or people who resemble them even unconsciously, likely are not going to be convinced by Krauss's discussion of virtual particle pair-formation, even though this idea is now something like a century old and has a lot of empirical support.However, if drawback #4 was my only gripe with the book I'd have loved it. Krauss, like Stenger, is on a scientific, not a philosophical mission. (In fact, Krauss denigrates philosophers at almost every opportunity, an attitude that would be unfair were it not for the efforts of Jacques Derrida alone, to say nothing of his disciples.) But again, if one wants to confine one's mission, so much more desirable is a footnote or endnote directing the reader to a philosophical exploration of "nothing"--so drawback #1 strikes yet again.Back on the gripping hand, we've all had experience with people who will equivocate until their dying breath. They also seem to be the sorts of people who write reviews of books they haven't read. It's easy to understand why Krauss doesn't want to take the first step towards people who have sworn before the altar of God never to meet him halfway.5) Flipping to the authorial photograph on the jacket, I find myself wondering how I can trust a physicist who looks uncannily like Stephen Merchant.(Okay, I'm kidding with that last one. But it *is* spooky...)The things I liked about this title are more straightforwardly enumerated. Except I already enumerated, so I'll, er, alliterate:A) The subject is inescapably interesting, at least to me. Cosmology--the study of the origin and possible fate of the universe is a literally a wonderful subject--full of wonder. Krauss's enthusiasm for his subject shines through, and he is, shall we say, philosophical about some of the stranger and lonelier potential fates (such as what Wikipedia calls "The Big Rip", though Krauss doesn't use that term).B) Krauss provides capsule introductions to many physicists of whom you may not have heard, such as Vera Rubin. I never mind a reminder that science progresses through the efforts of actual human beings, and it's nice to know a little about them. Giving just enough biographical information to identify what made a person noteworthy, and what was personally interesting about them (for instance, the lengths to which Rubin had to go to get her Ph.D. in astronomy) without digressing too far from the conceptual matters at hand is a real skill, and one Krauss practices masterfully.C) Krauss is unapologetic about his atheism and at the same time offhand about it. This is, in my view, exactly the right approach. The world doesn't need your story about how you were de-converted, or never religious in the first place. Atheism should be a consequence of the workings of your mental apparatus, not a first principle. Multiple public opinion polls in the United States have shown that atheists are America's "most distrusted minority"--more so even than gays and Muslims, against whom discrimination is at least regarded as somewhat controversial, or as requiring restraint under some circumstances. I infer that there are a substantial number of evangelical Christians who would rather fly on a commercial passenger liner flown by Mohammed Atta (were he still alive) than by an atheist. (Fortunately, they are ignorant of the religious attitudes of the pilots I know, as they are of so much else.) The problem is obvious to me--plenty of Christians know atheists, but don't *know* that they know atheists. Krauss sets a good example. For a book that supposedly bolsters atheism, Krauss has surprisingly little to say about it. He lays out the cosmological physics (albeit without math, sigh) and lets the reader wield Occam's Razor for him- or herself.D) In spite of his dearth of references, I did infer from Krauss that Alan Guth's famous 
The Inflationary Universe
 is worth my consideration. I will certainly be looking into that to see if it can fill in the many gaps that this title left for me.Bottom line: this might be a good introduction to modern cosmology and a few wacky quantum-mechanical concepts for lay people who are a bit more lay than I am, but it's certainly no Origin of Species.

Krauss makes clear without mathematical elaboration that the universe is rapidly expanding and that this expansion can be understood by the mass particles which we cannot observe directly. This mass is needed because the mass of the visible matter would be attrackted among themselves which would imply an implosion of the universe. Virtual particles pop up and disappear again in very short time moments. This is ‘from nothing’. These particles explain the mass we are missing. The expansion of the universe will ultimately imply that we cannot see it anymore as the mass ourside our cluster cannot be observed anymore. The fact that we are able to see it is therefore special. According to Wijnberg this can be explained by antropic selection implying that there are many universes so that inevitabile in one of them (ours) the conditions optimal are. Because we see that there is matter there should be an imbalance between matter and anti-matter in some time amd instant. The empty space apparantly is instabile then. In the small asymmetry the creation takes place. Krauss states that attributing the first movememt to God a complexity that adds an element which in itself has to be explained. This seems not logical. In his opinion the mulitversum assumption as basis for our universe makes more sense. I am impressed by the knowledge which has been build up by a great deal of people on our universe. Does this influence the way I see God? Apparantly the laws of nature can explain much more then I assumed. It is plausible that the big bang occurred and the virtual particles and empty space also seems plausible. I think the multiversum assumption is far fetched, let’s say a leap of faith. Just like in biology the large number of occurrences is used as argument to explain our existence. I find it hard to understand the first causes and am inclined to give God a role here. Further one can experience Him in your personal life and hear about Him from old (biblical) and new (testimonial) stories.

This book is an eye opener! I learned so much, about the cosmos, the history of the universe and more.I'll start with the bad - the book is hard to read as it is filled with deep explanations in the field of quantum physics and other research and without basic understanding of the topic I think people will get lost. Also, the writer uses half smart half funny philosophical debates about physics which sometimes are annoying. Too much use of the word 'nothing' although it is necessary for the idea. The good: Since I'm Jewish but I don't "like" religion of any kind it is hard for me to get into any serious debate with religious people as I had no real data to present them and they twist it against me.Now, not only my beliefs (not that the universe needs my faith in it) got stronger they also got facts.Here is some of the notions I took from the book and the reading that came after it: - Evolution is not a theory - its a fact, even the weird parts of it has explanation. And I wasn't a fan of evolution by the way. - The Big bang has been proven scientifically and even the age of the universe is determined. No maybe, no opinion, no theory - it is proven! The data is there- The universe is not empty and most of all does not need high power to exist.- Matter and space can come out of nothing - This is something that religious people often say "how something so vast and infinite could come out of nothing". Usually their answer is that some invisible being (that came out of nothing by himself) HAD to create it.. So no, IT doesn't. Matter and space can exist from nothing. In conclusion: People who hold strong religious beliefs will discard this book even before starting it. And most of people on earth doesn't even know that some of the biggest questions in the world has already been answered. I think that the scientific society should get involved with education more instead of just saying - they are stupid let them be.

Lawrence Krauss' book is a fun summary of the evolution of cosmological thinking from Galileo to today. It's humorous and highly readable, although I confess the author still lost me at parts. Armchair theologians and deists beware: Krauss is not a believer in the supernatural, and despite best attempts (for him) still comes across as a bit contentious/contemptuous of the idea of God. Why bother? Krauss' whole thesis rests on an evidence-based portrayal of the natural world. If he's right, persuasion is irrelevant; we all ultimately experience the same natural consequences. At p. 146, he says flat out, "Occam's razor suggests that, if some event is physically plausible, we don't need recourse to more extraordinary claims for its being." Yet having strung together an elegant (and still emerging) picture of physical laws and their function as an engine of cosmological history, he proceeds to make a wholly unnecessary non sequitur argument, writing:Consider an electron-positron pair that spontaneously pops out of empty space near the nucleus of an atom and affects the property of that atom for the short time the pair exists. In what sense did the electron or positron exist before? …There was potential for their existence, certainly, but that doesn't define being any more than a potential human being exists because I carry sperm in my testicles near a woman who is ovulating…. In any case, if potential to exist were the same as existence, then I am certain that by now masturbation would be as hot button a legal issue as abortion now is.Still, while quotable, this example of fallacious reasoning is an anomaly in the work as a whole. If Krauss at times unnecessarily hostile to supernatural explanations for naturally-explainable phenomena, the basis for his impatience is exceedingly clear.It's been over a month now since I read this, so let me do what I can to briefly summarize Krauss' thesis from memory and a few select notes (yes, I took notes), with sincere apologies to the author and other physicists for totally bollixing it up. Let's start with the premise of science itself. Krauss' scientific philosophy ties the level of confidence in our worldly knowledge to what we repeatably and repeatedly observe. As for extrapolations from these observations, he is with Karl Popper in requiring scientific theories to make falsifiable statements to be taken seriously or considered interesting.In human terms, the universe is so incredibly large and longstanding that it is difficult for the mind to grasp, and yet consistent, continuing, and independent observations of multiple, correlating phenomena establish a sturdy conceptual framework from which we can further build. Thus Krauss takes us from discovery to discovery, locking in the existence of quantum particle fluctuation with not a little help from the Swiss, and triangulating the Big Bang from a host of unrelated data that requires only a bit of diligent staring to cobble together. As he puts it at p. 20, "Nowadays, one way to see a supernova is simply to assign a different graduate student to each galaxy in the sky. After all, one hundred years is not too different, in a cosmic sense at least, from the average time to do a PhD, and graduate students are cheap and abundant. Happily, however, … since supernovae explode once per hundred years per galaxy, with 100,000 galaxies in view, you should expect to see, on average, about three stars explode on a given night."We are surely privileged to be living at a time when it is possible to use tools to gain primary evidence of things ranging from infinitely vast to infinitesimally small, from age-old to near instantaneous. What to make of the strangeness of miniscule antiparticles, which are hard to see, short-lived, and exceedingly rare? Should we view them as Krauss suggests at p. 62 "in the sense that Belgians are strange? They are not really strange; it is just that one rarely meets them." Could there be a divine plan in all this? For the author (p. 6), if "metaphysical speculation is independent of the physical validity" of the cosmos, it "is irrelevant to our understanding of it." Yet without metaphysical explanations, how do we explain the ultimate origins of existence? After all, we are hardwired to seek causality. Logic itself is built on the premise that everything comes from an arbitrary somewhere. First positions are always fiat.That's nothing. And what Krauss ultimately teaches is that nothing is unstable. Of course, "true nothingness" turns out to be nontrivial to define. Is it absence of matter? Of energy? Of the potential for either? Is it nonexistence or pre-existence? Philosophically and logically, where nothing is defined as an absolute negation – "not X," where 'x' is anything you care to name – the very idea is undefinable. Whatever results, some new absence emerges by inserting another "not," leading to the knotty paradox of seemingly infinite regression.So empty spacetime is not truly "nothing" inasmuch as it now appears to be filled with dark (really, "non-radiant") matter and energy. Nor can the space within atoms be said to be empty; we can now predictably find particles and antiparticles popping out of the void and annihilating one another like so many kamikaze soap bubbles. We've learned that the universe is expanding; but we're discovering that this applies not only to the fabric of spacetime (which is directly observable, whatever it may be), but also (and this is extrapolable) the space between spacetime. These ever-expanding gaps make possible whole new universes. Moreover, each of these newly-erupting universes operates or much more likely, dissolves, collapses, or implodes under their own respective sets of unique, self-consistent physical laws. Thus does nonbeing give rise to being, as something is always coming from nothing. It's the norm, just the way the cosmos is wound.And so Krauss proceeds to write God out of the equation. Either God exists wholly apart from an infinitude of possibilities, in which case, God is irrelevant. Otherwise, and with extrapolable evidence for a frothy nothingness that continuously foments newly observable matter and energy, "the requirement of an all-powerful deity who somehow exists outside of our universe, or multiverse, while at the same time governing what goes on inside it" ceases to be plausible. "It should thus be a claim of last, rather than first, resort." (p. 146 again) All in all, it's an amazing overview. I can't say I fully understand the cosmology he describes here or its full implications, but it's oddly comforting to learn that I don't need to take any of it on faith.

I really enjoyed this book but I can’t say that it’s a must read or that it’s for everyone. If you have a general understanding of physics and quantum mechanics it will be a fun read but if you haven’t refreshed or learned about the fundamentals of these subjects it might be a bit confusing at times. For instance, when Krauss discusses the origin and ultimate end of the universe he assumes that the reader has an a priori understanding of the four forces and how they function. Furthermore he assumes his reader is not only educated in these fields but also accepts empirical evidence provided by science over religious dogma. With that being said, it seems a bit futile to even dispute the “God of the Gaps” argument or any theological ideologies throughout the book because his assumed reader wouldn’t be in that demographic. In the instance that his reader was a religious person who denied empirical evidence, his arguments wouldn’t be substantial enough to sway their opinion in a different direction. Therefore the argument against God or theological ideologies would best be saved for another book.*im not sure how to do a second review after my second read so I’ll just add it to this one! This is definitely a book that should be studied more than just read and I will probably read through it a third time before the year is over. I generally don’t reread books back to back like this but this book was a special case. There was so much information on physics, quantum mechanics and string theory that it would be challenging to retain all of the information with one single read unless you were already a particle physicist or something of the sort. I really love this book and think there is much to learn from this more than what most general science books will teach you. With that being said, I still stand with my original view that it might be a little challenging to grasp all of these concepts without a prior understanding of physics and quantum mechanics. If you’re looking to get a general understanding before reading this book I’d look to A Brief History of Time and Astrophysics for People in a Hurry or Crash Course on YouTube also has a lot of information on these topics. I’ll end this review with a couple of quotes I really enjoyed!“The best answer I have ever heard to the question of what it would be like to be dead is to imagine how it felt to be before you were conceived. In any case, if potential to exist were the same as existence, then I am certain that by now masturbation would be as hot button a legal issue as abortion now is” “Scientific ethos is based on three key principles: 1) follow the evidence wherever it leads2)if one has a theory, one needs to be willing to try to prove it wrong as much as one tries to prove it right 3)the ultimate arbiter of truth is experiment, not the comfort one derives from ones a priori beliefs.” “A truly open mind means forcing our imaginations to conform to the evidence of reality, and not vice versa, whether or not we like the implications” “Reality doesn’t owe us comfort”

"Why is there something rather than nothing?" is a question atheists are often asked by believers. My own simple answer before I read A Universe From Nothing (or before I heard hints from other publications on this subject) was "Why does that question necessarily imply a God? Why not other explanations?"Lawrence M. Krauss, a particle physicist turned cosmologist, gives us science's latest ideas on how something might come from nothing, and in fact may have been inevitable. And how, given further eons, the something we know may just well become nothing again.We happen to live in a place and time where we can look out and see the light from billions of galaxies, and can see that they are accelerating away from us. Should there be any observers anywhere in the universe, say, a trillion years from now (they won't be earthlings, since our sun will have long since burned out), galaxies outside their own gravitational cluster will have receded to the point where their light can no longer be seen. Those observers will not be able to figure out that they inhabit an expanding universe. Something I never would have thought about.Quantum physics and cosmology are not easy subjects to get one's head around. I certainly don't understand them very well, but this little book is compelling for the curious.

Lawrence presupposes that metaphysical materialism is true (Read Bernardo Kastrups latest work for very solid arguments that it is not) and tries to paint a picture with the much limited knowledge of our current physics, and some quantum physics. He readily ignores experiments in quantum physics that point in different direction, like those where the primacy of the observer (consciousness) prove to be of major importance. Check out physicist Thomas Campbell who write about these instead and you'll find someone who isn't bound by dogma.The myth of creation he paints is the same old, coming from current paradigm of materialistic ontology. Everything is accidental, without any meaning. When anything close to religion is mentioned he promptly ridicule it. I'm not religious in the ordinary sense myself, but I fully understand its legitimacy and viewpoint - which is a philosophical one, outside of science.Lawrence say that people confuse the questions "Why" and "How" only so that he can try and paint up a how and tell us this is the same as why. This kind of reasoning is so naive or deliberately misleading that I'm not going to comment on it any further than that.If you want to understand contemporary materialist, go for it.On a quest to understand the existence we're in? This won't help you.Try going back to the old esoteric texts of Hermes and start from there instead.

What evidence shows the universe is flat? Is it possible that everything we see came from nothing? Are we basically just made up of a set of particle/anti-particle quantum fluctuations that arise from basically nothing?This book discusses these questions and gives some background to how we arrived at other scientific insights. He gets very technical in the last 1/3 of the book so if that isn't for you just skip those parts. Some of the concepts he discusses are so mind-bendingly insane it almost seems like he is discussing the supernatural instead of the natural (i.e. virtual particles).He covers a lot of ground and I think makes great arguments for how we know what we know when it comes to physics and cosmology, while taking as many shots at the super-conservative view of God and religion as he can. He does as good a job as any to explain virtual particles, better than Feynman in my opinion. I also think he does a better job of condensing the research on the flat universe compared to Brian Greene's book, as well.

Krauss' narrative interweaves the epic history of cosmology with intelligent discussions about the fabric of the Universe and the notion of a Creator.The beginnings of the book focus on the key discoveries that lead to the picture of the Universe we have today. Such discoveries are truly eye-opening and reveal, on a quantum level, the bizarre nature of empty space, i.e. "nothing".Krauss explores ideas of General Relativity and Quantum Physics. Amongst other things, he writes about the implications of different geometries of the Universe, the evidence for the Big Bang, dark energy, inflation and the implications of quantum gravity.Ultimately, the book undermines the credibility of Theologians and Philosophers in the pursuit of truth about our reality.This is a 5 star read for anyone interested in Science, Philosophy and Theology.The chapters are nice and short, however at times difficult to read for those not already pre-exposed to ideas of cosmology. I wish I could rate this 4.5 stars.

Great Stuff!Understandable written.Even if I had to read each chapter twice.Do not expect any answers of “why do we exist” or what was there before the Big Bang.This book explains the universe as we understand it with the current state of scientific knowledge.It shows the history of our understanding of the universe. As such each chapter ends with a “cliffhanger”, because almost each next chapter reveals new insights which changes what was understood in the previous one. That made for an intriguing read! But also it is confusing. Just as one thinks this is it; some new development is described. A new development that sometimes goes back in time. Fascinating to read how from seemingly “empty” space our whole universe evolves, including us humans. => So that means for me that space is not really empty. It does contains something after all!Or as Krauss puts it: “Hidden in what seems like empty space - indeed, like nothing - appear to be the very elements that allow for our existence”.The book describes how the Big Bang theory became a fact, based upon empirical data.It explains why the universe we live in is flat.Matter created via quantum fluctuations out of seemingly nothing.That is the stuff that is explained here.Fascinating as said.After chapter 6 it becomes more and more theorizing. Now I really got to understand what physical theorist are doing!Much of these later chapters is still theory. Not yet verified by empirical data (like String Theory or the multi-verse). But still very plausible. And that is enough for Krauss.He emphasises that thru science alone we can understand our surroundings: ““Science provides a possible road map for the creation of space (and time) itself - and perhaps also an understanding of how the laws of physics that govern the dynamics of space and time can arise haphazardly”.Because as he states it: “relying on invisible miracles is the stuff of religion, not science”.Is there a First Cause? We don’t know and Krauss dismisses this question. He focusses solely How there is something from nothing. He stresses could have. We may never have enough empirical info. But it is plausible and that is significant for Krauss.

A fairly 'quick' read on one of the most abstruse concept possible, the origins of the universe. Krauss does a good job summing up the development of the physics over time and their incredible implications. I was somewhat pleased to read his somewhat perplexed reaction (compared to my utter confusion) to string theory having recently finished Brian Greene's earlier effort (The Elegant Universe). I was less pleased with his recurring need to joust with the 'creationists' and theists. There is little common ground to even debate on in my mind, the two 'camps' are literally a universe apart and the twain shall never meet it seems. Science for all its power and beauty can never really answer the 'why' although Krauss gives it a heroic effort. Still, there is so much in this thin volume that I need to revisit already, the importance of the Cosmic Background Radiation and the Cosmological Constant, the criticality of a 'flat' universe, dark matter, dark energy, etc. I really wish he had provided a list of suggested further reading or any kind of reference section. It is a serious debit in an otherwise fascinating little book on a BIG subject.

Krauss is clearly brilliant, and knows lots of interesting things, but that only occasionally comes through here. There are stunning, universe-redefining revelations, but they’re often presented in a scattershot, unstructured way. Having an editor to trim the already slim volume would help, as well as keeping Krauss’s typically absent academic mind on one topic for long enough to explain it properly before moving on to the next shiny theory. Also, there’s ill-advised patter about philosophy and theology to no apparent end besides getting on the New Atheist gravy train, and Krauss gets way too hung up on the anthropic problem (without even defining it!) for his own good. Still - worth the read to know why we’re all here, just be prepared to fight for the knowledge. Like being a passenger in a Ferrari driven by someone with a twitchy foot, it’s a jerky ride, but when it goes, it really goes.

One of the finest pieces of cosmological literature that I am so glad I chanced upon. I listened to the audiobook which was beautifully narrated by the author himself. Even though I thought I knew alot about the latest and greatest in humankind's understanding of the universe, this book managed to teach me so much more and in fact left me with a very different worldview then what I had before reading it. For example I was surprised to learn that most of our universe is actually dark energy and this fact snowballs into a expanding universe which will leave humans of future with nothing to see in the night sky. However bleak as it may seem, the fact that random particles are able to come in to existence in our universe from absolutely nothing, gives me hope that we are generally moving in the right direction and as a reader I must always remember to accept the universe rather than try to listen to theologians make random justifications. Epilogue by Richard Dawkins was the cherry on the top and I have to recommend this book to any one curious about our universe.

Author Lawrence M. Krauss attempts to answer the age old question of how the universe started without getting caught in the endless regression of "first cause" or having to settle for some supranatural phenomenon or being. The first thing he defines is the word nothing. Nothing in the fabric of space and time is actually something. He goes on to describe how virtual particles pop in and out of existence and the expanding universe. There's a lot in this book to digest and it's all very fascinating. The crux of the book is that nothing is actually unstable and the universe was created a certain way because it had to, although he leaves the door open for other universes (multiverse) to have the possibility of other characteristics unknown to us. In the end, something will always arrive out of nothing. Mind bending!

Quote Review! In any case, even in a universe with no miracles, when you are faced with a profoundly simple underlying order, you can draw two different conclusions. One, drawn by Newton himself, and earlier espoused by Galileo and a host of other scientists over the years, was that such order was created by a divine intelligence responsible not only for the universe, but also for our own existence, and that we human beings were created in her image (and apparently other complex and beautiful beings were not!). The other conclusion is that the laws themselves are all that exist. These laws themselves require our universe to come into existence, to develop and evolve, and we are irrevocable by-product of these laws. The laws may be eternal, or they too may have come into existence, again by some yet unknown but possibly purely physical process.

I'm sure I got something out of this highly detailed account of the origin of the universe, but there is nothing much I can relate. Following the logic of Occam's razor, it appears that his logic regarding the necessity of a Creator is superfluous and based on prior convictions.I may have got stuck at the assertion of a flat universe.How can a flat universe contain multi-dimensional entities?The universe is the way it is whether we like it or not. p x11Science simply forces us to revise what is sensible to accommodate the universe, not vice versa.p151

This is the second of Krauss's books that I've read. It confirms my experience with the first one - I find him harder to follow than other's who write similar material. There were definitely some sections that I just didn't understand. I would like to re-read it sometime in the hope of improving that situation. That said - the parts I did understand were very interesting and illuminating and compel me to come to Krauss's defense against those detractors who accuse him of misrepresenting the kind of "nothing" that is being referred to in the question "why is there something rather than nothing?". Typically, these critics focus on the part of the book where he treats empty space as "nothing" and point out that this empty space is not truly empty due to the virtual particles etc to be found there and fail to acknowledge that Krauss himself concedes in the book that this is a valid criticism and that he then goes on to explain how it has been shown that space itself can emerge from a state much more profoundly like the kind of nothing they have in mind and that this kind of nothingness is fundamentally unstable.Personally, I think that last point is critically important and a conclusion that one can arrive at through a philosophical mode of analysis as a necessary empirical fact without understanding the how of it. The simple of it is that the kind of "nothing" that so stumps us is one in which this nothingness is the only state that exists in any sense and is unalterably stable. So defined, this is a state that is logically restricted from ever giving rise to or even co-existing with anything at all. And yet, we do exist. The conclusion that this latter fact should make glaringly apparent to us then is that the pristine, idealized, nothingness that we imagine when we ask why there is something rather than nothing _cannot_ exist. That this is so remains mysterious to me and yet it seems to be an unavoidable conclusion as is the conclusion that the closest thing to a state of nothingness that can exist must be fundamentally unstable, else, again - neither we, nor any God, or any form of anything, could exist in any way.

I listened to this book and, in hindsight, that may not have been the best idea as I am not an auditory learner. Additionally, since most of my listening time is spent in transit, I can easily get distracted if the material requires a good deal of concentration. "A Universe from Nothing" requires the reader's full attention - at least, any reader who comes in without some basic knowledge of cosmology (i.e. me). Eventually I gave in and got the e-book version of this as well so that I could read and listen at the same time, and this dramatically improved my understanding of the material."A Universe from Nothing" is an expansion of a YouTube talk that Lawrence Krauss gave for the Richard Dawkins Foundation that ended up going viral. Whereas that talk lasted for about an hour in length, the audio of "A Universe from Nothing" lasts five and a half hours. As a result, I would encourage the layman (again, that'd be me) to start out with the YouTube lecture as it succinctly sums up the argument Krauss makes here (and has visual cues to boot!) "A Universe from Nothing" is best grasped by those who have some understanding of cosmology and want to delve deeper into the topic. The topic, while hard to grasp, is nevertheless a fascinating one. I won't attempt to summarize the book's contents here because I would prove woefully inadequate at doing so. Needless to say, Krauss answers that question often posed by theists to atheists, "why is there something rather than nothing?" In short, because there has to be. The state of nothingness is so unstable as to basically make "somethingness" a foregone conclusion. Now imagine that concept explained in detail over 200 pages.Krauss is such a brainiac and so passionate about his subject that he has the tendency to sometimes forget that his readership just isn't as smart as he is. As as result, he'll start talking about things like String Theory, Dark Matter, and God Particles, while providing little to no initial explanation of what those things are - assuming that his readers already have some basic understanding of these concepts. Sadly, I did not, and Google proved a very useful - and necessary - companion piece for Krauss's book. Krauss does wax poetic and beautifully about certain concepts, like the knowledge that all human beings are the result of atoms that were cast out by exploding stars, or supernovas. So it is, he says, that the atoms that make up your right hand are very likely to have been from a different star than those making up your left. "We are all stardust," he writes, later adding that we ought to "forget Jesus" as it was the "stars that died for us". Here we come to a common criticism of Krauss that is the same we find in other scientific works or works about biology that come from atheists like Richard Dawkins. That is the belief, firmly held to by theists, that science and religion aren't incompatible. Indeed, many of the negative reviews of this book are from religious readers upset that Krauss throws the occasional jibe at religion. To which I say, OF COURSE science and religion are incompatible! How is a person supposed to believe both in the Big Bang and Natural Selection and that Jesus had to come to earth to die for our sins? The very idea is laughable. The idea of some kind of eternal state - either Heaven or Hell - where human beings go after they die? Clearly contradictory to everything we know about the universe and that Krauss writes about here. It is always necessary to refute this kind of religious nonsense because in addition to being simply wrong, it's dangerous. It's dangerous in a world where funding for scientific and medical research (e.g. Stem Cell research) is denied because those with the power to grant this funding are themselves brainwashed by religious dogma. If for no other reason, "A Universe from Nothing" is essential reading for its ability to further expose the nonsense that is religious belief and shine a light on the wonder that is the universe.

This entertaining little book was planned to be flanked by two bulwarks of atheism: Richard Dawkins, who provides the glorious afterword, and Christopher Hitchens, who was supposed to write the introduction to the book.This planned structure says something of the motivations of the book: part scientific, part anti-religious.The scientific parts works well, as far as I can comprehend them (though admittedly it's not easy for a non-specialist to comment on the validity of particular theories in theoretical physics!).The problem lies with the anti-religious, anti-theological, anti-philosophical works. They are crude and unconvincing. They might be true, but that is beside the point.For a writer who claims to want to one-up God's account in Genesis, one should be willing to put yourself to the task with some humility.The core argument is that one doesn't need a "prime mover" or a "creator" to get the whole universe rolling. I feel that Krauss manages to titillate some nerves and ruffle some feathers - but a decisive blow against the theology of creation and the philosophy of nothingness this is not. (One can always say in return: "alright, but WHO made the universe so that something can arise without an antecedent cause?") Science may throw up any number of facts, but without the logical subtlety of Thomas Aquinas and the power of persuasion of Jean-Paul Sartre, it cannot win hearts and minds. I am one of those people who doesn't need further convincing of the awesome explanatory power and beautiful poetry of science, so maybe I am not the target audience... but I find it an implausible assertion that a non-believer would repent and amend his superstitious ways from reading this book. That said, I really, really, do hope so!Frankly it is a shame that the question of theology is so prominently displayed here, since it only clogs up an otherwise interesting cosmological tale of the origins of the universe. 2/3 of the book are straightforward theoretical physics, and those are the good bits. For a lay reader they provide a fantastical tale that sounds too weird to be true, but that apparently resonates with the scientific consensus consisting of the very best minds of our times. The world really is completely amazing!Whether quantum fluctuations can give birth to "something out of nothing" - even entire universe - is a fascinating proposal, and the basic tenet of the book, that "Nothingness is unstable," lends itself to impressive and dizzying mind tricks. The book is nutritious food for thought even for philosophers and theologians, even if the author doesn't make the most of the evidence that he so dutifully presents.The story consists of black holes, multiverses, a short history of competing scientific hypotheses, space exploration, anecdotes about Richard Feynman, impenetrable mathematics, and even more juicy anecdotes about Richard Feynman...Unfortunately all this good stuff is marred by amateurish anti-theology. The book would be better without it. If something good needs to be said about the atheistic pseudo-philosophy, at least we can take solace in the fact that another gallant (if feeble) sword is directed at the Beast of Religious Belief. Religion, after all, is responsible for uncountable tyranny, stupidity and bloodshed. I applaud the spirit of the book, even while deploring the execution. PS. You may have noticed that I have said little about the science of the book. That is because it's just too difficult. I mean WTF, you can't expect a social science major to comment on black holes!Sometimes the wisest thing is to shut up in the presence of a mystery.

I finished this book very much in two minds about it. So far as the content itself was concerned, I had no quibbles: this gave me precisely the explanation of something-from-nothing that I wanted while at the same time offering me a good (and in my instance timely) update on the state of modern cosmology.I also liked very much the fact that the book isn't burdened by apparatus: it eschews the standard dozens of closely packed pages at the back of references to papers I'll never read. I get fed up of this unnecessary crap at the back of supposedly popular science books: it's not as if the author is planning to lie to me. (Besides, as has been amply demonstrated, dishonest authors can use the apparatus to aid their deception.) (I get doubly fed up when, as has happened, my publishers force me to burden a book of my own in this way!) (The worst of all is when the end notes mix these useless references with informative additional stuff that should have gone into footnotes, so that you keep having to scrabble to the back only to find, most of the time, that you've come on a wild-goose chase.) It was a pleasure to read a popular science book without this constant distraction.Rant over.And I liked Krauss's attitude toward string theory. It's plain that he himself doesn't hold much hope for it, but instead of simply dissing it or ignoring it he gave it fair air time while explaining his reservations. His approach left me with a welcome thirst to find out a bit more about string theory, of which I know abysmally little.So far so good.What really irked me about the book was how goddam sloppy it was! Clearly the people at Free Press hadn't thought it was worth doing a final proofread, because there were countless literals; most commonly, these consisted of what seemed to be copyediting changes where the original version had accidentally been left in the text alongside the substituted one (so that, as it might be, altering "What really irked me about the book" to "What really pissed me off about the book" resulted in "What really irked me pissed me off about the book"). On two or three occasions I found myself flogging my brains to understand something only to realize that the obstacle to my comprehension wasn't (just) my habitual stupidity but the fact that there was one of these maddening copyediting hiccups. There was the introduction of the Horizon Problem, only for us never to be told what the Horizon Problem actually is. There was the diagram described on page 18 with a merry "I . . . reproduce it for you later in the book"; in fact, it's on page 112, as some previous reader of my library's copy had thoughtfully noted in the margin so that others didn't have to go searching for the blasted thing. There were sentences that rambled on forever to no good purpose. (I have nothing against long sentences in principle. I object to the ones that are in effect several shorter sentences joined up repeatedly with "and".) There's the use of the term "meta-galaxy" to discuss the result when, in the far future, our local cluster coalesces; after checking the dictionary, I still don't know what Krauss thinks the prefix "meta" means. I assume he was aiming for "mega-galaxy" but got distracted along the way.Overall, then, a mixed bag. However, if you want an answer to the perennial creationist objection that "you can't get anything from nothing", this is the place to look; the book's much recommended on that basis.

And so be it: the landscape of multiple, causally disconnected universes purported by current cosmological theories may contain at least one universe with a combination of physical laws that allows what we see around us, and us to live - and all these universes emerge from nothing and may return to nothing in the long end.This statement somewhat blows out most of theology and shows how science can at least conceive of addressing and making sense of aspects of knowledge that for a long while and until recently were considered out of reach. The conclusion is the latest installment in the progression of cosmic nihilism that started with Copernicus in dethroning the centralism of humans in the universe: Earth is not the center of the solar system, the solar system is not the center of the universe, the laws of heavens are the same as those on Earth, homo sapiens is very much old, the universe does not need a creator and finally it is one of uncountably many (maybe).This books is somehow similar to Hawking's "The grand design", as the conclusion is the same and the general attitude of disdain for religion and theology is as apparent. The present book focuses much more on the fundamental role played by the energy of empty space in driving our current understanding of the laws of physics and the cosmological state of things; it also presents less history of science and at the same time more philosophical reflections by the author (plus a short crystalline postface by Dawkins to nail the coffin of the theology of the gaps - although Dawkins' comparison of the present book with Darwins' Origin of species is an exageration of sorts, if only because here Krauss is proposing no new theory but only popularising current scientific knowledge). So there is ample overlap yet also specific material that can be found in both books. Between the two, I tend to prefer this one, as it exudes less scientism (of which Hawking is a grand if myopic proponent) while leaving place for awe and reflection. Particularly, in unraveling what the energy of the vacuum implies (flat universe, eternal inflation and emergence of universes from nothing as allowed by the Uncertainty principle in quantum gravity, the current ideal window of time to confirm experimentally the expansion of the universe and the Big bang, the emergence of space itself and of matter from space by fluctuation of the nothing, the problem of the 120 orders of magnitude of error in calculating the energy of vaccum itself), Krauss goes much further than Hawking's latest vulgata - somehow, Krauss prolongs the causal sequence in the progress of theories from Maxwell onwards that in Hawking's book is so well sketched (the additional nodes are Dirac's first combination of quantum theory with relativity which predicted, to his initial despair, antimatter, and then Feynman's intuitive explanation of antimatter through his graphs, arising the concept of continuous production of particle-antiparticle pairs prescribed (since not prohibited) by physics below the Planck time and length). In both books, Feynman plays the role of the prescient hero.Ultimately, as Steven Weinberg witted, science makes possible not to believe in god, and here we have further evidence. Krauss however refrains from concluding that all knowledge will ultimately come from science, because it is not a given that a ultimate theory exists, and if it exists that we get to know it, and even then this will only set the rules of the game, which we still need to play ourselves, if only philosophizing about it.

here is my best take on "A Universe From Nothing" of which I understood some, but not all- There exists some kind of primary space, which is not the "outer space" that we think of when we think of "space". This primary space has qualities that we don't understand and it either A) infinitely big and expanding at crazy speeds or B) Science doesn't have tools to measure or understand it. (We theorize it exists because evidence of the emergence of our Universe strongly supports the existence of this primary space.) Within this primary type of space, our kind of "empty space" can emerge. This is the kind of empty outer space that we picture when we think of Star Trek, black stuff filled with little more than star dust and maybe passing light. This space, while empty of matter and what we consider "normal energy", still carries a certain energy which scientists call dark energy or "the cosmological constant" which pushes space apart. In fact, if this dark energy/ cosmo. constant did not exist, then all the galaxies would start to crash together due to gravity. Instead, the galaxies are rushing away from each other at ever faster speeds.When this empty space emerges, either it or the dark energy (I got confused reading this part) can spontaneously create matter and antimatter pairs. These are tiny particles and their negative counterparts. These tiny matter and antimatter particles usually smash into each other and annihilate each other, leaving a balance of zero energy. This apparently happens ALL THE TIME as a very small scale.However, sometimes this ratio can change and you can have more matter or antimatter. As in the case of our "big bang", the ratio of matter to antimatter began to favor matter. When this happens, it can reach a sort of boiling point which is called "inflation". During inflation, empty space can start to expand at a crazy rate. One thing that I learned from "A Universe from Nothing" is that while nothing can move faster than light through space, space itself can expand at a rate far, far faster than the speed of light and that has been happening in our Universe for a long, long time, so that even though light is shooting out towards the limits of empty space (the empty space is which is expanding into the primary space that we don't really understand), light cannot ever reach the "end of space" because space itself is getting bigger at a much faster rate.So this is how a universe can be spawned. According to modern theory, universes may be spawning all the time, all within the prime space that I mentioned above.
