By definition, most of these universes will be empty universes or maybe just beds of radiation. Only by chance will some universes reach the right level of matter vs. antimatter, the correct level of gravity vs. cosmological constant that will produce galaxies and other organized structures.Hence, the main idea of the book is that, by observing the underlying structures of our universe and the big bang that created it, we can see that "empty space" can spontaneously generate matter and energy. If this happens enough times and in enough places, then you can have an infinite numbers of universes. Some of these universes are bound to organize matter into galaxies. And, finally, that there is a lot of evidence to suggest that this is true.

There are known knowns. These are things we know that we know. There are known unknowns. That is to say, there are things that we know we don't know. But there are also unknown unknowns. There are things we don't know we don't know.-Donald Rumsfield

Albert Einstein famously expressed his intellectual queasiness over quantum mechanics when he said, "God does not play dice with the Universe". I confess that I can feel his pain. I have always found the standard model of reality propounded by quantum mechanicians, with plethora of particles, real and virtual, to be a rickety construction held together with string and super glue. The fact that this model has provided the most accurate predictions of experimental outcomes in the history of science, winning by four or more orders of magnitude over its nearest competitors in physics and the other sciences, does not dissuade me from my belief that it is an ad hoc construction which will eventually yield to a simpler, more elegant, theory once the resolution of our scientific instruments improves. Ptolemaic theory, with its epicycles, managed to explain astronomical observations and retain the earth at the center of the universe very nicely until the telescope and improved devices for measuring arcs came along. I must also confess that I am very wary of popular science books. I have resolved that I will never read any book that purports to be the Tao of anything. Now that I have confessed to two prejudices that should have prevented me from even cracking this book open in the first place, I must say that, having done so, I found it to be an exceptionally readable and cogent explanation of current speculation regarding the origin and ultimate fate of our universe. The title is serious: quantum cosmologists, using the predictive power of quantum mechanics, now assert that our entire universe arose from a pair of virtual particles which, being the negations of each other, cost zero energy. I have pondered this hypothesis, which has the further ramification that these events are occuring all the time, spawning an uncountable number of universes which are forever unreachable from our own, and I simply do not believe it. I am an apostate from the church of the dice-throwing God. There, I said it. This book is an excellent popularization of a topic which, with the recent discovery of the Higgs boson, has attracted interest of the educated reading public. Oddly, the Higgs boson is not mentioned once in these pages, which disappointed me somewhat. My only other criticism is that the author is a card-carrying member of the Dawkins atheistic science club and debating society. At times, Krauss deviates from the task at hand to attempt to explain the existence of moral imperatives in a godless universe, a challenge which has defeated a great many philosophers, most notably Immanuel Kant. Lawrence Krauss is, by all accounts, a respected and excellent theoretical physicist, but he is no Immanuel Kant. If you are at all interested in finding out about the multiverse, quantum entanglement, spawning universes like foam bubbles on top of a pint of Guiness out of the quantum vacuum of space, you will enjoy this book. If you find it convincing, you should try the Book of Genesis next. The account you will find there requires less suspension of disbelief.

Before I say anything, I was "into" nothingness before nothingness was cool.I guess I had a lot of fun, toying with existence, albeit, my version of the existence of nothingness was more philosophical and poetic musings rather than math and quantum physics. It's rather interesting that both the author and I sort of came to the same conclusion, that we are merely trying to figure out how and why the world is as it is, and that there is something rather than nothing because we wouldn't be existing to think about nothing if there was nothing.The thought that nothing is unstable, nothingness has energy, and the methodology the author steps us through to get us through was very new and entertaining. I was fascinated by the idea that being in existence meant that one was made up of energy, though it is probably common knowledge in the theoretical physics world. I guess it is definitely worthwhile to step out of one's comfort zone in thought processes once in a while.Admittedly, though the author does do an excellent job "dumbing down" some of the concepts he was going through, most of the material does require a lot of hardcore mathematical thought, especially if you have not been trained in quantum physics or chemistry. I was straining to recall all my physical chemistry and quantum mechanics from my college years to get a grasp of the concepts the author was trying to portray. Honestly, I am unsure whether a reader with absolutely no exposure to these concepts would follow through half the material in this book. Granted, I probably only got a minute fraction of the theory he was trying to explain through myself, but at least previous exposure helped me persevere through the math without freaking out and shutting the book half way.I am nevertheless bemused on why the author is so negative towards the concept of a Christian God as the creator of the universe. He slams a lot of the Bible Belt educators trying to add Intelligent Design and/or Biblical creation in part of science curriculums, which even as a devout Christian myself, I agree that all that is utter nonsense. Yet personally, I experience absolutely no conflict with the proof and acceptance of the Big Bang Theory or the theory of evolution with my Christian religious beliefs. In fact, I have a hard time understanding why people have to think it is one way or another. Perhaps I am one of those naive, hardheaded uneducated individuals trying to find meaning in coincidence that the author is trying to enlighten. But in essence, there is really no use in fighting over things that are not logical. The author's universe is undiscovered and full of surprises, and so is the God in which I put my faith. There is no way to know whether either of us found the true law that governs the entire scope of being or whether we found rules and laws that explain the environment and current existence surrounding us. So why fight about it, and just get along? Isn't the correspondence of ideas fun and time consuming enough anyways?

I find cosmological speculation to be mind-boggling but the word research may be more appropriate than speculation in this work by a theoretical physicist. I admit that I couldn’t follow most of the mathematically-based arguments that Krauss employs in this book, but I think I understood the essential gist of what he was saying – that the concept of “nothing” that most of us have in our heads is completely inadequate.  “Nothing” is actually made up of “something” which has to do with dark energy dark matter, (the stuff of black holes, string theory, faster than light concepts) most of which is unknown, if not unknowable (if we’re lucky we understand perhaps one per cent of how our infinitely mysterious universe actually functions). If I followed Krauss correctly, in the subatomic physics world of protons and neutrons, “something: does appear from “nothing” and is apt to disappear just as well.  The implications of this are profound and makes idle and meaningless, talk about a “God” who has created the universe. The traditional notion of a “God” is redundant, and besides, even if accepted, begs the question of the Creator’s origin. Why does God exist? The universe is capable of creating itself and there is no need of postulating a cause behind the “Big Bang” theory which Krauss accepts. The Big Bang came out of “nothing,” and was followed by an incredibly swift inflationary period when everything took a fraction of a second to grow through 28 orders of magnitude. It is billions of years old and may well vanish again into “nothing”. But to repeat, “nothing” is not what our conceptually-limited minds make it out to be. It’s impenetrably obscure to us - we see or comprehend virtually nothing of what is there. One of the most interesting aspects of how science approaches this subject is Krauss’ contention that “we live at a very special time. . . the only time when we observationally verify that we live at a very special time.” That means that that if we were existing in the distant future , the universe will have expanded so far that all galaxies except our own will have receded forever so there is no trace of their existence. Today we can still see their traces, even if billions of light years old. If true, all that one can say is that we’re extremely lucky .  Reading this book has reinforced for me the idea that the traditional notion of God is meaningless. “God” has always seemed to be to full of anthropomorphic wish-fulfillment fantasies. But what is revealed in this book makes one even more humble in the face of awe-inspiring mysteries that dwarf the traditional idea of “God.” To continue to exist, God has to be redefined. Maybe the ending of the Book of Job has the last word after all – human concerns and problems are simply dismissed in the unknowable dimensions of nature, or in our age, the universe.

The arguments in this book show a striking resemblance to the "inflationary model" of multiverses that is described within by Krauss. Just like an inflationary bubble of space quickly arises out of quantum fluctuations and, driven by "dark energy", rapidly expands to approximate a flat, and thus stable universe, Krauss' claims expand rapidly via dark conjecture and uncertainty, and only due to the distance one quickly reaches from the initial premises does the conclusion he makes appear to be stable or plausible at all.It would be amusing to count all the "if"s, "could"s, "might"s, "possible"s, and such that underpin the arguments of this book, but I'm not sure I'm motivated to try. Especially in the latter half, where Krauss should presumably be tying everything together into a tight conclusion, instead he presents a series of loosely connected conjectures that are riddled with disclaimers about how the science involved isn't well-understood yet.For example, Krauss brings in Feynman quantum sums around p. 162, and in the process of describing their contribution to something arising from nothing says, "[T]here is no completely unambiguous method to define Feynman's sum-over-paths technique in general relativity. So we have to make some guesses in advance based on plausibility and check to see if the results make sense." Later on he says about some of the implications, "These are open questions. However, unless one can come up with a good reason for excluding such configurations...it seems most reasonable to consider these possibilities."Near the end of the same chapter (p. 170), he states, "The lesson is clear: quantum gravity not only appears to allow universes to be created from nothing...it may require them." (Emphasis added).To paraphrase Krauss: "It's really clear that something may be the case if a bunch of stuff that we don't really know for certain might also be true. And if that stuff is true, and if some mathematics that still haven't been reconciled can be assumed to sort of work together, then it's possible that the universe could have arisen from nothing. Isn't that amazing?"I'll give Krauss credit for being honest about the tenuous nature of his conclusions, but the problem is that the book is put forth as attempt to answer a very serious question, when in reality it is completely inadequate to that purpose. And this is not to mention the serious philosophic flaws in Krauss' reasoning, considerations of which he contemptuously flicks away in a manner that demonstrates he doesn't really understand them.If this book had merely been published as a brief summary of current cosmological thinking, along with a projection of some tantalizing possibilities in the directions cosmology may go in the near future, then it would be a decent book. But as a book that claims to explain how something arose from nothing, it is a terrible failure. Hence 1 star.

The gist of Krauss's argument is that, as opposed to a closed universe (collapsing on itself) or an open universe (infinitely expanding), the universe is flat. By "flat" Krauss either refers to the boundary between a closed and open universe where there is a balance between gravitational attraction and a repulsive force that counters gravitational attraction, or a universe that is so expansive that there's no curvature. He also defines flatness as the universe "slowing down, but never quite stopping." I believe that Krauss's argument boils down to what creates this repulsive force that counters gravitational attraction. By his calculations, only 1% of the universe is the matter that consists of galaxies, stars, the earth and us. Thirty percent consists of dark matter and seventy percent comes from dark energy. Dark energy, which I think is Krausss's repulsive force, consists of virtual particles that pop in and out of existence and have zero energy, yet do all the work to counter gravitational attraction. The discussion of virtual particles seems to form the core of his argument that something comes out of nothing. Whether any or all of this is accurate is for the physicists to decide. From the non-expert reader's perspective, Krauss is a challenge. The repeated references to "a universe from nothing" come across as a mantra as he continues to move ahead with his sweep of cosmic history, in a brief book, from the big bang and its inflationary period to a distant future where all disappears into nothingness, while making a few critical comments on creationists and string theorists along the way. He crams in too much. Something needs to give. For starters, a slower, deliberate and elementary description of what's involved with virtual particles and how such counter gravitational attraction (and how that is negative gravitational pressure) would have helped explain how he gets to his central point of "exactly" zero gravitational energy that results in a flat universe. The reader understands how plus 1 and minus 1 is exactly zero but that summary leaves out a lot of information that Krauss blows through. Despite these shortcomings, this book is provoking in the best sense of the word. Krauss fills in the always mysterious "empty space" with stuff that in his argument is the engine of the cosmos itself. But still I wonder. Krauss states that Andromeda is one of 100 billion galaxies are "in our observable universe" (p. 8) and then he says that "400 billion galaxies currently" inhabit "our visible universe" (p. 107; also p. 123) and then qualifies that by saying that our galaxy is "merely one of perhaps 400 billion galaxies in the observable universe" (p. 3.) Then, in the Afterword, Dawkins says that there's 100 billion galaxies (p. 188). The discrepancy doesn't inspire confidence.

“Every atom in your body came from a star that exploded. And, the atoms in your left hand probably came from different star than your right hand. ……. It really is the most poetic thing I know about physics: you are the stardust.”- Lawrence M Krauss The book ‘Universe from Nothing’ happeningly explains about how universe is formed from nothing. It is very interesting to know that how things start to form its path from nothing. The origin of universe as known is the formation from Big bang Theory ….. but when this book came in hand I was pulled towards its fascinating title "Universe From Nothing" and so the reading started. It is understood in the book that no matter universe is formed from nothing but still it does so according to the laws of quantum gravity. So how something can be created from nothing can be explored while going through and slowly involving self within the pages of the book. Reading extensively about cosmology, particle physics, multiverses and quantum mechanics might be uninteresting, difficult, confusing and at times boring for the non-scientific reader but the black holes, dark matter and dark energy may keep it interestingly hooked. There are lot many things in the book which are hard to absorb by a non-fiction reader and hence it may require lots of patience to get involved into it, but the way the author has put it up keeps it easier for all readers to get involved and keep a person hooked passively to know more about the universe and the book interestingly. The writer explains the differences between a closed, open, and a flat universe, and puts up the reasons why we probably live in a flat universe. He also explains about how the scientists claim so precisely the four figures as ‘universe has expanded for 13.72 billion years since the big bang theory’. But at times to understand the context clearly and get to the bottom of the arguments, the pages have to be turned back again and again. At times there is a conflict of mind while reading to understand ‘what we know’ from ‘what we don’t know’. Also the lesser known facts and scientists explained adds to the knowledge and understanding of the reader to full convincing. Science will continue to evolve …. But how we look at it and how much we come to know is a very wide thing as the observable light we can see today may shift so far on the light spectrum that it may become invisible ……. And eventually everything will come to an end. "Quantum fluctuations, which otherwise would have been completely invisible, get frozen by inflation and emerge afterward as density fluctuations that produce everything we can see! If we are all stardust, it is also true, if inflation happened, that we all, literally, emerged from quantum nothingness" ….. very interesting :)

A most interesting book with flawsKrauss is a brilliant guy with a lively style but this book, despite offering the general reader some real insight into contemporary cosmology, and some rye jokes, was a bit of a disappointment to me. The main problem I think is that Krauss doesn’t come to grips with the implied question in the subtitle, “Why is there something rather than nothing?”First he wants us to know that “why” questions are really not science, they’re philosophy. The question our esteemed author insists on is “HOW is there something rather than nothing?” But this is not the same question.Next there is the sleight of hand with the notion of “nothing.” Putting aside word play such as the ambiguity in, say, “nothing matters,” it is not correct to say that the universe came from nothing because it came from the expansion of space. Space is not nothing, as Krauss admits on page 152. The question then would be why does all this space exist? The answer, it came from inflation. But inflation required energy and that also is not nothing.So all of Krauss’s talk (from the also brilliant Alan Guth, by the way) about the universe being the ultimate free lunch is just that, talk. The plain truth of the matter is that, yes, the question “Why is there something rather than nothing?” is a philosophic question and not the sort of question that physics can answer. However it is not a subterfuge for slipping God into any equation (as Krauss implies), although I suppose some people do that. It is instead a profound question that has been asked, as Krauss points out, since antiquity with still no answer in sight. If we could get an answer as Hawking said, we would know the mind of God.Krauss gives physicist Frank Wilczek’s answer which is that “nothing is unstable.” Somehow I didn’t get the proof for that except to understand that virtual particles go in and out of existence in “empty” space according to quantum mechanics, which I don’t doubt. However again it is the case that that empty space is just not empty so there was never any instability between nothing and something because there never was any nothing. The problem as I see it is the limits of our science. There is something about space that we just don’t understand. We know from Heisenberg’s uncertainty principle that space cannot be empty, but we don’t know why—or, as Krauss would have it, we don’t know how space could be empty.I could give you the answer, “nothing is impossible,” which after reading this book, seems more and more likely, yet there is no way I or anyone else can or has demonstrated that nothing is an impossible state of the universe. Yet it could be true.It is rather annoying (I imagine that Einstein, James Clerk Maxwell, Niels Bohr, et al. are twirling in their graves) to see physicists today doing either math or philosophy and imagining that they are doing physics. I will give Krauss credit though. He gently makes it clear that string theory, for example, is not science. (See pages 130-134)As far as the cosmology and physics in the book go, I think Krauss makes some things that were previously opaque somewhat clear. Take for example why inflation occurred. It seems (as Guth realized) that “as the universe cooled, it underwent some kind of phase transition—as occurs, for example when water freezes to ice...” (p. 96) This led to the release of energy as “latent heat” leading to the incredible inflation that expanded the universe by a factor of more than ten to the twenty-eighth. Now THAT is an expansion.I also liked the suggestion that the Big Bang may have spawned multiple universes. However those other universes apparently are not in any practical sense part of our universe because inflation pushed them so fast and furiously away from us that their light will never reach us. These I believe are different than those that some physicists believe came into existence outside the Big Bang. (pp. 128-129)One thing I didn’t understand is this: Krauss says that the universe is currently flat; however in the future it will be open, so ultimately the universe is NOT flat. Have I got that right?Another thing I didn’t get is this: Krauss tells us that during some time in the past before the dark energy of space exceeded the gravitational pull of matter and radiation that the expansion of the universe was slowing down. Does he mean that space was contracting or just the matter and radiation? If space itself was contracting then we have a mind’s eye picture of a shrinking ball of space with matter and radiation within getting closer together. If only matter and radiation were contracting while presumably space was expanding or staying the same, we have a picture of the bubble of the universe with lots of space along its boundaries (if we can speak of boundaries of space) while nearer the center are matter and radiation. Which is it? I don’t know.Puzzling was Krauss’s insistence that we live in a “special” time because the contractive pull of matter and radiation exactly matches the expansionary force of dark energy. (pp. 122-123) I think it is only special to us (or actually only to cosmologists) and moreover this special time probably spans millions of years.Okay, now for some Kraussian jokes.First a string theory joke. He writes, “...the Nobel Prize-winning physicist Frank Wilczek has suggested that string theorists have invented a new way of doing physics, reminiscent of a novel way of playing darts. First, one throws the dart against a blank wall, and then one goes to the wall and draws a bull’s-eye around where the dart landed.” (p. 134)Here’s a bit about particle physicists and the anthropic principle (sort of): “Cosmology has produced one totally mysterious quantity: the energy of empty space, about which we understand virtually nothing. However, particle physics has not understood many more quantities for far longer!” He adds further down the page, “Maybe all of the mysteries of particle theory can be solved by invoking the same mantra: if the universe were any other way, we could not live in it.” (p. 136)On the last jocular point I would say, maybe not us but some other creatures, and they would be invoking the same anthropomorphic principle and calling it by another name.Krauss remarks that “one way to see a supernova is simply to assign a different graduate student to each galaxy in the sky. After all, one hundred years is not too different, in a cosmic sense at least, from the average time to do a PhD, and graduate students are cheap and abundant.” (p. 20)Actually the best joke in the book is also a double pun on the phrase “universally attractive”: “Any high school student will happily tell you that gravity sucks—that is, it is universally attractive.” (p. 77) (No, I will not explain this.)Another question about the nature of the state of nothing is, could there be nothing but the laws of nature existing in truly empty space and time? Or put another way (and I wonder if this is ~ Krauss’s position) there is something rather than nothing because the laws of nature will always be there whether there is space and matter or not.Near the end of the book Krauss does explicitly address the essentially philosophic nature of the question at hand. Brushing aside the need for a First Cause, he writes: “...empty space or the more fundamental nothingness from which empty space may have arisen, preexisted, and is eternal.” (p.174)Best and easiest answer I think.—Dennis Littrell, author of “The World Is Not as We Think It Is”

The book requires a certain amount of familiarity with complex theories for one to be able to keep pace with the topics discussed. Most those with such foreknowledge may find little new though until in the last quarter. The short book moves too fast while discussing topics old and new. Various sections are well written but could have been far more effective if the author had added alternate descriptions for emphasis and summaries/repetitions to bring the point home.A rationalist's causal tale of creation has the same issue as the creationists' turtle-on-the-back-of-another varieties: one falls prey to an infinite regress until one reaches a point whether one leaves the rest to a God or what the author presents here: the emergence of something out of nothing. The author has brilliant rationalist descriptions on such a creation but with two issues.One, the author's story is based on the premise that "nothing is unstable". However, his nothing is not a true nothing.: it is a state without matter but with all the quantum physics laws that we have valid in this universe pre-existing. From such a nothing, it is conceivable to create a universe but the question has been pushed back only marginally from Big Bang as the starting point to a state of no matter but all existent science law as the starting point. While the author touches upon this flaw towards the end, he does not realise that compared to the evolution description from Big Bang to now, the step from nothingness to Big Bang is not only tiny and highly speculative but also without much utility at scientific or philosophical levels.Two, the author does not sufficiently explain the creation of excess matter or photons from nothingness and inflation despite many hints. A nothingness can spontaneously and briefly give rise a pair of particles (like matter anti-matter). There is a small chance that one such pair fails to annihilate as is its want in a fraction of time, because before it does inflation within one of the constituents lead to a massive creation of excess material. While it is possible to see such a material creation when pairs are created at the boundary of a blackhole for example, there is not sufficient description on how this could be the case during the inflationary phase in our universe.All in all, what is attempted is bold. The writing style is quite lucid despite the complexity. The book could not have provided answers that don't exist. With more descriptions, a lot more could have been addressed.

This is Lawerence Krauss's attempt at denying the existence of a deity through explaining the current state of physics and cosmology. It follows (with much more detail) his RDF foundation lecture which was up until recently on YouTube (and which I enjoyed immensely).The current state of physics parts of the book are quite informative and bring thing almost up to date - I can't pretend I understand all of it (to paraphrase Richard Feynman "If you think you understand it, then you don't understand it") however it has cleared up a few questions that I was only vaguely aware had been resolved -such as 'does our universe have an open, closed, or flat topology' and 'Why does the cosmic microwave background radiation appear lumpy' - both of which are answered here (and in this spoiler (view spoiler)[ a) it is flat, b) because nothing travels faster than light and local variations in the plasma of the big bang would not have time to 'equalize' as per expected theories since the expansion of the plasma was at or close to the speed of light  (hide spoiler)]).Of course it is very difficult to explain very bizarre ideas, such as those that arise from modern physics and cosmology to dim witted person-sized earth-dweller such as myself - and especially to do this without any mathematics and I credit Krauss for this and for the fact that I did actually increase my knowledge of the universe through reading it. The difficulty is the constant references to the G-Word, which are completely unnecessary in my view. Anyone reading this book is unlikely to need to be convinced of the existence or otherwise of a first cause, and frankly the sheer beauty of the ideas, if understood, is highly unlikely persuade you either way - after all the 'first cause' in the case of the universe is still unknown, and will probably never be entirely provable anyway.The idea of 'something from nothing' is also fascinating and is an interesting idea. Suffice to say, if the theorists are right here (and they think they are!) then it is possible that the universe just popped into existence of it's own accord. And I guess if it happened once...One annoying thing however is that, in my copy least, the figures used to illuminate the text seemed to be sequenced badly and lacked captions. This made it difficult to identify which figures related to which chunks of text!

I was turned on to this book when watching an interview with Christopher Hitchens, prior to his passing, where he referenced it. In short, he said that it was a fascinating book which made a compelling case for why (and how) the universe could, indeed, have been created from "nothing," rather than by a "first cause" set in motion by a creator.I find the idea provocative, because it has been something philosophers, theologians, and people of all kinds have struggled with forever. Atheists have always struggled to answer the basic question: "if there is no creator, than what created creation?" Certainly, a scientist believes in the big bang as the ultimate creation of the universe, but what created the singularity that exploded in that moment? Maybe it wasn't the Judeo-Christian God, but surely it could not have simply appeared spontaneously out of the nothingness.Similarly, the religious among us have also struggled with the concept of God himself. If God created the universe, than what created God? Typically we get answers to this question that are, to be kind, cop outs. "He is beyond time" or "he has always existed and will always exist" or "he is beyond understanding." These answers have never been particularly satisfying to me. After all, if you believe that about God, you can just as easily believe that the universe itself is eternal, and has always existed, and did not have an ultimate "beginning" to it. Indeed, many theoretical physicists have argued over the years that the universe as we know it began with the big bang, that it will re-contract in on itself in a big crunch, and explode again in another big bang, in an eternal cycle.Regardless, being fascinated by both the philosophical and scientific aspects of the questions of existence, and the nature of creation, I thought the book sounded fascinating.And to be sure, it was very interesting. Krauss is one of the lesser known but still prominent purveyors of "popular science" -- scientists that are quasi-celebrities as they try to make science have mass appeal -- but he is still a brilliant cosmologist, and you can hear his mind at work in the book. And the book was definitely interesting and worth my reading it, for sure.My relative disappointment in the book, though, came from a couple places.First, it seemed to me like the provocative thesis and title of the book was a bit of a cover for him to talk about general cosmology, and in a way that, at least to me, sounded like he was attempting to lord his knowledge of the subject over the reader.There is no question that you have to do a fair amount of scientific explanation to set the table for why and how the universe may have emerged from nothing, but the number of topics he covers in cosmology, particle physics, quantum mechanics, relativistic physics, electromagnetism, and so many other areas, left me with the impression that he was attempting to show off in the hopes that he was writing a new version of A Brief History of Time by Stephen Hawking. Much of it was not essential to the ultimate argument he was making. To me, a lot of the book was superfluous, if admittedly interesting.I was also left with a bad taste in my mouth by Krauss' attitude, throughout the book. I understand he is decidedly an atheist and is not fond of those who have faith, but in my opinion he had a sneering, elitist, arrogant attitude about those who do. Yes, I understand he has had to debate some young Earth creationists over the years and those conversations have left him frustrated in his perception of those folks. But the concept of existence and where it came from is something that he himself acknowledges has been philosophized about for thousands of years. So having a holier than thou attitude about others considering the question of existence just seems misplaced to me, no matter how wrong he may think they are.I'd have much preferred if he reflected some understanding of why people look for answers they can understand, and simply stuck to explaining why he thinks there is a new way of thinking about it that might give us greater understanding. Instead, I got a bunch of snide remarks that expressed his contempt like, "everyone, except [fill in a group he considers irritating] agrees with me." Unnecessary, and petty if you ask me.My second, and arguably more important criticism of the book, is that he never really pays off the premise of the book.Like a person who spends ten minutes setting up a joke with a lame punchline, Krauss spends most of his book bringing us to a point where we are ready to hear his ultimate point, and then spends about half a chapter on it, and doesn't really pay it off.I thought a lot of the journey along the way was quite interesting, and set the table nicely. He explained, for instance, why and how quantum particles can, in fact, materialize out of nothing, and then disappear into nothingness. This got me really interested, but was still ultimately unsatisfying, because as Krauss himself point out, that observation still requires some kind of existence, and some kind of instigating event for that materialization out of nothing to occur.Great, because he moved on and acknowledged that limitation, and then brought us more information, at one point showing that in a multiverse, a universe with our specific design is the only type of universe to be created that could in fact survive long enough to not blink out of existence quickly, and thus give rise to life that can even ask the question of where it came from.Also interesting. Also provocative. But that is more or less where he stops. He concludes with some thoughts that basically boil down to "our universe exists the way it does and was created from nothing because in the multiverse this is the only place it could've happened." It was circular logic that didn't ultimately satisfy the paradox in most of our heads: why is there something? From where did it originate? If from a God, what created God and what was there before? If from another dimension, what created that dimension? If some kind of complex multiverse, from where did it originate? Basically, how did existence become existence? It is a logic puzzle that we have never satisfactorily answered -- and may never satisfactorily answer -- but yearn to search for.Unfortunately, as much as I did enjoy the book and found it interesting, I don't think it paid off the claim made on its cover. Certainly not "enough" that it would cause me, an enthusiastic consumer of science material who knew much of what he described in the book already, to give it my highest recommendation.

In his book, Lawrence M. Krauss asks the question of why there is something instead of nothing, that is, why does the universe exists instead of not existing. Why are we here, doing what we do, instead of not being here. While this opens up inevitable questions regarding the meaning of life, the universe, and questions regarding a possible creator, Krauss is more focused on looking at how physics explains the existence of the universe. He looks at scientific discoveries that have shaped and pushed forth the idea of the big bang theory and how this relates to the universe being here and how it might all end one day.I enjoyed reading this book largely as a result that even though it begins with a philosophical approach, it really builds its argument largely with a close summary and analysis of the basic tenements shaping the big bang theory and its implications. As someone who isn’t a physicist, but fascinated by the subject matter, I found the book to be written in a straight forward style that invites the reader to gain a fundamental understanding of how science explains the universe, its properties, and what we can still learn and predict. There’s a good amount of philosophy integrated in the book, but in my opinion, I would have liked more of it. However, Krauss, ultimately, brings everything together with the notion that the fact that there is something from nothing, despite it being able to be explained through direct and calculated science, results in something magical that can be appreciated despite the fact that we may never discover what it all means.

I’ve been a fan of Lawrence Krauss for several years. He’s a dynamic, entertaining science communicator and a very bright guy. As I write this, his You Tube video on the subject of this book (A Universe from Nothing) has 1.5 million hits. That’s not as many hits of course as stupid cat videos, but I find it encouraging. I saw Lawrence at The Amazing Meeting a couple of weeks ago in Los Vegas and he gave a great talk. His writing is accessible to non-technical people and since I always enjoy essays on science history I thoroughly enjoyed is summary of cosmology in history. I’m not sure Krauss mentioned it, but the science of cosmology has probably increased its knowledge by two or three orders of magnitude in the past 20 years (about the time Carl Sagan died). Modern physics is amazingly complicated but Krauss makes much of it understandable on some level – I particularly enjoy his explanation of ‘inflation’ which finally made sense. Of course if we accept some or any of the premises of modern cosmology we do so on the basis of authority, but it’s an authority acceptable to me because scientifically authoritarian communicators have been vetted by the scientific method. This book is interesting and provocative and I certainly recommend it. If you don’t want to invest the money or time for the book (its actually a fairly quick read), then at least invest an hour in the You Tube video.

This link gives a good overview of the subjects covered: http://newbooksinbrief.com/2012/01/28...Humourous, elegant, with a definite awe-factor, and thought-provoking, most of the science not too hard to grasp if you have an ability and determination to grasp abstract concepts, and an open mind free of hubris. Carl Sagan would have liked this book, ditto Richard Feynman, who, along with Charles Darwin, are science heroes of mine. Poetic and poignant as well, for example:"The amazing thing is that every atom in your body came from a star that exploded. And, the atoms in your left hand probably came from a different star than your right hand. It really is the most poetic thing I know about physics: You are all stardust. You couldn’t be here if stars hadn’t exploded, because the elements - the carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, iron, all the things that matter for evolution - weren’t created at the beginning of time. They were created in the nuclear furnaces of stars, and the only way they could get into your body is if those stars were kind enough to explode."From the emergence of the universe, from nothing, 13.72 billion years ago, to its likely future, this book is an excellent overview of current thinking, from long and intense observation, of quantum physics and cosmology.

The Author has succeeded in producing a relatively (no pun intended) easy to read book on some quite complex concepts in Physics - in particular the areas of Quantum Mechanics and Cosmology. I enjoyed that he included quite a bit of the History of the fields involved - and probably would've appreciated a bit more - as I do think he could've better explained the history of the conflict between Relativity and Quantum Mechanics.Like most books covering topics on "breaking edge" Science, the Author will probably need to do an update. Assuming of course recent Science Alert type posts regarding Dark Energy et al are reliable.However, I do disagree with the Philosophical conclusions that the Author makes - which should be expected. Though I have post-grad qualifications in Science (Mathematics), I am a Lutheran Pastor - so it shouldn't come as a big surprise that whilst I enjoy and appreciate the Author's Physics, I would not so much enjoy his evangelistic drive for Atheism. I would be tempted to suggest that the Author talks more about God than any other Physics books I've read - including those written by devout Christians.So if you would like a good read into modern Physics research this is a good choice, though I would caution you in regards to the "New Atheism" interjections throughout.

I get the impression that this book is taken as yet another book whose intent is to announce the death of any realistic need for religion (following Harris, Dennett, Dawkins, Hitchens, etc.), and rightfully so. It more or less completes the puzzle, bringing in a cosmological perspective of what amounts to a naturalist view of reality. By the end we are left with a wonderful account of why science and reason trumps theology in the pursuit of truth.Given the distinct possibility that most of the people who will pick up this book are already convinced of that notion, the book nonetheless has great value. It provides a wonderful survey of the bleeding edge of physics, and is worth reading if you're interested in getting a good perspective on a very abstract science. He simplifies the concepts (omitting very little of the original theories, I might add) in a way few are able to. I definitely prefer his explanations to Brian Greene's (not to undermine Greene's efforts one bit).Prof. Krauss is definitely a better public speaker than he is a writer, and his humor comes out better in person than it does on the page. Regardless, we still get plenty of his charm and authority in the text, and it is a pleasure to read. Quick, too; I read it in a day.

There is something fascinating and wonderful about a book like this, even though the science is WELL beyond my comprehension, there is a comfort that comes from the logic, the questions, the admitted problems and unknowns, the theories and current research.... In some regards, reading this book is much like reading scripture. In both there is much I don't understand or comprehend, and in both there can be found comfort and satisfaction. However, in scripture the comfort is superficial and often has a half-life that leaves me realizing the comfort is illogical, even immoral, and thus it is an unstable and unsatisfying comfort. In a book like this from Dr. Krauss, however, the answers don't need to be fixed, the science can be outside of my mental capacity to understand but I can have more "faith" in what I don't understand because the science is continually looking to disprove and better understand. Scripture demands my faith in absolute believe without doubt and science rewards my doubt and welcomes my questions, never with the hubris of a preacher but only the inquisitiveness of very smart people looking for real answers.And to hear someone like Dr. Krauss talk at this level is truly inspiring.

Summary"A Universe From Nothing" argues that modern physics is starting to shed light on questions as foundational as "why is there something rather than nothing?" Kraus doesn't purport to provide an ultimate "answer" to the riddle existence: he simply points out that science is making progress. The very fact that this question is suitable for empirical inquiry is pretty remarkable, and Krauss's presentation of what we've learned so far is fascinating.While this isn't the best book to dive deep into the physics itself (Kraus's treatment is a bit unfocused and cursory), "A Universe From Nothing" is notable for changing the way you think about the "big questions." I left with a better appreciation for how ill-suited our intuitions are when it comes to understanding the nature of reality, and sense of amazement that, if we take the laws of physics as a given, they might actually predict a "universe from nothing."A decent tour of modern cosmologyMuch of the book consists of a tour of modern cosmology: the big bang, inflation, the fact that the universe is expanding, the shocking discovery that this expansion is accelerating, and the implied existence of dark energy. Props to Krauss for taking the time to explain how scientists were led to these (often unexpected) conclusions, but otherwise its pretty standard pop-intro-to-cosmology stuff. My main complaint is that it's not always clear how these discoveries relate to the question at hand: namely, why is there something rather than nothing?Quantum physics casts doubt on our intuitionsBefore we can take a stab at answering said question, we'll need to challenge some seemingly reasonable assumptions, such as the idea that you can't get "something" out of "nothing." Virtual particles serve as a poignant counter-example. In short, quantum physics predicts there are particles and anti-particles constantly popping up "out of nothing" and subsequently annihilating themselves. They're called "virtual" particles because this happens so quickly that we cannot, due to the uncertainty principle, observe it directly.Still, virtual particles have a measurable effect on their surroundings, and you need to take them into account when calculating things like the energy spectrum of hydrogen ("the best, most accurate prediction in all of science"(68)). The point is, virtual particles don't care that they violate your intuition. A hundred years ago someone might have argued, on philosophical grounds, that "something" can't come from "nothing." Today we no longer have to philosophize. We know, on empirical grounds, that it does.Quantum gravity (might) predict a universe from nothingOur intuitions rewired thus, Kraus points out that once you have a quantum theory of gravity, quantum behavior applies to the fabric space itself. In fact that, just like quantum mechanics predict particles appearing out of nothing, quantum gravity predicts space itself appearing out of nothing. This gives us "one way of thinking about the answer to the question of why there is something rather than nothing: nothing is unstable." (159)Now, we should be a bit wary here. We don't yet have a mathematically consistent theory of quantum gravity. We use "approximate" theories, and thus the resulting predications need to be taken with a grain of salt. Even so, it's delightful to think about the implications of such a (prospective) finding. We'd effectively be in a situation where the laws of physics actually predict that a universe like ours will have "popped up out of nothing." And while we'll still need to account for the laws themselves, it's pretty amazing how much we'll have removed from the philosopher's and theologian's domains.Can we explain the laws of physics themselves?Kraus briefly talks about how a multiverse might help explain the laws of physics themselves, but at this point we're on purely speculative ground. And that's OK. The point isn't that science has all the answers. It's that it might. Or rather, that it has more answers than we previously thought, and that when faced with "the big questions," we should hesitate before declaring them outside the realm of empirical inquiry.Conclusion"A Universe From Nothing" is by no means perfect. Its exposition of cosmology is too superficial if you already know a thing or two, and not high-level enough if you don't. It's a book that should have either been much shorter or much longer. The good stuff, though, is great. At its best, it's a meditation on the relationship between science and philosophy, and an ode to following the evidence, wherever it may lead. If you consider yourself a bit of a science-and-philosophy nerd, it's worth checking it out. A lot of smart people have spent their lives speculating about the mystery of "existence." In "A Universe From Nothing," you'll finally get to hear what nature has to say. Notable Quotes"'Why is there something rather than nothing'... is first and foremost a question about the natural world, and so the appropriate place to try and resolve it, first and foremost, is with science." (xiii)"Lack of comfort means we are on the threshold of new insights." (xv)"The job of physics is not to invent things we cannot see to explain things we can see, but to figure out how to see what we cannot see." (26)"A truly open mind means forcing our imaginations to conform with the evidence of reality, and not vice versa, whether or not we like the implications." (139)"[As to why there is something rather than nothing]": I am going to assume what this question really means to ask is, 'How is there something rather than nothing?' 'How' questions are really the only ones we can provide definitive answer to by studying nature." (144)"One way of thinking about the answer to the question of why there is something rather than nothing: nothing is unstable." (159)"Why is there something rather than nothing? Ultimately, this question may be no more significant or profound that asking why some flowers are red and some are blue. 'Something' might always come from nothing." (178)

This book was quite a let down. I'll have to admit that the title was quite the hook for me, implying that it would show how physics solves the philosophical question of existence, but a more accurate description would have been: how matter is created out of pre-existing empty space that is embedded with energy and shaped by pre-existing cosmological constants, which doesn't have quite the same ring to it, but that's really what he's talking about here. He seemed to have a God fetish, and he occasionally made mean-spirited side comments about Americans that had nothing to do with the subject at hand; I wasn't sure if they were supposed to be jokes or whether he just had to get his European superiority complex off his chest (not that Krauss is European himself). The material in the first half of the book is old news to anybody who even casually follows science, and I don't think that he did a good job describing the more abstruse material in layman's terms (not that this is an easy endeavor, it's just that he didn't pull it off--Dawkins' afterward seemed to indicate that I wasn't the only one that wasn't quite sure if they understood Krauss right).

In the interest of full disclosure- I am a huge science geek, but it's been a while since I've read any good science books. This one is great. In attempting to answer the question of why or universe looks, acts, and occasionally smells the way it does, the reader is given a tour through physics, quantum mechanics, relativity theory, string theory, and many more gobs of awesome science stuff. This is the kind of book I would love to see take hold in public schools in the states. It seems we as a country are turning away from science and become more subjectivity in our thinking. I remember teaching in Santa Fe years ago (so old, oh god!) and having parents tell me that we should be teaching creationism in schools. Or at least not be teaching that "other theory" in the interest of respect and fairness. Books like this, if read by the general populace, would make us a better society, because it puts the kibosh on all of that. Well written and can be understood by laymen like me (although certain parts I had to read through a few times to really get the concept). Where did we come from? What does nothingness even mean? If you have ever asked those questions, read this book.

I should preface this review with the statement that I am relatively familiar with the material in this book, having done some fairly extensive reading on the subject -- I have a doctorate in Particle Physics, although left the subject immediately after gaining my doctorate; I started reading on the subject of "Physics I missed since" after I retired.I had hopes for this book, and indeed found it very readable for most of its content. However, towards the end it changed into rather a polemic against philosophy and theology. Now, I am sympathetic towards what one might refer to as a "rationalist" approach to the discussion of whether there is a supreme being/force/whatever. But I didn't think that that part added much to this book. I would have preferred the author to confine himself to a logical presentation, without involving criticisms of philosophers and theologians, regardless of how deserving they might be of those criticisms. For that reason, I gave the book only 3 stars instead of 4.The author has a pleasant writing style, and conveys his explanations of physics theory and observations well, with some good analogies.

Not unexpectedly, Krauss writes in the same manner in which he speaks; long, drawn-out, and oftentimes irrelevant. While the book itself was short, I often found myself perplexed, particularly towards the end, at the sophomoric philosophical practices illustrated in this book by an overly confident Lawrence Krauss. Krauss finds the biggest strength in his book by showing off his knowledge of theoretical physics. The biggest weakness, his overwhelming failure to philosophically interpret any scientific information, which essentially overrides the strength he does have. Along with his philosophical 'dumpster-fire' analysis, he makes a hearty attempt at convincing the ill-informed that 'nothing' is 'something'. Krauss, being a huge advocate for scientism, makes a sincere effort to reconcile his faith in atheism by casually proclaiming that a natural process created something from nothing. Lastly, Krauss, while good in his field, is a horrible philosophic mind and shouldn't consider making an attempt to answer philosophic questions like, 'why is there something rather than nothing?', particularly if he despises philosophy.

Technically, I didn't finish, but I had less than 10% left, so I think I can safely give a review.1. I find myself to be a fairly intelligent person, but this was way above my reading level. I would read a paragraph and then hope the next paragraph would explain the last! Granted, I took physics for architects, so my background is sketchy, but still for a book for laypersons it was extremely difficult to read.2. I get it that the author is an atheist. I get it that he doesn't want 'believers' using his theories to promote their ideas. But I don't get why he insists on belittling persons of faith. Repeatedly. As a believer in a one true God, I think that what I could understand of his book only reinforces what I believe. We can't see 90% of the universe? Huh, I wonder what sort of forces are dwelling in the unknown? He calls it dark energy. Fine. I would rather be 'dark energy' than obliterated into nothing when I pass on from this life. 3. If you are interested in the Universe and need graphics and visual aides, go to Discovery Science and search for 'universe.' It is amazing how the universe was made from nothing...

This is another well-done book explaining the origin and evolution of the universe based on up-to-the-minute theoretical insights and experimental discoveries. A particular virtue of this book is that it does not talk down to the reader, as many do, although I would have appreciated some mathematics which is a much more concise way of conveying the ideas.Richard Dawkins provides an afterward in which he concludes "If the On the Origin of Species was biology's deadliest blow to supernaturalism, we may come to see a Universe from Nothing as the equivalent from cosmology." Well...that is quite a recommendation. Although I don't think it rises to such prominence, I would offer this book to anyone who wants to brush up on the latest picture of reality.While it seems unlikey that anyone whose processes of independent thought have been paralyzed by the toxin of religion would ever pick up this book to read, Kraus has done an admirable job in portraying a real universe full of wonder without the need to invoke the supernatural.

This book is a real mess. It's like he's thrown a load of scientific discoveries in the air and they have landed all over the place, like iron filings on paper. A science writer needs to apply a magnet to these facts so that they become an explanatory story. This is just a list of stuff he knows. The Dawkins afterword is unbelievable in its gush. Suggesting that this book might come to be seen as being as important as the origin of species is just ridiculous. There is nothing new in this book and its contents are not in any way orchestrated.The description of how we come to know what we do about the universe is fascinating but incomplete. This book needed to be 700 pages long, but that would have meant he'd have to actually explain things to us non-physicists fully and after reading this, I just don't think he is capable of that.Finally, I know he won't like this comment, but no matter how stylishly he dismisses people who say he doesn't address "nothing" sufficiently, he really doesn't address "nothing" sufficiently.

This is an amazing book. In extremely simple, even layman's language, this book explains the latest achievements in the fields of physics and cosmology and provides insight into the past, the present, and the future of the universe we live in. I read this book in a single breath - it's a real page-turner (or whatever it's called on Kindle).The only thing I disliked in this book is that it has to deal so much with theology and creationism. It makes me really sad that we live in a world where scientists have to waste their energy fighting myths and proving science right and myths wrong. Science works, as Richard Dawkins nicely puts it in the epilogue, it yields results. I am looking forward to the day when Krauss and others will write books such as this without having to discuss why physics is more plausible than theology, and why no God is necessary. But then again, if that was obvious to everyone, maybe this book would be unnecessary. And that's why I give this book five stars. Amazing work.

Honestly, it is a terrible book for all audiences. It is intentionally deceptive and only ceases to prevaricate in the last few chapters. When you finally get there, you will have laboriously read through a jumble of unstructured fluff that his editor certainly did not read. The content is far and few between and uselessly applied to anyone genuinely interested in any topic it presents. He intentionally sweeps over statements that demand more clarification, and never fails to use ad hominem whenever he meets an objection.If you are a theist who is interested in the arguments of atheists, do not read this book: it has nothing for you. If you are an atheist who is interested in learning more about your worldview and the sophisticated expressions of it, do not read this: it has nothing for you.I could say more, but it has already been better said by someone else. I direct anyone who might read this to click the following link and read the short review. http://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/25/boo...

Mind=blown!I don't know where to begin, or whether I can succinctly say why this book is so amazing and so important!Krauss takes us on a cosmological voyage, explaining some of the most intricate, complicated, and simply inexplicable ways of understanding our universe. It isn't an easy read for someone with no firm background in physics, and it helped me to have some of the background in order to understand this book better. I had to go back a few times and re-read certain passages because I just couldn't wrap my insignificant little brain around it. That's the beauty of this work. Prof. Krauss' ability to explain something so convoluted to the reads is astonishing. And, while the faith of our universe may be bleak, our universe is so invigorating and provocative. Thankfully, we have people such as Prof. Krauss to study it and unravel some of the mysteries.Amazing read. I'd give it ten stars.

Very misleading title. 80% of the book is a commentary of what other great scientists have said much before this book was written. In the last 20%, the author explains a physical phenomenon that is so fast and microscopic, that it appears to be 'nothing.'Then the author conveniently uses the word 'nothing' again and again, and explains how the big bang happened because of 'nothing.' Then, with a masterstroke of deception, the author wraps up the book by implying that the universe came about from nothing, in a literal sense.This is flawed logic. Something being 'seemingly nothing', and 'nothing' are universes apart. Also, to write a book titled 'A universe from nothing,' where you supply the definition of 'nothing' makes no sense. Nothing means nothing. It doesn't mean a certain tiny level of matter and anti matter oscillating very fast. That would still be something.The title must be 'A universe from something so small, that it looks like nothing'.

Lawrence Krauss is a lucid writer on science topics but I see few people that'd benefit from this book. The overview of science is a summary rather than an introduction except on some topics where the author seems to inconsistently go into depth. The difference between BOOMERANG and WMAP are neat but not necessary and seem to be largely filler in this otherwise thin book. The author talks about "symmetries" but doesn't really describe the much more in-depth types of symmetry that science provides vs. say left-right (bilateral) symmetry. There was little discussion on why some things are conserved and others are not and this is both handy in explaining a lot of things and quite beautiful.This is short for one of my reviews as this book is like most of Krauss's, very meh. Watch the YouTube video of his presentation on the universe from nothing if it saves you the cost of this book.

Disappointing compared with Krauss's other great books. It was dense, difficult, meandering, and ultimately unsatisfying. Krauss accuses his critics of changing the meaning of the word "nothing," but it just doesn't seem fair to call empty space "nothing," as Krauss does. Empty space has properties, and nonexistence is not among those properties. Empty space has height and depth and length and volume. Why is there empty space instead of nothing? At best Krauss shows only that a universe from nothing is plausible, and four-fifths of the way through the book, Krauss, himself, changes the meaning of his terms, deciding that the real question is to ask "How" is there something instead of nothing, not "why." But the real question, properly understood is this: Why is there something instead of nothing--wouldn't it be easier for there just to be nothing?

Although I have to acknowledge that a lot of this book was over my head, the ideas and discoveries expressed in it demonstrate how amazing our natural world is and how amazing it is that there are people among us with brains big enough to figure it all out without resorting to divine intervention. The fact that it has taken only a few thousand years to learn so much about a universe that is billions of years old, with huge leaps being made over just the past century or so, is mind-boggling. Some reviewers have complained that the author bats down theology and creationism in this book, but when you have science being pushed out of classrooms in favor of non-scientific, religion-based concepts of existence, I think it's a perfectly valid topic to include in a book about the universe.

Lawrence Krauss may be a little irreverent, but he's an excellent cosmologist. He's already updated this book once (Higgs boson discovery at the LHC), and modern physics is exploding with both new discovery and new questions, so I wonder if current models and theories will change radically in the next few decades.I read this book piecemeal over quite a long time due to workload and several other books and projects that intervened, so I'm hesitant to try and put together a genuinely coherent review. However, I can say that whether you like Krauss or not, you have to admit he's always interesting, and he's very proficient at breaking down complex concepts into understandable chunks.I happen to enjoy both science and a bit of irreverence. I'd like to reread this book when I have more time to focus on it.

Krauss gives an interesting summary of recent cosmological research. But his philosophical maunderings are unconvincing. Also, he makes an interesting linguistic blunder in my view. He does not define "Nothing", and even seems unaware that this word has different meanings in different contexts. Thus "I did nothing all day", or "there's nothing in this jar", or the like do not mean "no thing". Similarly, it turns out that empty space can give birth to "something". But saying that something came from nothing is rather vacuous (pun intended). He would have been better off if he had used another word, like "space" instead of "nothing". As I "read" the book on audio CD, it would have been a lot more easy to follow too, as I could not tell when he meant "nothing" and when he meant "Nothing".

When I was taught the story of the Babylonian ziggurat as a young Catholic, I remember thinking, "This is stupid 'cause mountains are taller than towers, right?" I wasn't sophisticated enough to understand what I realized now: god destroyed the Babylonians for the sin of being capable. Science is the modern ziggurat, an edifice hundreds of years in the making that can see back in time 13.72 billion years and predict into the future trillions more. If they were capable, we are more so. I'd like to say I understand all the details and implications of Krauss's writing, but I can't. I got the broad strokes, and that's enough. The idea that the universe has net-zero energy makes so much sense. Now that the idea is in my head, I can only say, "Of course. How could it be otherwise."

"This is the beauty of science…science forces us to revise what is sensible to accommodate the universe rather than vice versa."This book is a vastly expanded version of a talk by the author that we attended six or seven years ago. While Krauss can be a bit abrasive, he is an excellent speaker and the topic is a fascinating one for me (as I'm keenly interested in cosmology and physics). Since I listened to this on audiobook, I think I need to re-read it as a physical book; there were many notable passages and sections that I missed when the environment around me became noisy. It is well worth re-reading even if I'd not missed any part of it.

I'll admit, I'm not up to speed on my quantum or theoretical physics, or my string theory :) I was a bit lost at times, but got the over all point. Yes, we can come from nothing, there doesn't need to be a sky daddy. And there's scientific evidence that we did poof up from nothing. Because nothing isn't nothing. And some day way in the future, we'll poof back into nothing. Unless, we destroy the planet first, but that's a whole 'nother can of worms.It was interesting. I think it could have been written for a broader audience/easier understanding. But there's only so many ways to make physics interesting. All in all, it was decent and informative.

Absolutely the worst book on modern cosmology in the library. First, this guy can't write. He has no discipline, can't stick to one thought at a time, and often casually inserts personal stuff into the scientific narrative. Second, his arguments are a pastiche, not tightly woven, borrowing from here and there, losing the reader. Third, his central point, that something can come from nothing, slips into the book for about 2 pages, unexplained and undefended, and then he briskly moves on as if it was established. As the NYT Book Reviewer said in his final note, this book is just dumb. There may be much more to the science he attempts to describe, but this is a disservice to the discipline.

Make no mistake, Lawrence Krauss hasn't actually answered the question of how a universe--any possible universe, including ours--could arise from nothing. But he does make a damn compelling case that such a thing might not be very far outside the realm of possibility; in fact, it may turn out to be an inevitability based upon the problem of Nothing. Nothing, a word which in everyday parlance has a specific meaning, turns out to defy our intuitions at the quantum level. This shouldn't be too surprising. The history of science (including and especially physics) is the history of the universe kicking our 'common sense' in the nuts over and over . . . and over.

A Universe From Nothing was a good read. I am by no means scientifically minded but I still appreciated hearing Dr. Krauss' explanation of a possible beginning from nothing. I agree that it is lazy to fill unanswered gaps with God but I cannot release the idea that there is something out there. He/She/It may not have created the universe but my wishful thinking wants to believe there is something greater than us. Regardless of our beginning, I agree with Knauss' approach of scientific proofs rather than Creationist's "because the Bible says so" approach.Ultimately, I liked best the quote from Richard Feynman that Dr. Knauss referenced, "I don't mind not knowing. It doesn't scare me."

A lucid explanation of physics up to this point, with some interesting speculation and philosophy mixed in. Dr. Krauss is quick to reveal places where it might be tempting to draw certain conclusions but backs away from them for reasons he reveals. I found this candid honesty made the book more enjoyable. Two additional notes, I would argue the universe (potential multiverses)Krauss describes is not incompatible with Zen Buddhism in its simplest form. Further, I found the hubris of Dawkins' epilogue nauseating. There is no God and Dawkins is his prophet.

This book(let?) is an expansion of that famous hour-long physics lecture on YouTube. While the lecture had frustrating moments when Krauss skipped expanding on interesting themes due to time pressure, this book is not actually as much fun as the lecture. The jokes are the same but the delivery in prose suffers compared to the video. So, you should watch the video, and then maybe come back to this afterward. With that said, there's a wealth of fascinating material in here, and it is quite engrossing in its own right; it's just by contrast that it suffers.

There's some fascinating ideas in this book including the disappearance of the evidence for the big bang and inflation due to inflation. However, the book is too short to give a full explanation of the ideas, theories, and evidence he presents. Using my previous readings to inform me, I could follow his logic and his conclusion -- something from nothing is possible and thus the Prime Mover isnt necessary. On the basis of this book alone, others may not be so easily convinced. Still its one more nail in the coffin for the cosmological argument for God.

This book could not be more of an eye opener to not why, but how we exist in this universe. Every chapter is like opening a treasure chest and discovering something new about the life we live in. Krauss's words are poetic as well as understandable to even those who don't know an ounce of physics or cosmology. Even the afterward by Richard Dawkins is insightful and witty. He reminds us of the astounding facts we just read. Because after this book, your mind will be blown away... Which may become a reality sooner than we think!!

Listening to this book was cool, though I zoned out some. Instead of persistently rewinding, I absorbed what I could and may revisit it later. Dawkins's afterword was lovely. As other reviewers said, Krauss's Cosmology 101 was solid. His exploration of string theory was less so, but that wasn't the focus anyway. I enjoy ontology and science, but I think biological sciences are more my speed generally. Chemistry is hella-cool, but I usually think of it in terms of metaphor. Hence my majors in English and psychology and not anything useful :-)

It's really hard to rate/review a book you don't understand but here's my best shot. This book covers both a "primer" on astrophysics and a debate on how our scientific view of the universe compares with what has traditionally been the domain of theologians and philosophers. The main claim is that the universe arose from nothing, that it will likely revert to nothing and that we are in existence at a fortunate time when we can actually see these changes taking place around us - in the distant future, all traces of the Big Bang will have disappeared due to the expansion of space.

A fascinating read, if a bit technical at points. I think with such a topic, the author has done a fine job of distilling the information into layman's terms. My only real complaint is in regard to his unapologetic attacks on "god". They seemed unnecessary to the narrative and a show of intellectual jousting aimed at proving the "god" notion wrong. I think he should let the book and science speak for themselves.

I really enjoyed Lawrence Kruass hit youtube video "A Universe From Nothing" so I eagerly anticipated this companion book. I feel like the book was more difficult to follow than the talk and though it espouses the same ideas doesn't so such in such a revolutionary "ahHA!" manner. I still think it's an excellent book, but I don't feel it would be as effective without the talk to put it into simpler terms.

Why is there something rather than nothing? Mind boggling to think about. Krauss explains current thinking about the origin and future of the universe and why it looks like it does. He makes for clear explanations, but I'm sure I couldn't explain it to anyone else without a ton of handwaving; I'm a poor vessel for all the details. Still, what he does make clear is how all the theories and research add up to a coherent, if complete, picture of the universe. Would make good re-reading.

Krauss is clearly brilliant. The book is ambitious (massive understatement), and well done. It's deliciously, intentionally hostile to religion. Not sure why I didn't give it a 5 other than I reserve 5's for books that either (a) drive me to tears, or (b) make me dizzy with enthusiasm for living and learning, or (c) both. This book got close but not quite (CBNQ). Take home message "nothing is unstable". Read it if you want to find out what that means.

This book is the indirect result of quantum fluctuations of nothing! Ok, I'm loaded with jokes about nothing inspired by Krauss sense of humor and refined irony. Even the chapters’ titles are entertaining and the content devastating as Dawkins concluded. I looked at the starts today and saw the past being transmitted all the way to my eyes through nothing! Nothing storing the past… is poetry from nothing… mind blowing book!

Krauss unabashedly explores his thesis with verve, keen attention to scientific detail and writes with unadulterated intelligence; simultaneously not dumbing down the mathematic and scientific elements of the text and also writing with an open, sometimes hilarious style that is easy to grasp for the average reader. The updated edition is excellent and features a killer afterword from Richard Dawkins. Exciting, rich reading.

In this book you get an idea of modern cosmology and how it's possible and even almost necessary for nothingness - no matter, time or space to be unstable and put forth something. It's also one of those books that points out that we live at a rather special time, when it is possible to come to right conclusions about the Universe - that it's expanding and that there was inflation and the Big Bang right at the beginning of time and space. Quite an easy and interesting read.

Though not as elegantly written as 'A Brief History of Time' or even 'The Grand Design' (both by Stephen Hawking, the second in collaboration with Leonard Mlodinow), it more succinctly summarizes the problems and implications of our current theories of cosmology and explains why our universe may have spontaneously arisen from nothing through quantum fluctuations — and not only why it may be possible, but also why it may be plausible and perhaps even likely.

There's a LOT of information packed into this rather quick read. A bit overwhelming to tell you the truth, but still completely fascinating. Both Carl Sagan in PALE BLUE DOT and Lawrence in this book stress the importance of doing as much as we can to study the cosmos and the origins of the universe right now while we really have such unprecedented access to it since, because of inflation, cosmologists in a few hundred thousand years will be unable to see what we see now.

Enlightening, informative, and encouraging. This book answered several questions I had about the origin of the universe and the nature of the big bang. The ideas and theories this book explains are so profound they seem obvious (although not necessarily easy to grasp). There were a few parts that felt like I was trudging through some cosmic sludge, but for the most part Dr. Krauss keeps a quick tempo as he takes the reader through the biggest questions humans have ever asked.

This is a short summary of modern cosmology, with (yawn) a bit of polemic against religion. The book is based solidly on accepted observationally confirmed science, with barely a mention of more speculative ideas (one critical page on string theory, a few references to the multiverse.) Not much that will be new to anyone who reads much popular science writing, but a good starting book that is relatively up to date.
