Reading this book was like a funfair carny explaining how he hides scorpions in his rectum for his magic act. The parts I understand are fascinating, but because the information is coming from an unfamiliar, niche subject it can be confusing and the parlance, at times, is incomprehensible. Definitely worth reading for the mind-blowing parts but I think some things aren't meant to jive in a regular human brain...

My brain hurts after trying to digest this book. I must say the author offered some interesting and rather compelling information regarding the origins of the universe and how the Big Bang came to be. The idea of something from nothing makes sense now. Sorta. I will have to re read this book again to fully grasp it. Overall, it was thought provoking, fascinating and immensely informative.

A very good book Lawrence Krauss gives an interesting and at times depressing view of the universe and its future. The inevitable emptiness of space and how in a trillion years, all the evidence we have for our current view of the universe will vanish faster than the speed of light.As he said "We live in a special time"

This is a great book, by a great author. Still, Krauss cut a few corners too many. Unless you do know the physics behind the story, it's hard to finish this book without thinking that Krauss expects you to trust him on a lot of the details. Which you should, of course. I just like it when they take they trouble to explain everything.

The beginning and end of the universe calculated with some precision based on actual evidence. Not that I can understand it, but it is great to have someone taking a credible approach. The author would have us "marshal the courage to live meaningful lives in a universe that likely came into existence, and may fade out of existence, without purpose, and certainly without us at its center."

I liked it but I didn't love it -- not because it was not a fascinating subject but because quantum theory just eludes me much of the time, even when brilliant people like Krauss do their damnedest to dumb it down for me. The ideas presented are fascinating, though. The afterward by Richard Dawkins is a gem too, a gem that is possibly the high point of the book.

The information is well presented and the ideas are quite large. Now, my physics are rather weak overall, but most of the concepts presented were explained in way I could keep up with few exceptions. For the parts I had trouble visualizing/ fully grasping I am going to blame myself rather than the text and that is why I am giving 4 stars instead of 3. Worth reading.

Recommended for many reasons: He was a great friend to Christopher Hitchens, and espouses many of the same principles governing our existence but through a scientific lens. He writes clearly and eloquently, and can explain basic quantum mechanics and theoretical physics to a complete novice. His infectious excitement for his discipline is honest, humble, and genuine.

I'm a sucker for cosmology books. Krauss' book intrigued me most in the musings that quantum fluctuations are what allow the universe to be created from nothing. Also intriguing is that current theories would not be verifiable in a trillion years or so -- not that that will matter much. It is also a good overview of what has transpired in cosmology in the last 100 years.

Fascinating, though sometimes a little much for a layman to grasp. I had to go the audiobook route because just looking at it was daunting, though I would recommend that method of digestion for this book, as Krauss makes for a great narrator, and his passion for the subject matter comes through in spades.

I really like some of Krauss's books, as well as all his lectures, however this book lacked something important: a point. Although he tries constatly to make, he doesn't seem to have given it the amount of attention need for it to be noted. It is, however very wel writen and comprhensble enough for someone who is not familiatr with physics.

Hawking's Grand Design is said to be "a mind blowing stuff" , I can tell that this expression best describes this great book . The complete change in my way of thinking deeply owes two books : "The First Adventure of Mind" , and "A Universe From Nothing" . Here is the scientific version of "The Myth of Sisyphus" .

Sometimes I wonder how is it possible that scientists work everyday and for many years with this kind of theories and knowledge while the general public is left (sometimes willingly) in the dark. This is a really good book.

Krauss is extremely good at explaining complex concepts in terms that, while perhaps not easy to grasp, were understandable. (I admit that several paragraphs required reading through a couple of times!)

This is an excellent overview about why there is something rather than nothing - why the universe exists. A very easy read with lots of excellent information. Highly recommended. Spoiler alert - a supernatural being is not needed to create our universe.

Excellent cosmology but inept and frankly disrespectful ontology. Don't use the word nothing if you mean something. The title, if it was being honest and not just trying to drive book sales should have been 'A universe from the quantum foam'.

A scientist's view of philosophy that misses the point but at least tries to answer the fundamental question of where everything came from ... Yes, there are more energy states where something rather than nothing would exist but where do the energy states come from etc. etc.

For a non scientific person like me, at times it was difficult to understand. However I've gained some scientific knowledge from it. I also love history, and the historical background to the study of universe was fascinating!
It felt like Sheldon Cooper was lecturing me. I don't know if I got much out of it. It was heavy on theory and light on empiricism. It's a short book so I may reread it or just find something better.
http://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/25/boo...https://www.quora.com/How-is-the-zero...

Overall I liked the book, but it seemed to lack an answer to its own question. Also whole paragraphs seemed more of a review of philosophy than science, which would be an easy pitfall given the subject. Overall I enjoyed his lectures more than this book.

Not as tough to digest as “A Brief History of Time,” but not for the faint of heart, either. My main take away was that things like life and the universe can come together more randomly than one might think.

Well written, an interesting and very informative read. The science doesn't get so deep that you lose interest yet there is enough detail to keep it interesting and provide enough detail to understand the concepts and follow the logic of the narrative.

Lawrence Krauss has put together a fine introduction to the current state cosmology that is marred only by a provocatively metaphysical title to which exposition attempts to hew. Authors often lose control of their titles, and Krauss may have argued that subtitle should have read “How there is something rather than nothing,” or even better “How there is something in addition to nothing,” (which would surely be more consistent), but, really it is the metaphysics of “nothing” in the title that make it less than it could have been. But I get ahead of myself.Krauss appears to have two main aims in A Universe From Nothing. One would to make modern cosmology interesting and accessible to those, such as myself, who frankly don't have the background to understand cosmology at its deepest level. Here Krauss is brilliant and elegant. Keeping analogies and diagrams—which tend to mislead more than they enlighten—to an absolute minimum Krauss moves from the relatively straight-forward (why it is that it appears all galaxies are moving away from when the Milky Way—or any other galaxy for that matter—is not the center of the universe) to the more obscure but profound, (just what is this thing called inflation that comes—in cosmic terms—hard on the heels of the big-bang, what is it suppose to explain, and why it is an integral part of cosmology rather than an ad hoc support). He even makes a foray—albeit somewhat non-committal—into string theory. Those who want to know about dark matter, dark energy, negative energy,1 virtual particles, or quantum fluctuations, could do much worse.There is also much that is truly thought provoking on an existential level. For instance, Krauss clearly argues that given the state of our current knowledge, future advanced civilizations on worlds yet unborn would have far fewer clues than do we about the origin of the universe. The background radiation, that cold echo of the big-bang, will be too faint to detect. Galaxies will be so far apart that they will not be visible one from another. At such a time, the only reasonable conclusion one could reach would be that the universe is much smaller and never had a beginning. One cannot help but wonder, what is it that we have missed—could not help but miss because we have come upon the scene when we did—that would change our body of knowledge. On the other hand one might ponder, what phenomena might arise some billions of years from now that on a cosmic scale is simply hidden from our current view. Such a provisional view is quite humbling. On the other hand, minds such as Krauss, may delve in new directions and make these constraints moot. We just don't know all that we can't know.Now for Krauss' second aim—an aim which almost certainly is the reason for some of the effusive praise found on the dust-jacket—that cosmology shows that creatio ex nihilo is no big deal, that it happens all the time, and so that God either doesn't exist or is not necessary (which really amounts to the same thing). Here Krauss engages the reader on a philosophical level—a discipline Krauss elsewhere has demonstrated little patience. However, the nice thing about philosophy is that just about anyone can participate. If one is willing to ignore a few gratuitous swipes,2 the philosophy is quite approachable. Moreover, while most of us cannot engage deeply enough to critique the physics in A Universe From Nothing, almost anyone can evaluate a philosophical argument delivered on the popular level.Krauss deploys two basic arguments. The first runs something like this: The argument that philosophers and theologians3 offer for the existence of God is everything must arrive from something (ex nihlio nili fit4) but that the chain of one thing arising from another cannot be infinite. So, the chain must end with God. But, every instance of nothing that philosophers and theologians offer is either too vague to be evaluated by scientific means or is such that science has shown that something can arise from it. Moreover, philosophers and theologians fall back to ever more abstract and absurd notions of what nothing is whenever science is able to show that something comes from nothing, but this line of reasoning cannot go on forever either. God is not necessary for the creation of the universe.Although the form of the cosmological argument that Krauss seems to be critiquing starts with something along the lines that everything that began to exist was caused by something else, rather than that from nothing, nothing comes, it is a safe assumption that Krauss would consider nothing that “something else,” so we can simply proceed to the second premise. For the first charge, Krauss maintains that the typical characterization used by philosophers and theologians of nothing as the negation of being is vague and untestable and so cannot be demonstrated as true.Much of the rest of the A Universe From Nothing, can be seen as directly or indirectly supporting the position that any sensible idea nothing is enough for something to arise. Whether one is talking about virtual particles springing from empty space, the net energy in the universe being zero, or the false vacuum that propelled inflation in the early universe, Krauss would maintain that a physicist can come up with a more common notion of nothing than a philosopher. In fact, the progression of the book is such that we are led to ever rarefied versions of nothingness. One can picture Krauss prodding his implicated interlocutors, as if saying “Is this nothing enough? No? How about this?” Indeed, Krauss accuses philosophers and theologians of changing what they mean by nothing in the face of science showing that something can come from nothing.In reply, one could reply that while “negation of being” might sound a bit esoteric and obfuscating (the notion of being is not easily approached), one could suggest that if something exists, then it isn't nothing. Now, the idea of existence may be just as vexing as being, but philosophers would agree that if something exists it has being and both philosophers and physicist would agree that if such things as quantum fluctuations and such are real, then they exist. If existence as such isn't the sort of thing physic can evaluate, then it says more about the limits of physics than it does the nature of existence. Unless Krauss would want to argue that things that exist arise from things that don't, it would seem that adage “ex nihlio nili fit,” still applies.Krauss' further gambit that philosophers progressively move away from more common sense ideas of nothingness to more obscure ones as physics discover something arising out of nothing does not gibe with the history of philosophy. Krauss quips that he imagines that Aristotle and Aquinas thought of nothing as empty space. On what this imagination is based is hard to say. Aristotle argued against the existence of the void. The choices before us would seem that he either held empty space to be something or (and this seems more likely) impossible. One could also point to more modern reflections in the correspondence between Clarke and Leibniz. Clarke held (with Newton) that space was absolute, but would have hardly thought of it as nothing. Leibniz, idealist that he was, held to a relative view of space such that if there were no objects, there would be no space, empty or otherwise. One might further argue that Kant's famous antinomies of time and space loose their force unless space is considered to be something.The problem we have here is that while we might be able to conceive of nothingness, we can hardly be said to be able to imagine it. When trying to imagine—or if you will, picture—nothingness we can only go upon ever more rarefied things that are next to nothing. This is a problem of which Krauss should be very familiar. Human beings do not live at the scale of either the quantum world or the cosmic. We really cannot imagine things at those scales and explaining them by what we commonly experience is fraught with limitations. Common sense ideas tend to break down at the extremes. It seems shortsighted to reserve this judgment for science while denying it to philosophy, and it would seem that philosophers have held a very radical view of nothingness for millennia.It may well be on account of this radical nature of nothingness that philosophers such as Aquinas never used ex nihlio nihil fit5 as a premise but only as a supporting argument.6 The shame is that the only conclusion on can draw from ex nihilo nihil fit is that existence as such is necessary, not that a necessary being exists. Perhaps The Necessary Universe: How There is Always Something When There's Nothing There, just didn't make for as good a title.Although initially directed at the so-called fine-turing argument, one almost guesses that Krauss senses that nothingness is not the issue, because toward the end he pivoted to a different line of argumentation. The most promising explanation for the origin of the universe predicts the existence of multiple universes. Multiple universes dispense with the need for a creator of the universe in the same way that natural selection does. Even if one could argue that God is somehow behind the existence of these multiple universes, their very necessity renders God redundant and by Ockham's Razor nonexistent.One does not have to be a physicist to find multiple universes (along with string and brane theory) appealing and intriguing. While a thing's being appealing (as Krauss frequently notes) doesn't make it so, those of us who are not cosmologists should best allow those are to play out the promise of multiple universes. For now, let us who are not in a position to pass judgment accept that this is just one of an unimaginable number of universes.The second line of the argument simply goes after the fine tuning argument. The fine tuning argument is merely Paley's teleological argument on a much larger canvass, and so any successful critique of fine tuning only goes to show that a good analogy doesn't prove anything.Of these, it is the third that may be the most interesting because buried there is the idea that the cosmos is necessary insofar as all possibilities (and so all potential) are realized. Multiple universes hold out the promise that the cosmos is fully actual and so, in a way, a necessary being.There are, however, some prima facia objections that A Universe From Nothing doesn't address. Assume for the moment that there are multiple universes and that there always7 have been. Each universe is in a system of multiple universes that can be seen either as distinct state of affairs, or possible worlds8 (because they are mutually inaccessible, following David Lewis), or as a single state of affairs or possible world (because only as a whole would they constitute a maximal state of affairs, following Alvin Plantinga). For convenience sake, let us continue to call the former “multiple universes” and the latter a “multiverse.” Looking at multiple universes, it should be pointed out that while possible worlds are not sets but states of affairs that have mereological qualities, once one compares the properties of one state of affairs with another, one is talking about sets. Now the interesting thing here is that even if the number of possible worlds is infinite (and as best as I can tell, brane theory stops short of that) that in Zermelo–Fraenkel set theory not all possibilities are realized because there can be no universal set. One can argue about Zermelo-Fraenkel, but it is not at all obvious that set of universes is necessary at all.So much for looking at things from the vantage of David Lewis. Looking at things from Plantinga's point of view,9 the reason for the multiverse is that it is a consequence of physical laws of this universe and the Platonic horde of universes is necessary for this universe to exist. Anyone who has read Kant should see what comes next. Simply because the laws that make this universe possible necessitates the existence of a multiverse does not necessitate the multiverse itself. One could dispense with both the consequence and the antecedent without contradiction. It would still seem possible that none of these universes exist or that there could be universes that are superficially similar to ours (at least at the macro level) but whose underlying natures are radically different. That is to say, there might be a host of possible multiverses that could exist, but only at the exclusion of all the others if actual. One might reply that such speculation is quite out of bounds of any science as utterly unknowable and should not even be considered,. However, philosophers are inclined to ask such questions, and if it is unknown that such radically different universes exist that would exclude our multiple universes, it is unknown that this multiples is the only one. So, it cannot be said with any certainty that these universes, even if they as a whole always existed, are necessary.While Krauss supplies no sustained argument, A Universe From Nothing displays a distinctly anti-metaphysical cast. For instance, while Krauss rightly observes that most “why” questions are really “how” questions. Questions such as “Why is the sky blue?” might be better recast as “How is it that the sky is blue.” Not only is this a more accurate—albeit less elegant—construction but is one that the sciences are ideal at analyzing. Krauss then maintains that all “why” questions that cannon be construed as “how” questions deal with ethics. From here it is easy to see that since asking why something rather than nothing is not a moral question it must be a “how” or mechanical question. The possibility that why something rather than nothing might be neither ethical or mechanical is never addressed. One could argue that question of existence rather than non-existence is fundamentally an ontological or metaphysical issue.Krauss ends A Universe From Nothing with a reverie on the meaning of life. There is an almost Stoic resolve that although the universe itself has no purpose and his place in it is utterly insignificant, he is able to draw meaning from life. Krauss is at least polite enough not to point out that even if the universe has a purpose, there is no reason to conclude that any given member has one. It is also true that even if we do have a purpose (or purposes), there is no reason to conclude that the universe is the sort of thing that has one.10 What is curious is Krauss' turn of phrase—drawing meaning from life. One would have thought it better for him to say that meaning was something he created (from nothing?) for himself. However, to draw suggests that there is something there, at least implicitly, that even if there is no meaning in the universe itself, meaning can emerge from the universe. Regardless, metaphysics looms close by whether one draws or creates meaning.There is also the question of just what is meant here by “meaning.” Is it simply a feeling of fulfillment (in which case, what is one pursuing, the feeling or the fulfillment) or is it some agreement between one's nature and one action or direction. Perhaps the feeling that one's life has meaning is a defense against the fact we do indeed signify nothing.These would seem to be perfectly reasonable questions for anyone to ask. Stoicism (or any other of a host of alternatives) is perfectly respectable. Yet the question of meaning has meaning, though it would not appear to be one within the canons of physics (or biology for that matter). Yet choosing a general ethical outlook is not something that can be done within any given ethical system but upon the nature of the good. That nature is essentially a metaphysical. If such a question is worth pursuing, perhaps others, including why there is something rather than nothing, are worth their while apart from physics.___________________1I'm erring in putting these two in close proximity. They have less in common than the nomenclature might suggests.2There is the old chestnut about scholastic debating about how many angels can dance on the head of a pin, treating the Euthyphro dilemma as if it were newly invented, and assuming that like physics, knowledge in theology must be cumulative and progressive. 3Krauss frequently lumps philosophers and theologians together. While there are a fair number of people who can be characterized both as philosophers and theologians, there are a great many from each camp who would rather not be associated with the other. Krauss' target is likely philosophers who have strong theological commitments, e.g. Christian philosophers.4From nothing, nothing comes.5It is of passing interest to note that creatio ex nihilo can be taken in two ways, as creation out of nothing (the affrimation that God required nothing outside the divine nature, or the denial that God made the cosmos from some outside substance unrelated to the divine nature) and creation from nothing (that God used nothing whatsoever to create). One could argue that any theology that allows some meaning to divine attributes must deny the idea of creation from nothing [whatsoever].6Actually, medieval philosophers were more concerned with ex nihlio nili fit as an objection to the traditional doctrine or creatio ex nihlio. The affirmation of ex nihlio nihil fit (with which these philosophers agreed) seemed to entail that the cosmos was eternal. Aquinas, for instance, did not attempt to demonstrate that the cosmos had a beginning, only that ex nihlio nili fit was consistent with the cosmos having a beginning.7Always would almost certainly have be understood in a non-temporal or eternal sense here.8“Possible world” is a term of art used by modal logicians for a state of affairs that can somehow be considered complete. Such state of affairs do not have to be very large in order to be considered worlds, but since the cosmos is an actual complete state of affairs, it qualifies as a possible world.9Actually, I'm stretching things a good deal here. Even if Plantinga were to concede that multiple universes could constitute a signal state of affairs, he would still insist there are multiple multiverses.10For instance, during a rush hour commute one may reasonably ask where each of the drivers is going, but it would make no sense to ask where rush hour is going.

I intend to write a long review of this book. I was enthralled because of the brilliance of the genius exhibited by the developments of modern science up to p. 140.I was appalled by the non-paradoxical use of the phrase "Nothing is something" on the first quotation page and in the chapter heading on p. 141 and following. At least the medievals had a better way of putting the problem, "What is not, is."Addition: In his metaphysics, Aristotle had a short answer to the notion of Nothing is something. "For everything that changes is something and is changed by something and into something." The quantum field which is denominated as nothing, changes...Much more to follow. Here it is... Quotes and comments in a rambling sort of way.Krauss, A Universe from NothingXii Nevertheless, the declaration of a First Cause still leaves open the question, “Who created the creator?” After all, what is the difference between arguing in favor of an eternally existing creator versus an eternally existing universe without one?NOTE: To say First Cause assumes that that cause is with all other causes in the same genus.xiv-v Now, I am told by religious critics that I cannot refer to empty space as “nothing,” but rather as a “quantum vacuum,” to distinguish it from the philosopher’s or theologian’s idealized “nothing.”So be it. But what if we are then willing to describe “nothing” as the absence of space and time itself? Is this sufficient? Again, I suspect it would have been … at one time. But, as I shall describe, we have learned that space and time can themselves spontaneously appear, so now we are told that even this “nothing” is not really the nothing that matters. And we’re told that the escape from the “real” nothing requires divinity, with “nothing” thus defined by fiat to be “that from which only God can create something.”NOTE: Actually, what those who say that there is creation actually say is creation from no preexisting subject.p. 135 Rather, we can imagine an infinite number of universes stacked up above a single point in our space, invisible to us, but each of which could exhibit remarkably different properties. I want to emphasize that this theory is not as trivial as the theological musing of Saint Thomas Aquinas about whether several angels could occupy the same place, an idea that was derided by later theologians as fruitless speculation on how many angels could fit on the point of a needle—or more popularly, on the head of a pin. [Not quite but close. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/How_many...] Aquinas actually answered this question himself by saying that more than one angel could not occupy the same space—of course, without any theoretical or experimental justification! (And if they were bosonic quantum angels, he would have been wrong in any case.)NOTE: I think this paragraph comes close to what is the difference between those who think all is physical and to those who do not. I suspect multi-universes stacked above a single point takes more faith than thinking immaterial beings exist but be that as it may, Aquinas does give a theoretical argument as to why more than one angel cannot occupy the same space. In the first place, it is not occupy in our sense. In the second sense, the angel is “there” because of a manifestation of power, not because of a spatial relation.p. 143 At the same time, in science we have to be particularly cautious about “why” questions. When we ask, “Why” we usually mean “How?” If we can answer the latter, that generally suffices for our purposes, For example, we might ask: “Why is the Earth 93 million miles from the Sun?” but what we really probably mean is, “How is the Earth 93 million miles from the Sun?” That is, we are interested in what physical processes led to the Earth ending up in its present position. “Why” implicitly suggests purpose, and when we try to understand the solar system in scientific terms, we do not generally ascribe purpose to it.NOTE: Right! If one defines science as the empirical and mathematical verification of physical knowledge, absolutely. The issue is whether this is the only kind of knowledge that human beings can have.pp. 146-149 I have already argued in the preface to this book that merely defining “nothingness” as “nonbeing” is not sufficient to suggest that physics, and more generally science, is not adequate to address the question. Let me give an additional, more specific argument here. Consider an electron-positron pair that spontaneously pops out of empty space near the nucleus of an atom and affects the property of that atom for the short time the pair exists. In what sense did the electron or positron exist before? Surely by any sensible definition they didn’t. There was potential for their existence, certainly, but that doesn’t define being any more than a potential human being exists because I carry sperm in my testicles near a woman who is ovulating, and she and I might mate. Indeed, the best answer I have ever heard to the question of what it would be like to be dead (i.e., be nonbeing) is to imagine how it felt to be before you were conceived. In any case, if potential to exist were the same as existence, then I am certain that by now masturbation would be as hot button a legal issue as abortion now is.NOTE: The shallowness of Krauss’ use of the definition of potential with respect to sexuality stuns me. One definition is: “(often potential for/to do something) the possibility of something happening or of someone doing something in the future.” The problem is that there is another definition of potential in physics: 2 Physics the quantity determining the energy of mass in a gravitational field or of charge in an electric field. There has to be a field of some sort for the electron-positron pair to pop out of empty space. That field is “something.” It has to be near a nucleus…p. 148. Let’s now turn to one of the most remarkable features of our universe: it is as close to being flat as we can measure. I remind you of the unique facet of a flat universe, at least on scales where it is dominated by matter in the form of galaxies, and where a Newtonian approximation remains valid: in a flat universe, and only in a flat universe, the average Newtonian gravitational energy of every object participating in the expansion is precisely zero.NOTE: I do not understand this. The theory is apparently opposed to the notion of a curved universe and mandates that parallel lines will remain parallel. Whatever it means, I have always been curious about “space.”a. First of all, is there an edge to space. Could we get to the edge of spaceb. Secondly, it seems to me that to say there is space implies there is something there, even if there is nothing in parts of it. For space implies extension and extension implies that something is there somewhere which is measurable. p. 149-150. First, I want to be clear ab out what kind of “nothing” I am discussing at the moment. This is the simplest version of nothing, namely empty space. For the moment, I will assume space exists, with nothing at all in it, and that the laws of physics also exist. … I suspect that, at the times of Plato and Aquinas, when they pondered why there was something rather than nothing, empty space with nothing in it was probably a good approximation of what they were thinking about. 	As we saw in chapter 6, Alan Guth has explained precisely how we can get something from this kind of nothing—the ultimate free lunch. Empty space can have a non-zero energy associated with it, even in the absence of any matter or radiation. General relativity tells us that space will expand exponentially, so that even the tiniest region at early times could quickly encompass a size more than large enough to contain our whole visible universe today.p. 151. It certainly seems sensible to imagine that a priori, matter cannot spontaneously arise from empty space, so that something, in this sense, cannot arise from nothing. But when we allow for the dynamics of gravity and quantum mechanics, we find that this commonsense notion is no longer true. This is the beauty of science, and it should not be threatening. Science simply forces us to revise what is sensible to accommodate the universe, rather than vice versa. NOTE: I have to presume that there is non-zero energy as a kind of field, in space, or making up space, I do not know. But with both space and non-zero energy, there is something around. In a funny kind of way, Krauss in the paragraph on p. 151 is announcing the new metaphysics. I wonder if Krauss thinks that Plato and Aquinas meant by something, “matter.” Be that as it may, cf. the following paragraph in (following up on pp. 149-59):Thomas Aquinas and Big Bang Cosmology William Carrollhttp://www3.nd.edu/Departments/Marita...“Joseph yciski has described well the confusion between metaphysical nothingness and the concept of a vacuum in contemporary physics. Even in the absence of particles, "physical fields do not disappear, and their properties still can be characterized in the abstract language of mathematics."(35) In attempting to describe the significance of Hawking's discussion of creation, C.J. Isham claims that we can identify the mathematical concept of any empty set with the absolute nothing in the traditional understanding of creation out of nothing: "The initial space from which the universe 'emerged' can be defined to be that part of the boundary of four-dimensional space which is not part of the (later) three-surface. But this is the empty set, which gives a precise mathematical definition of the concept of 'nothing'!"(36) “On the other hand, see Aquinas, 12. "Apparet quod illud spatium in quo stellae moventur, non potest esse vacuum, eo quod impossibile est esse vacuum in natura [...] Relinquitur ergo quod totum illud spatium in quo stellae videntur moveri, est plenum caelesti corpore, quod pertinet ad ipsam substantiam sphaerarum" (In ii De caelo et mundo, lect. 13, n. 3). Does Void Exist?: The Thomistic Rejection of its Presence in the Natural World. Mario Enrique Sacchihttps://maritain.nd.edu/jmc/ti98/sacc...p. 152. To summarize then: the observation that the universe is flat and that the local Newtonian gravitational energy is essentially zero today is strongly suggestive that our universe arose through a process like that of inflation, a process whereby the energy of empty space (nothing) gets converted into the energy of something, during a time when the universe is driven closer and closer to being essentially exactly flat on all observable scales.NOTE: And there is the conclusion, nothing becomes something. Why can’t he say that an energy field gets converted into matter by the mechanics of physical forces (strong, weak, gravity, electrical or whatever it is)?NOTE on pp. 172-173. Krauss comes back to the notion of First Cause and demolishes it. I suspect that he means by First Cause a self-created being. That is certainly not what is meant by Aquinas and probably not by Aristotle. Aristotle spoke of the Prime Mover and he did identify that Prime Mover as God, although many have said he was only talking about form or mind or nous. Cf. Aristotle’s Identification of the Prime Mover as God, Joseph G. Defilippo, The Classical Quarterly, New Series, Vol. 44, No. 2 (1994 p. 393 et seq. Certainly, Aquinas molded Aristotle. Cf. I, 7, 1. Is God unlimited? Aristotle tells us that in ancient times all philosophers considered the first principle to be unlimited, and reasonably so since they saw no limit to the things deriving from the first principle. But because they made a mistake about the nature of the first principle they made a corresponding mistake about its limitlessness. They thought of the first principle as matter, and hence assigned to it a material limitlessness, saying tht the first principle things was some limitless body.”

Actually, I'm only about 75% through this book, but I decided to review it now since Dr. Krauss (a guy I like) is delving into religion and philosophy... stuff that is apparently outside his expertise. He says that he has debated theologians and I'm sure he is good at it, but in this book he makes a few errors and slights-of-hand to make his argument easier. I assume he has only the best of intentions. (I mean that because like I said... I like him.)In the beginning of this book, Dr. Krauss explains how frustrating he finds debating religious people and members of school boards. He says this in almost a defensive manner. I see this sort of stance taken by people who feel besieged by others who take a different (and wrong) view. I sometimes experience this myself when I try to explain Judaism to Christians.I am impressed that Dr. Krauss was a friend of atheist Christopher Hitchens, now passed away. I respected Hitchens because I could trust him to always tell the truth even when it did not help his cause. I trust Penn Jillette the same way. I do not trust Richard Dawkins. Dr. Krauss seems to be somewhere closer to Hitchens than Dawkins. Krauss admits the faults in his arguments but does not call a lot of attention to them. That fact that he points them out at all is encouraging. The reader simply has to be alert and realize what he is saying. (That is what I mean by slights-of-hand.)The complaint that sent me running to the keyboard is that he misrepresented Occam's Razor... the general principle that suggests that the simplest or most elegant solution to a problem is probably the correct one. In his book Dr. Krauss says that Occam's Razor is always the correct one as if it was a law of nature. That is an error. Therefore he begins with a flawed premise. That doesn't suddenly make religion correct. It simple means he is not using the English language correctly... a flaw he admitted he might fall into before he even set out. It's an easy mistake to make. I don't fault him. I am warning the reader so that the reader doesn't make a mistake.Defining terms is a prerequisite to any debate. The fact that a religionist would ask him to define his terms is not proof that all religionists are idiots. Dr. Krauss simply has to reform his question into terms the religionist can understand or define his terms. Not walk away in a huff.I get the same schtick from engineers, lawyers or anyone who has a specialty. They try to dazzle me with... uh... lingo... with unfamiliar terms. It is not unusual, but it is also not proof of anything.The problem is that Dr. Krauss is not a religionist himself. Therefore he is unaware that much of what he is saying smacks of a religious argument using science... and an implied "Trust me. I'm an expert!" I'm sure he is an expert in physics. I trust him in that. But I don't trust him to tell me about my faith. In essence he is trying to convert me to atheism. Religionists know about conversion and they know an attempt when they see it. Apparently Dr. Krauss doesn't realize that is what he is attempting to do. That is probably why he gets so much push-back. He is clumsy at it.Stick with what you know, Dr. Krauss. You will win more acolytes that way.Over all... well at 75% into it... this is a really good book. I just wish he would feel more comfortable while doing it.Penn Jillette is an atheist who feels perfectly comfortable with religionists and does not require religionists to be wrong so that he can be right. I recommend reading his book: God, No! Signs You May Already Be an Atheist and Other Magical Tales. (Warning: It contains a lot of vulgar language, but when I've seen him debating Christians he leaves the potty mouth at home. Nevertheless, I encourage people to read the book. I would gladly invite him to my home as I would invite Dr. Krauss, but not Dr. Dawkins.) I'll update this review once I've finished the book.

Nothing is unstable .. that will pretty much be the essence I will recall from this book. It doesn't mean everything is stable, it means that whenever you have nothing, it will find a way to become something. While counter-intuitive this has a pleasantly reassuring appeal. The fact that the author credibly assures us this applies to the universe (where "stuff" has been demonstrated to pop-in and out of existence) doesn't seem that far-fetched vs more conventional life-experience. Whenever there's nothing going on..something always seems to pop up.In any case, given that either there is nothing and therefore nothing/no one can ask the question of why there is nothing/something or there is something and whatever it came from must always have come from something else..it's not that hard to accept that the whatever first something there was..it by this logic had to come out of nothing. Well, apparently it is actually hard for certain religions to accept that their deity, if it/he/she isn't a persona, may not even be "a first cause". Interesting how cosmologists who appear to be the mathematically smartest, financially most endowed individuals (electron colliders, space telescopes,..) find themselves mostly in debate with faithful, theologists and philosophers. When I refer to cosmologists as the smartest, it's because the experiments they conceive to measure the size and age of the universe (13.67 Billion years) are largely beyond my imagination and comprehension. My limited IQ stretches just enough to not get torn completely but it's hold on this part of the book is tenuous at most times. I was happy to learn that per such experiments late 1990s , our universe has now been unambiguously identified as being flat vs open or closed. At least a flat universe seems to be the easiest to understand of all universes.So this flat universe (which is not 2, and perhaps more than 3 dimensional) doesn't just exist, it expands. (Actually it's the expansion of nothing that created everything). The expansion part I was familiar with from popular Big Bang awareness. What I didn't before realize is that as a consequence of this expansion the evidence of the Big Bang (static on Tv's) will in a couple of Billion years be undetectable for us, similarly, we will not see all the galaxies beyond our own. We, therefore, appear to live in the limited time (limited being a relative term since it's still expressed in billions of years) when we can still detect our universe 's origin and demonstrate the expansion by seeing the red-shift of galaxies which move away from us. As the universe expands those galaxies will become so removed we won't see them at all. Likewise, as the universe expands the cosmic microwave background signature of the Big Bang will fade out of detection. Somehow and quite contrary to the author's intention, this suggests there might be a diety with a sense of humor after all. The author does go so far as to say that our universe might have the exact laws of nature it has because in any other universe we would be unable to survive to detect other laws. That opens up the gates to multi-verses and the TV series Quantum Leap.Everything was well brought, it only gets 3 stars from me because the author couldn't overcome my lack of intelligence on some of the techier parts. I trust he's right when he says it's proven there's more dark-mass than visible mass and that you gravitationally-lense to see further and that supernova's are standard candles but he benefits in this from my faith in him and his position is quite clearly that faith isn't enough !

Nothing¹ illuminates the unbridgeable² chasm between religion and science as brightly as does the subject of Nothing. The fundamental difference between religion and science won't be found in any particular disagreement of fact, but rather in their foundational epistemologies. Science is built upon empiricism, whereas religion rests on rationalism (and also on revelation and faith, but it’s the incompatibility of empiricism and rationalism that’s relevant here). Although Universe from Nothing is more about the physics of cosmogony than the philosophy, it’s that philosophical incompatibility that I’d like to discuss. In Universe, Professor Krauss explains that the empiricist’s answer to the question why is there something rather than nothing? is that an empty universe would be unstable and would spontaneously stabilize itself by becoming a universe of stuff. Energy and matter, and even space and time, emerge into existence on their own. Krauss argues further (and I think somewhat speculatively, and perhaps unnecessarily) that the laws of physics themselves would spontaneously bootstrap if the universe were devoid not only of energy/matter and spacetime, but even of the rules that permit the existence of that stuff in the first place.The theologian’s objection to Krauss’ conclusions is that no matter how deeply an empirical explanation might reach, we can always dig to a deeper rationalist layer. If the laws of physics come into existence spontaneously, mustn’t there be meta-laws to permit this? asks the theologian, and then meta-meta laws, and so on, ad infinitum. Theologians will insist that there must never be such an infinite regress (but why not? we don’t know that infinite regress isn’t a real thing), that the laws of physics must have an ultimate answer (but why? maybe the laws of physics have no deeper explanation but simply are), that we cannot accept that we just don’t have an ultimate answer (but why? maybe ultimate answers don’t exist, or exist incomprehensibly to us), and conclude that the answer to the question of existence must be God. (Having thus “proved” the existence of a generic, deistic God by rationalist means, they then switch methodologies to faith and revelation to “prove” that this generic God is, in convenient fact, the particular God that they believe will provide them eternal paradise. But those are conversations for another time.)Krauss dismisses these objection out of hand, on the grounds that questions of objective fact that can’t be answered empirically can’t be answered at all. The point to understand here is that he is perfectly justified in doing so. That this dismissal is justified is something that religious apologists seem never to understand. Which brings me to that fundamental incompatibility. The relationship between empiricism and rationalism can be likened to that between Elvis and the Beatles. As the philosopher Tarantino observed: 
“Beatles people can like Elvis, and Elvis people can like the Beatles, but nobody likes them both equally. Somewhere, you have to make a choice, and that choice tells you who you are.”
 And so it is with epistemology: you can like both rationalism and empiricism³ but you can only choose one to serve as your final arbiter of Truth, and that choice of methodology defines and informs your worldview. Loosely speaking, either physics trumps metaphysics, or metaphysics trumps physics; you can’t have it both ways simultaneously on one single topic. It’s certainly possible, however, to choose to apply empirical standards to one subject and rationalist standards to another, and this is precisely what anyone must do when (futilely) trying to prove that religion and science are compatible. In applying different standards to different realms (i.e. empiricism to scientific questions, rationalism to religious questions), one does not demonstrate that these subjects are compatible in any meaningful sense, but only that we’re capable of arbitrarily compartmentalizing our thinking. This may be a trivial sort of compatibility, but it’s not the philosophical accord that the theologians are after, and passing it off as such is, at best, intellectual dishonesty.Because of this divide, there’s nothing that Krauss (nor any other empiricist) could ever say on the subject of Nothing that could ever satisfy a rationalist. To the rationalist, the Nothing that science has come to understand through observation is not the True Nothing, the Metaphysical Nothing, because mere observation can never reveal ultimate truth about anything. To the rationalist, that which we can observe is merely the extant manifestation of all the potential realities that might have existed, and which are all just as real as that which happens to have actualized. The ultimate Truth of these potential worlds, and therefore of the real world, may only be attained by means of rationalist arguments. To the rationalist, the rejection of these ideas is "scientism" or "materialist bias." But if (if) those accusations have any meaning at all, that meaning can only exist within the rationalist's own worldview.So, how do we choose between empiricism and rationalism? In an interview with Diane Sawyer, Stephen Hawking remarked, “there is a fundamental difference between religion, which is based on authority, and science, which is based on observation and reason. Science will win because it works." Over the past five centuries or so, empiricism has worked in ways that rationalism, over the course of more than five millennia, has never had and likely never will. Within the worldview of the empiricist, the practical success of empiricism (i.e. technology along with the stunningly wide and deep body of knowledge obtained through science) makes it the undisputed winner. The trouble here is that the value we place on empiricism’s success is in itself axiomatic and therefore unprovable within the rationalist’s worldview. A rationalist can (and must, if he wants to remain a rationalist) axiomatically reject the valuation of practical success as a measure of the worthiness of a worldview. Ultimately, there can be no way, even in principle, to reach into someone else's worldview and convince them that their paradigm is wrong. Ironically, the critics of the so-called “new atheists” who accuse them of being ignorant of philosophy, are themselves missing the philosophical truth that within the worldview of science, theological arguments are by definition non-starters, regardless of how convincing they may be within their own sphere.For me, the debate between empiricism and rationalism (actually I'm veering more towards arguing against faith here; yes it's sloppy but so what?) is settled by the observation that science converges, whereas religion diverges. No matter their starting points, those whose last arbiter of Truth is reality always converge towards consensus. When empiricists hold mutually exclusive beliefs, they acknowledge that at least one, and perhaps all, of those beliefs must be incorrect; their shared reality eliminates the falsehoods to reveal those beliefs most likely to be true. By contrast, when two theologians make mutually contradictory claims, there is no way, even in principle, for them to determine which claim is correct. Each must convince themselves, based on nothing but their internal convictions and predilections, that they alone possess the true revelation and that all of the other theologians, who believe different things for exactly the same reasons, must be wrong.¹ Well, hardly anything.² Oh, yes it is. Get over it.³ It’s impossible to not like both; rationalism and empiricism are yin and yang. Empiricism couldn’t exist without axioms that are necessarily rationalist, yet rationalism couldn’t exist without experiential inspiration. No concept can ever be either purely a priori or purely a posteriori.

The highly reputable physicist, Lawrence M. Krauss, sets out to tell us that universe came into existence practically from nothing. In his attempt to explain their latest findings, he wants us to understand that nothing is not nothing, or, alternatively, nothing is something quite significant. The immediate ramification of this assertion is that we should not ascribe undue importance to a divine being, or a creator, something that Krauss painstakingly tries to explain with ruthless objectivity and surgical precision. Inevitably, some feathers are ruffled as well. Personally, I think his account of our universe is unceasingly fascinating, but his personal inferences seem unbearably flawed. Science equals atheism, and you have identify with 1 or 0 or you are dumb! He explicitly puts forward the assertion that theology has no function, but this argument also touches on the importance of all humanities. While it is fascinating that they overwhelm and enlighten us with their findings, they also scare the hell out of you, since there is nothing that counts for something except 0 or 1. Then its safe to say that in the next world war, which doesn't seem very unlikely, human beings will be torn to shreds due to some mathematical equations that will justify actions taken by the leaders. It is quite frightening to see that human beings forget that science is not an end, but a means to better the world and the human condition. Through a scientific line of enquiry, all things amount to and stem from one question, So What?. That is, in any endeavor, we have to first and foremost weigh up the practical outcomes, and subsequently, fall into a soul-crushing pattern of commodifying everything around us, and through this, well, what sort of consequences are more likely?! I guess utter disregard for human beings as ''beings'' and conceptualization of human beings as a means for a lofty ideology. In fact, both Lawrence, and his friend, Richard Dawkins, who has written a compelling afterword for his book, both, openly, and again, openly, encourage ridiculing anyone who holds a contrary view to their beliefs, not sympathetic engagement with the aim of a dialectic that will result in a better outcome, but utter sneer for others. We all tend to brood on the importance of literature and philosophy and related fields that address us as the subject matter mainly, and not universe, as an entity that we should be cut off from, well, it seems like no matter how much knowledge you glean, you are prone to holding prejudice against people from different walks of life, and that's why we should study humanities to know ourselves better, and enjoy poetry and painting for it's own sake, and beauty for it's majesty and things in and for themselves. I can't help but understand Kant better in these cases, what does it really mean to perceive each human being as an end, if one captures that in it's full spectrum, other seemingly important issues might be dissolved.And lastly, I was also wondering how the less privileged will be treated in the future, with this cast of mind, they should either identify with 0 or 1 to survive, even if they have a thick mind to grasp it, they should fake it. Overall, Krauss and Dawkins arguments are amazing, but equally perplexing, when considered broadly in the light of the consequences that they entail for our universe.

I'm not sure where I saw the recommendation to read this book, but I wish I hadn't.Mind you, this book was way above my pay grade, if you know what I mean, because it was written by a physicist and it's about cosmology. (The universe and all it entails fascinates me, but when you get into the scientific reasons why there is what there is in the universe and how it works, then I'm somewhat lost.)I had high hopes for this book when, within the first few chapters, the author wrote: "...stars don't explode [go supernova] that often, about once per hundred years per galaxy. But we are lucky that they do, because if they didn't, we wouldn't be here. One of the most poetic facts I know about the universe is that essentially every atom in your body was once inside a star that exploded. Moreover, the atoms in your left hand probably came from a different star than those in your right. We are all, literally, star children, and our bodies made of stardust" and "Go out some night into the woods or the desert where you can see stars and hold up your hand to the sky, making a tiny circle between your thumb and your forefinger about the size of a dime. Hold it up to a patch of the sky where there are no visible stars. In that dark patch, with a large enough telescope of the type we now have in service today, you could discern perhaps 100,000 galaxies, each containing billions of stars."The above two portions of the book so impressed me that I posted them on my Facebook page.But then, the egotistical author kept denigrating those who believe in creation by a higher power (he is a scientist and feels superior to those who believe unlike him and perhaps feels the need to convey to his fellow scientists his total disbelief in anything that has to do with God or a god-like entity). If he had mentioned once or twice his belief that there is no God and He/She is not responsible for anything in the universe, I may have been able to overlook it. But Krauss goes on and on about it, mentioning it, I think, in just about every chapter of the eleven chapter book and the epilogue.This I might have overlooked, too, but he actually--more than once--calls into question the intelligence of people who believe in creation by a higher entity even though, on page 139, he writes: "If we wish to draw philosophical questions about our own existence, our significance, and the significance of the universe itself, our conclusions should be based on empirical knowledge. A truly open mind means forcing our imaginations to conform to the evidence of reality, and not vice versa, whether or not we like the implications." He does not keep an open mind, but asks that others do. As for me, I believe in a combination of creation and science, and am willing to consider other opinions. The author believes his opinion is the only one. That just doesn't hack it for me.The author's ego so undermined what he was trying to put forth in this book that I would not recommend this book to anyone.

For anyone wanting to delve into advances in physics and cosmology since Hawking's excellent 'A Brief History of Time', this is a great place to start. While the prose is not quite as succinct as Hawking's, Krauss nonetheless introduces us to startling range of theories and experiments that have completely changed how we look at the universe around us. In this regard, it is an excellent book and I for one got a far better understanding of Dark Matter, Dark Energy and the behaviour of virtual particles than I had before.So why only two stars..?For one thing, the entire book is littered with derogatory comments concerning religion. Hawking argued that because we are bound by the laws that govern our universe, we are precluded from ever knowing what happened before the Big Bang. In this way, the door is left open for the possible existence of a God, however unlikely or unpalatable that might be to the individual concerned. Krauss on the other hand, absolutely hates the idea of there being a God and does his best to use the physics he introduces, as a means of disproving the existence of a creator or divine influence. Theologians and philosophers are treated as little more than dirt, which in my view, greatly diminishes not only the quality of the end product, but also Krauss' standing as a balanced and respectable scientific investigator. (I am scientifically trained but not religious, by the way.)And this brings me onto my second point. Krauss' central thesis is that our universe arose from absolutely nothing. However, despite presenting a wide range of scientific discoveries that support different aspects of this idea, at no point in the book does he articulate an overarching theory to justify his proposition. Instead, he relies on three separate arguments, none of which, in and of themseleves, really advance us beyond our current state of knowledge, i.e. that we simply don't know for sure what created the universe that we live in. Because of this, Krauss actually ends up as a parody of the very people he is lambasting, trying to persuade us that the universe arose from nothing, without energy or physical laws, without a shred of evidence that this was actually the case.So overall, I found the book disapointing. As an introduction to recent scientific advances and thinking it is sound, but sadly it is diminished by Krauss' repeated attacks on religion and the lack of any solid proof for his central argument. A sensational title indeed and one that certainly caught my eye, but sadly a sensational disappointment when you get right in between the covers.

I painfully did not give this book three stars. I tried hard to justify it, but I just couldn’t get there. I have a few reasons for this decision to give the book a worse rating. First, despite Krause’s attempt to make physics understandable, clear, and the scientific theories that support the Big Bang theory the basis of his argument he just misses the mark. His whole purpose in writing this book is to prove to people who don’t believe in science or the Big Bang the science and the Big Bang actually make a lot of sense. But instead of doing what people like Carl Sagan and Neil DeGrasse Tyson have so expertly done - make science more populist in its explanation and proliferation - he remains dedicated to an elitist approach by patting his own brighter back and stroking his pedantic professorships. Second, his obvious distaste for anyone not espousing his viewpoint or driven by any sort of religious motivation is palpable. No one ever convinced anyone else of anything by telling them they are stupid for thinking otherwise. Finally, Krause and Dawkins (who writes the afterward for him) both are guilty of deep intellectually dishonesty. They both clearly show how the observations of theorists and scientists of the past were flawed by helpful in bringing us to the conclusions that science has reached today. They are a bit judgmental of those of the past for thinking that they had somehow arrived at the definitive truth while through continued scientific rigor humanity progressed to the knowledge we have today. But both these men posit that today is the best time ever and forever to be a physicist! Based on what we know today, someday humanity will not be able to view the stars any longer as the universe expands and the light reaches distances far beyond our ability to see in its past. They make these claims somehow believing that what they know now is all we can know. That it would be impossible to know more. Foolish close minded smart people who think there are no more unknown unknowns. Isn’t that the purpose of science? To keeping looking and find out if there is anymore? What evidence exists that would lead us to believe that there is no more to know? Nothing in our past would suggest that there is never anything else to know. It possible the universe sprang from nothing. And there is much evidence that shows it may return to nothing... but until that time, are we really to believe that science has already proved that there is nothing more? Two stars.

Back in 2003, it was cool to rag on theists. You see, back then people were literally talking about a giant religious war between Christians and Muslims. People were talking about civilization-scale warfare. Any thinking person was like, "I think I remember a John Lennon song about that?" That's when Sam Harris, Richard Dawkins, Christopher Hitchens and Daniel Dennet wrote their classical New Atheism books. At the time they were necessary! The Bible Belt was screaming about religious terror, forgetting that they were still instigating terror at home."Oh, you want to destroy our buildings, rewrite our history, live off planet-poisoning oil and create a country based on the religious law from a time when everybody on the planet wore sandals? Well, we do everything better and bigger over here in Texas." Again, in 2003 it was probably a necessary reminder "HEY GOD ISN'T REAL GUYS".But by 2012 nobody was super concerned about that shit. We were concerned about whether or not healthcare was a right (it is) and if the government should force you to buy healthcare (it does). So why the fuck did Krauss spend 1/5th of his book ragging on theologians, philosophers and religious folk? I came to read about the "Origin of the Universe" as part of my "read a bunch of history books from Big Bang to Twitter" project, and instead I got a bunch of poorly executed anti-religious dunking. The scientific content of the book, when it is there, is pretty good: We discovered the universe was expanding, and then we discovered the Cosmic Background Radiation. We probed that and then found the Universe is as close to "flat" as it possibly can be (Pythagorean's Theorem works!) This is pretty special because it means the Universe won't collapse into itself, and when you pair it with quantum gravity you have a nice hypothesis for *why* it is flat: rapid inflation in space-time made what would otherwise be a curve into a flat line. Great theory!The book, however, doesn't answer its subtitle "Why there is Something Rather Than Nothing" and another 1/5 of the book is spent railing about how people keep changing the definition of "Nothing".They don't. Krauss is/was just drumming up controversy for this(/his next) book. 1/5 Anti-Theologizing.1/5 Anti-Philosophizing.3/5s Science.3/5 Stars.

The book is about what our understanding of modern cosmos is and how God relates to that. I cannot (or want to) dispute his scientific reasoning as I only have rudimentary knowledge around the issue and to think I could say anything based on that would be kidding myself. I liked the book. It was informative, comprehensive, funny at times, and had a clear purpose for argumentation. But there are two complaints.Firstly, this book was messy at times, and I was a bit surprised at how huge portion Richard Dawkins afterword took (hah, I combined two complaints into one.) But this didn't bother me or affect my reading. Secondly, I have always found it odd that religion(s) are simplified to the belief of God/gods. After getting my masters from Comparative Religion, I have thought of religion being more about group cohesion than anything else. Dogmatism and the rest don't really matter for the "common" believer. What they held dear to them are the traditions that combine them to their community. The little rituals that console them. And so on. Yes, the belief in one God who judge the believers and heathens is in the center of Judeo-Christian religions, but it is not the sole point. It is not the point of a wedding or funeral. The argument that disputing God's existence will make religions to cease is too farfetched for me. The rise of the New Age, self-help books, and spirituality (some combined with scientific belief and without God or gods) indicate that there is a need for meaning and belonging. And that is what religions are about for many who seek them. Also, the belief into God/gods are part of our brain structure and how we observe the world, see neuroscientific research done from religion or read Pascal Boyer's Religion Explained for starters. I'm not saying don't have an argument about God's existence or that this book is wrong (or blasphemy as that is far away from what I think,) but what I'm trying to say is that religions are much more than their God or gods.But to finish this review, this book wasn't about religion. It was about cosmos and existence of God and my second complaint is invalid and should be ignored. Krauss arguments against God are well made, but I don't see them as arguments against religion. Yet, what made me like this book was that finally someone knows how to form an argument!Thank you for reading!

Got this almost five years ago, now I can understand it. Basically there are three possible kinds of universes from the Big Bang: open, closed, and flat due to whether the total energy is positive negative or zero respectively. A zero energy flat universe can come from nothing, having a beginning and end in nothing rather than collapse on itself (closed) or expand forever (open). Remember with general relativity mass-energy bends space. You can measure the mass-energy of galaxies by their gravitational effects on the light we see. Well only 1% of the matter in the universe is visible matter we're familiar with. But even with matter and dark matter there isn't enough energy to account for the universe, only 30%. The rest is found in the vacuum of empty space, dark energy. The negative energy from gravity balances out the positive energy of matter so that the universe is flat. Zero energy. From this vacuum quantum particles appear out of nothing and vanish in an instant not violating conservation and add energy which is cancelled out by the negative energy of empty space. This is how ours and other universes could have come to be, spontaneously out of nothing. Krauss makes clear that we're not certain the universe is flat and from nothing but he makes a good case for it. The implications are pretty amazing. Nothing is something in physics, something comes from nothing, and nothing is unstable. The way Krauss uses nothing is not in the philosophical sense of absence of being but as empty space with nothing we can detect. With this definition creation ex nihilo is possible but does not require anything supernatural. It also means existence and nothingness are ultimately the same. There is literally no reason things exist versus not exist for the distinction is meaningless or is contingent by what we mean by a particular thing existing. Quite existential. Everything is contingent, even the laws and constants of physics, with no necessary existence with a causal chain terminating in a necessarily existing being. No physical need for a creator, though Krauss' conclusion is that this doesn't rule out God but makes the hypothesis unnecessary.

I picked up this book based on the title, and I have to say I was disappointed. I was interested in a purely out of logic’s sake, and not interested in a theist vs. atheist debate. Gratefully, he tells us upfront that he is not going to answer it and I suppose could have stopped right there. I had read a couple of biographies of Einstein and thought I might be up for the intellectual challenge of cosmology, but it didn’t take long before the explanations went over my head. He does say we don’t know what we don’t know, and that is a HUGE caveat. Other explanations include: there is no such thing as nothing, it only appears as nothing (if that didn’t sound familiar). Even if there is “nothing,” the laws of physics are still in effect and perhaps laws still unknown can cause something from nothing – gravity could pull a particle from an alternate universe and then it would appear that something came from nothing. (But still, the particle came from somewhere…) So, just very unsatisfactory. 	Also, self-righteousness is just as unattractive in atheists and it is in theists. Personally, I think you only belittle yourself when you attempt to belittle someone else. State your case as a scientist and let your reader come to his/her own conclusions. Anyway, that is my two cents. I’m glad I plowed through, I think I caught a glimpse of some of the higher science involved, but maybe some better editing might have made this book more readable. In the end, I was put in a Whitman frame of mind:When I heard the learn’d astronomer, When the proofs, the figures, were ranged in columns before me, When I was shown the charts and diagrams, to add, divide, and measure them, When I sitting heard the astronomer where he lectured with much applause in the lecture-room, How soon unaccountable I became tired and sick, Till rising and gliding out I wander’d off by myself, In the mystical moist night-air, and from time to time, Look’d up in perfect silence at the stars.

In general this was a good and interesting book. It's a very complex subject to give insight into and the author does a good job with that. Unfortunately I think much of this type of science requires the related math to be truly grasped - but that's not a fault of the book's so much as maybe the type of book. The thing that confuses me about this book is that it was written only partly to inform about science and partly as an anti-faith polemic. This is an odd addition to several books in this space (brief history of time, our mathematical universe, and others) where it seems like the drive to explain for the author is based in a sense of themselves as latter day Galileos. I am sure they run into faith based opposition and that these anti-intellectuals exist, but are they really reading these books?In the specifics of this book, as well as in the general case they all fight against the god of the gaps - which is a good thing to dissuade people from. However, having dispensed with this god they decide the case against all faith, which ignores revelation out of hand. It seems to me that it wouldn't matter if god sprang from the big bang if this entity managed to communicate with humankind - you would want to check that out. In this sense every one of these books leaves me feeling like the authors didn't do their homework on their secondary concern (or perhaps their primary driver for writing to layman scientists). Finally, the consistent refrain in god of gaps polemics is that people of faith are at ease with no science because they have an easy answer already in hand. The author then turns around to use the science of people of faith like Newton and Leibniz (and a large horde of others). Just a lazy and perhaps disingenuous claim which shows me their fundamental concern is not education but evangelism of their point of view, casting their entire work into a different light.

Okay, first I’m going to address the 2018 elephant in the room; these days, hearing Krauss lament the poor treatment of women in science sounds, to say the least, brutally hypocritical. I cringed hard every time he brought the issue up, and since he’s dealing with cosmology, he can’t help touching upon (ouch!) the likes of Henrietta Swann Leavitt or Vera Rubin. But let’s put all that aside for a moment and focus on the book.Well, the subtitle promises that we will find out “why there is something rather than nothing”, and SPOILERS AHOY from here on out, but I must say that Krauss fails on that front. The key problem is that, indeed, it is difficult to pin down and strictly define “nothing” as a tangible (heh) concept that could then be shown to produce a, well, something. I would not say that “quantum vacuum”, as he seems to insist during the initial chapters, qualifies, and although Krauss spends some time lamenting how the philosophers and theologians he discussed this issue with keep moving the goalposts whenever he tries to get a solid answer as to what “nothing” is, through the progression of later chapters even he acknowledges that a proper nothing would be an absence not only of matter and energy, and not even of spacetime itself, but an absence of even the rules – the physical laws – that govern this void. But just as he removes one element after another of reality to get to the chapter where he promises to show how being emerges from complete non-being, from the absence of any structured substrate or even rules, he suddenly resorts to wild multiversical hand-waving and deftly sidesteps the whole issue, rather rudely leaving the patient reader, who plodded through quite a bit of by now well-known pop-sci cosmology to get to these juicy bits, dangling, with nothing to show for the effort. On a more positive side, at least the book is short, so not a lot of time was wasted getting to this non-answer.

Witty and entertaining. Krauss dedicates large part of this book to explaining the evidence of the big bang and what we can say about the universe's future. Complex and counterintuitive concepts are presented in a clear way. The very last three chapters are about the soul of the book - that which gives the title to it - and I generally found it satisfying when not awe inspiring and jaw-dropping. The only let down is the last question that naturally comes in mind when one inquires such topics. If matter can emerge from space, an act of creation that is well masked by the Uncertainty Principle, and spacetime itself can emerge from the space-devoid nothingness, where do the physical rules that allow spontaneous creation (or, rather, the inherent instability of nothingness) come from? Or, to put it in a different perspective, is spacetime-devoid nothingness the true, fundamental "nothing"? The existence of physical rules in this nothingness is indeed "somenthing", nonetheless. Is thus this nothingness eternal and the physical rules as well? Krauss cannot answer these questions, which are well beyond our capabilities, and perhaps no one will ever be capable of collecting data and evidence to reply. For what matters, Krauss delivered part of the answer to the Origin. The multiverse hypothesis, he claims, can help reduce the importance of the physical rules origin question, but we cannot dismiss out of hand the contrary, i.e. that there is no multiverse and that, alas!, there should have been an origin for the physical rules as well.Inebitably, the author has to acknowledge that we do not have to answer yet. He insists upon one key aspect of the debate, though, and in this he has my full support: that to rely on the easy God of the gaps approach will tell us nothing for sure.All in all, it's a really interesting book, entertaining as Krauss's own debates and interview.

Counted among the best of contemporary science popularizers, Dr. Lawrence Krauss presents an edifying and eminently readable guide through the scientific theories of cosmogony, as well as the history of scientific research and discovery on the topic all to answer the question, “Is there truly such a thing as nothing?” An award-winning theoretical physicist and cosmologist, Krauss explains various theories and evidence including the Big Bang versus steady state theory, cosmic inflation, particle physics, string theory (of which he is not necessarily a proponent), dark energy, dark matter, cosmic microwave background radiation, the “cosmic jerk” effect on the accelerating universe, and much more. He also spends several pages pondering whether cosmologists and astronomers trillions of years from now will be able to ascertain the true origins of the universe once it has expanded to a point where so much physical evidence may no longer be available. I would be remiss if I didn’t mention that an underlying theme of Krauss’s book is the dismissal of theology and all Creation myths as possessing any factual basis for the origin of the universe—a point which Krauss touches on sporadically at various points. One aspect that I enjoy as much as the science is learning about the history of scientific theories and discovery.
