As the book unfolds, Krauss—like Carl Sagan, Neil deGrasse Tyson, Michio Kaku, and others—takes the time to offer brief anecdotes and background information on several of the notable physicists, mathematicians, astronomers, and cosmologists who have contributed to our knowledge of the universe over the past century.

I'm tempted to give a 5-star review simply to offset the unwarranted low reviews by people that either have little understanding of the scientific method, are greatly out of touch with the modern state of human knowledge, and/or pretend they're informed about the relevant physics when they're clearly either being insincere or not paying attention.Many of these reviews can be summarized as:[I did not like this book because it offended me. I already know the answers to these questions and questioning those answers makes me uncomfortable. Centuries of scientific progress from the sharpest and most diligent humans among us means less than my personal opinion. I do not know of or understand the rigor of the scientific method, so the logical conclusion is that these arrogant scientists have no rigor and are wildly speculating from a couch with no proof or basis.]It seems to me the most arrogant among us often tend to see arrogance where there's the least of it.I won't, though. It shall be an honest 4-stars. This book has great potential, is important, is incredibly interesting, and should be elaborated upon and enriched with any updated physics findings that come in the next decade or so.The book as it is now, I'm afraid, could use better copy editing and better explanatory frameworks.But, to keep it in perspective, this is the best we have so far in intertwining Cosmology with that deep age-old philosophical question (This is what it was written to be!), and Lawrence Krauss deserves much praise for it.

As if migraines haven’t beaten my brains enough I decided to throw the question of our very existence at them and see what shakes loose.I had to give this 5 stars based on the fact that I certainly couldn’t expect to retain a working knowledge of the concepts in this book. There was plenty that I was just barely holding on to, and some that I maybe just lied to myself about understanding. So how can I critique something I didn’t fully get? I’m just gonna throw 5 stars out there and put my trust in Lawrence Krauss.A lot of these “celebrity scientists” have said that they get annoyed with people’s bad arguments because people don’t know enough about science to know that they are wrong. I can safely say that after this read I am perfectly aware of where I stand in terms of challenging academia any time soon.Aaaaaand I just had to delete half this review because I started using 2 years of community college to argue an astrophysicist’s definition of “Nothing.”Grasping some of the concepts in these pages for a blue collar guy is like trying to wrap your head around infinity or the holy trinity or one of life’s many riddles.Despite the restlessness in my mind, this book did contain a lot of easily understandable information about the current state of knowledge we have about the universe. It just got a little complex in the last 50 or 60 pages. At any rate I feel it’s good to check in with science from time to time to see where we stand on figuring this whole thing out and Lawrence Krauss is definitely a great source for current science and theories.

Not at all bad. I was mostly interested in exploring the apparent paradox of why there is still matter when it should have been eliminated with its respective antimatter during initial inflation. (That's definitely the biggest gap in my knowledge in the "big bang to present" timeline.)I got a whole lot more than I bargained for! The book walked a very difficult tightrope, and did it well: it was simple enough for me to (marginally) understand complex theories that were totally foreign to me while not being SO dumbed down where I was rolling my eyes and thinking 'yeah, I know that already.'One issue that I had is that the meat of the book, while incredibly informative, is flanked by some moderately militant anti-theism. Part of me understands this; it's like running into someone with a cast. You see someone wearing a cast and you ask them "what happened" and the person gets disproportionately annoyed. That might be the first time you're asking that (or seeing her in a cast), but she's been dealing with this crap for weeks now! You're stepping into the middle of something that has a lot of emotional context to which you are not privy (and, to be fair, for which you are not responsible).That's what this feels like. Now, is this kind of defensiveness understandable? Absolutely. Is it a pleasure to read? Not especially.Overall, a fantastic read for those interested in cosmology and quantum physics.

I've heard this guy on YouTube videos give talks and I was a little leery of reading one of his books because sometimes he sounds abrasive. In a similar vein to Sir Richard Dawkins he's anti-religion. Heck, I'm pretty anti-religion myself, I can appreciate Dawkin's points about how much cruelty human to human, has been caused by these man-made belief systems - my problem with both him and Krauss (in lectures) is that they always seem to be singing to the choir. You can't win others to your side by mocking them, putting them down, and refusing to validate their feelings. You don't have to validate beliefs or thoughts - especially if said thoughts are erroneous, but you should try to validate feelings if you are trying to win people over. Otherwise all that happens is that they shut up in your presence and as soon as your back is turned they go back to whatever they were doing. (If you've ever parented a teenager you will know what I mean.) Whew, sorry for the long lead in - because what I mean to say is that I was So Pleasantly surprised by how good this book is. It is very readable for the average reader and did not feel weirdly too complex the way some Hawking books do. The language is at a high school level and very engaging. I imagine this guy as a professor is probably much kinder and encouraging than he sometimes comes off in his public lectures. This is a great book and very illuminating. Give yourself time to savor the implications.

Lawrence Krauss is certainly intelligent and well versed in the subject of theoretical physics and cosmology; however, he is not a good writer - this book, whatever it is, likely is much better inside Mr. Krauss's head - it didn't make it out as a whole piece - instead, it is an epic fail. How? Because instead of reading like a book of science about science, such as those we have from Dawkins or Sagan, it is instead a painstakingly obvious manifesto of atheism. What I would like to say is pick a topic - are you writing a book that is about science? Or are you writing a book about philosophy? I do not care which, just pick one. This book appears to be a book of science, and there is much science in it - but the underlying empty space is dominated by a mission to debunk faith. This may be acceptable in a debate, or a different forum, but, I did not select this book to bolster an argument; I selected it to read about theoretical physics and cosmology. What a tragic lost opportunity of a certain great mind to share his genius in the field of science, rather than hounding faithheads with his atheist pugnacity. Still, underneath that, there is a good dose of science and a treat - an afterword by Richard Dawkins which reads better than the book. That is simply because Dawkins is a stellar writer and summarizes Krauss in a way that is brilliant, simple, and concise without punching one in the head.

This book had real potential, but fell flat for a few reasons:#1) The author fell prey to one of the most classic audiobook blunders of all time--thinking he's a professional narrator. This guy may be a brilliant physicist and a regular lecturer, but I just called him "Mushmouth". Seriously, if you can't enunciate all 5 syllable is "cosmological", you have no business narrating a book where this term and others like it occur regularly#2) Like EVERY physicist who TRIES to make cosmology clear to the masses, he FAILS to clearly articulate the many different interpretations of "an expanding universe". That is, there's the movement of galaxies away from one another because they are moving in FIXED space, there is the expansion of space itself, which (like a balloon being inflated) will make things get further apart even if they have no actual motion, and there is the combination of these two factors. The author sucks completely at distinguishing between these, often implying he's discussing one when later it seems he's discussing the other.#3) His choice to repeatedly interject his personal vendetta against religion. I'd rather he let religion die it's own natural death than lecture from a soapboxIn general, the book was interesting, and helped clarify Dark Matter and Dark Energy, but not completely.

The author attempts to bring an explanation to how it all began! More formally, the author argues that modern quantum field theory is able to explain how the material world can come to a stable existence as we see it today. Moreover, the author further argues that even space time itself can come to existence from nothingness purely by QFT.The book's explanation of the physics might feel inadequate to many readers, which is understandable. QFT is a highly advanced field and explaining it in a brief book is not possible IMO, so this is not the author's fault. In fact, the book is still able to convey the basic ideas.However, my more important criticism is how Krauss seem to ignore, and he might be unaware of, some important philosophical questions that should be discussed before the question of whether QFT can bring the universe into existence. Our modern knowledge of physics come from observing the patterns in the universe, theories like QFT are models that attempt to predict these patterns. It is not known why the universe obeys this particular QFT model and not some other, for instance, older disproven models. It is not clear, therefore, what it means to have the laws of QFT without having a universe at all! Are these laws eternal and all-powerful like a god? The book's conclusions are contingent on how we approach these questions.

I'd like to preface this review by stating that I'm a complete novice with regards to physics. Aside from basic schooling in general principles and the odd, terrible-CGI documentary, I began this book with no knowledge and an open-mind and I hope my review is helpful for those in a similar position. Krauss presents a very methodical and clear argument with substantial evidence (as one would expect) to endorse his claims. For the reader from a very limited physics background, such as myself, it was challenging to grasp a lot of the content as the book progressed. A solid understanding of classical physics is implicitly required for a full understanding of the argument and Krauss wastes no time explaining them. While I also understand his need for including the theological perspective of creation, I felt it was sometimes haphazardly shoe-horned in and superfluous to the point he was making. Despite this, the findings and arguments presented by Krauss are exciting and just because they aren't understood after a first read-through by a layman doesn't nullify them or mean they aren't elegant and compelling. I would recommend the book but ensure you have done the subsequent research on classical physics and give it a few passes if you're anywhere as clueless as I was when first addressing the subject.

A Universe from Nothing by Lawrence M. Krauss attempts to explain the latest thoughts on “Why there is something rather than nothing” in our universe. Dr Krauss Ph.D. is a theoretical physicist and writes a comprehensible book on the subject. He has an easy style and is able to explain complex subjects without completely burying the reader. He provides a nice background of our discoveries that have led us to this point so far in our understanding of the universe and ties it into the latest understandings to explain how the nothingness of “space” is thought to be unstable and that it is expected that energy and matter would explode onto this blank stage. That it is a process that most likely could occur and doesn’t require a creator to initiate. He admits, there is no proof to what he writes here nor a way to test it at this time, but in looking at what exists in our universe and the laws of physics, he creates a nice foundation to this explanation. He is giving us an overview without the detailed math that would come with an actual discovery or proof. While the future may turn out different, what he does give us here is a possible understanding to the basic processes and principles that could create universes as something expected. Not a miracle, but rather the result of natural processes.

I’ll start with the positive. I enjoyed the survey of thought over the years is cosmology and physics. This is a mostly a rehash of the work of others which you could find in many other books, but it was well laid out and pleasant to read.My problem with the book is the title and assumed premise of the book itself. The title would suggest that Krauss was going to tell us how, or at least in theory how, our universe could come to exist out of nothing. Instead he ends up redefining “nothing” in such a way as to suite his purposes. At several places in the book he talks about matter particles popping in and out of nothing. Anyone with a fairly basic knowledge of physics, chemistry, and cosmology will clue in quite quickly to what this nothing actually is. These particles are simply converting back and forth from a state of matter to energy in an electrical field. It’s common knowledge that matter and energy can change forms in certain circumstances. Krauss’ nothing still requires preexisting laws and in addition to empty space that already contains energy. The whole exercise seems to an elaborate illusion to fool those not well versed in the science or to confirm those people with a priori commitments to materialism.

I am a very religious person, and have oft wondered how anyone could be an Atheist, or as the title of this book puts it, believe in something from nothing. I did not realize this was the point of the book when I began reading it. This book, although full of scientific intrigue, is more of a philosophical one full of scientific backing to support an Atheistic theology.The beginning of the book was not as enjoyable to listen to because of this and I thought about quitting it halfway through. I quickly decided to see it to the end though realizing this person has every right to preach to me as I have undoubtedly felt a right, even an obligation to preach to others about my own convictions regarding the creation of the cosmos.With this renewed approach, I finished and thoroughly enjoyed the authors explanation of his atheistic ideology on the basis of the science that he deals with on the daily. Although not convincing in any way to shed any doubt on the faith I hold in a Creator, it did help me understand the point of view of the other side of the coin. It proved a healthy and respectful debate that religious folks and non-religious folks can and should be having.

The book was interesting, but the author is smug. I found the guy to be generally annoying. And everything was an attack on religious belief. It gets old after a while. I also think he landed flat in answering why or how there is something rather than nothing. And how the universe could have been created from "nothing." He claims that the universe probably came from quantum fluctuations, which isn't "nothing."I enjoyed the part about how we discovered the universe was expanding by measuring the red shift of various stars / galaxies at various distances. The farther away the star is, the more red shifted it is (the faster it is moving). It was interesting to think about how in the distant future the universe will have expanded so much that eventually space itself will be expanding faster than the speed of light (which is allowed, just objects cannot travel faster than light THROUGH space), and therefore if people are still around there will not be much to see in the sky. So, we live in a very unique time where we can observe the universe and gather enough data to conclude the universe had a beginning, etc.

I appreciate Krauss' writing style - he is easily comprehensible and his pace is fast but he doesn't gloss over important ideas. However, I can't help but think of this as a tract - a scientific and eminently reasonable tract for the non-existence of God. While I don't agree with the basic premise - that there can be something from nothing - no prime mover, I do have praise for this book. As a tract, the author is thoroughly convinced in his idealogy, as he should be. Science is his filter through which he comprehends the world. But he doesn't seem to think that there might be other filters, lenses if you will, through which we can view reality. Religion - God, either through organized ways or through mystical ways - can exist alongside science. If you think about God, you might wonder, where did he come from? Oh, he's always been there? Okay, then - did he come from nothing? If so, then the title of this book and the ideas that are presented are perfect - except that instead of the Universe coming from nothing - perhaps God did? I give this four stars because it Krauss is one of the great minds of our time and I think he is a dreamer, whether he believes it or not.

I am giving this 3 stars, mostly based on the fact that I totally enjoy the subject matter and I did learn quite a few new scientific concepts in regards to origins of our universe, as well as some particle physics and quantum theories are touched as well. The historical information about Einstein, Schrodinger and others was also interesting.However, I felt the book fell flat in terms of the main theme of it. A lot of science (heady science stuff) is not necessarily presented in an every day Joe type of format. I am a fan of popular science books as well as TV shows that touch on the universe and it's origins. That being said, a lot of the information explained in the book seemed at times like an info dump, while pertinent to the subject, it came off like cheerleading almost. Coming it at under 200 pages, I felt that there was unneeded information presented which made me realize that I am not a scholar in these particular scientific disciplines.I did really like the snippets of humour Krauss dropped throughout the book, and also the calling of religion and educational systems which seemingly exist to attempt to discredit science.

My knowledge of physics is not that great and even that is stretching it but reading this book was worth all the struggle in my attempts to understand what the author was trying to state and if I- a novice could find it within my grasp, then I'd say he was a success in explaining how universe could arise out of "nothing". What I loved most about the book was the unbiased tone of Lawrence throughout the book, nowhere did he impose his theories rather even refuted them as a true scientist. This book made me realize why I love science so much. It doesn't impose, doesn't demand acceptance rather prevails after numerous refutations.To quote Lawrence Kraus, "If we wish to draw philosophical conclusions about our own existence, oursignificance, and the significance of the universe itself, our conclusions should be based on empirical knowledge. A truly open mind means forcing our imaginations to conform to the evidence of reality, and not vice versa, whether or not we like the implications."

Quite an interesting book if you are interested in the fabric of reality and origins of the universe. The book only partially answers the question of why there is something by explaining how matter expands and disappears out of existence spontaneously. What is proposed is that 'nothing' is actually dark energy made up of 'virtual' particles. So although the account is fascinating scientifically, we are still left from everything (Big Bang) arising from dark energy, which is a proposed idea of something we cannot measure or detect. The biggest take away from the book though, is that something will always be produced from 'nothing' because 'nothingness' is inherently unstable.I recommend this book to anyone interested in the subject matter, but it may leave some readers behind as the subject matter can get on the technical side, and it helps to have a baseline level of knowledge of physics and cosmology.

Disclaimer: I have not read this book yet: as such, I have given it a 3 star review as an average- this will be adjusted once I have read the book. Now, normally I don't do this- writing reviews for books not read is a bad habit. After all, how can you fairly review and engage with a book you haven't read? So, let's call this a presumptive analysis or a title review. Now, science is incredibly important and useful in investigating the natural world. There are a plethora of questions that science is well suited to address and useful to help us understand more about reality- these are empirical questions and are of great import. However, there are questions simply outside of the scope of science- questions of (non-qualitative) value, meaning, purpose, and other related topics address things outside the domain of natural science. Being qua being falls into this category- *how* the universe began can (at least in theory) be empirically solved; but, *why* there is something rather than nothing is a question of ontology that is outside of the empirical realm.Edited for clarification

While I found the majority of this book quite fascinating, I felt like the last 50 or so pages were unnecessary. Perhaps this is because the last two books I read had covered these topics in greater detail, leaving me to feel as if Krauss was wondering too far from his own book topic. Otherwise, I felt like this book was really thorough, stuck to the topic at hand, and easy to understand. It can be quite mind boggling to think about where our universe came from, where it’s going, and that 99% of our universe is invisible to us. “As we expand our understanding, we will next see that inflation can represent simply the tip of a cosmic iceberg of nothingness.” Krauss makes a point in his book to explain that the time to better understand our universe is now as it will eventually be too late to do so. It’s quite sad how little the world has invested in our government run space programs, but thankfully people like Elon Musk exist.

In his Afterword for this book, which was originally going to be written by Christopher Hitchens before his health deteriorated, Richard Dawkins writes, "If 'On the Origin of Species' was biology's deadliest blow to supernaturalism, we may come to see 'A Universe from Nothing' as the equivalent from cosmology."It is a high compliment, but one I couldn't disagree with. Krauss' style is dense of course, and this took seven months to read - using both my physical copy and the audiobook from the library. Many paragraphs need to be read over several times, and I am no scientist or mathematician, much less a cosmologist. Still, the concepts are made very accessible with concentration, and I know now things I didn't before - like that we've measured how far we can see into the depths of space with a balloon in Antarctica, and how light "bounces" off of black holes, and how bubbles of unstable stuff can pop out of nothing for infinitesimal fractions of a second. It was well worth the read!

I don't mind anti-theism books. I don't mind anti-theism books that use scientific evidence against supernatural claims. I do mind science books whose authors feel they need to answer supernatural or any other non scientific arguments against their claims. This is one of such books.I don't get it. I really don't. As much as I want to, I don't and I don't think I'll ever will. Either write an anti-theism book or a science book. Having one with bits of another is confusing and unnecessary. The afterword of Richard Dawkins made it all even more confusing. The afterword really felt like one for an anti-theism book. But the bulk of the book really isn't.From a scientific point of view, I did enjoy the book although it is complex for someone with my (low) level of knowledge on the subject. I wonder how much more I would appreciate it if the time and effort put on religion was used to make it more approachable for the physics layman.

I think it would be helpful to put in the synopsis of the book that it is anti-religion and also that it may require some background knowledge of physics (above popular-science level reader). That said chapter 8 'A Grand Accident' really did make me think.....the idea of multiverses and how they could occur by creation of pockets in space. The underlying theme is that space is filled with a mysterious dark energy and it propels inflation of the universe at ever increasing speeds. I also liked the idea of virtual multiverses existing in different dimensions. It is not a bad book, just a difficult book, both in writing style and grasping the concepts. I did have to re-read paragraphs a few times! I think if it had not kept bringing up religion being superfluous to the universe I think it may have gained 3 stars but by continuing mentioning it, all it did was detract from the book (for me anyway).

The intuition that nothing can never lead to something is wrong. A layperson still need an act of faith to believe this statement but I admit this book provides evidence for it."we are all literally star children and our bodies made of stardust"."one thing is certain, however. The metaphysical rule that out of nothing nothing comes has no foundation in science"."nirvana is nothingness.""a universe without purpose or guidance may seem to some to make life itself meaningless. For others like me such a universe is invigorating. It makes the fact of our existence even more amazing, it motivates us to draw meaning from our actions and to make the most out of our brief existence in the sun, simply because we are here, blessed with consciousness and with the opportunity to do so. "" without science everything is a miracle. With science, there remains the possibility that nothing is. Religious belief in this case becomes less and less necessary, and also less and less relevant. "

I think this is one book which might have been easier to understand if it had more math in it. The concepts it covers are often counterintuitive, and although Krauss does his best to explain, his explanations are not always easy to follow. It doesn't help that the book lacks notes, references, and suggested further reading. The material does stretch the mind, and I came away convinced that a universe from nothing is possible for certain values of nothing, but no answer is suggested for ultimate origins except an eternal multiverse. Anyone looking for certainty will be disappointed; Krauss is quite clear that much is yet unknown and that much of what he suggests are plausibilities, not facts (which I, for one, appreciate). Many religious people will be displeased, too. His point that God fails as an explanation needs to be said, but he repeats it often enough to convey hostility to religion.

This is one of the best science books I've read for ages.The author is a well known and lauded cosmologist, whose work has explored the more difficult aspects of the Big Bang: How did it happen? How could it have happened? Is our universe the only one? Later on he does ask why our universe might have been created, but he points out that such a question may be meaningless. Above all, his goal is to show how the universe could have appeared from nothing, and how that means a creator is unnecessary.Written with skill, clarity and economy, this is a superb outline of the state of play in cosmology circa 2012. It simplifies theories without sacrificing their essence or importance - a rare skill in science writing - and while it doesn't give all the answers, it does elegantly and clearly give reasons why such answers may be impossible for us to know. Highly recommended.

This was a somewhat challenging read for me as I am not a physicist (though I loved physics in high school and graduated with an electrical engineering degree). I think the book would be more accessible if it had more pictures/images to enhance some of the ideas talked about. The images that were included really helped me grasp some of the concepts. I got somewhat lost in the physics lingo in certain sections and a few more images would have helped I think.In the end, an enjoyable read that explains how far we have got so far in explaining the origins and properties of the Universe. I wish I could give this to certain friends who always argue for God as the cause/creator of everything and question why I do not believe in God, but I think it is a little over their heads (as it was a challenge even for myself).

Tough read; mind-numbing numerals and equations aren't my strong suit. But what esoteric literature doesn't lose the attention of laypeople. Had quite intriguing propositions layered in corollary after corollary - I recently discovered that word and not sure if I used it correctly. I can still affirmatively state that I had some personal growth spurred at the cause of this.. this.. theoretical outline based on branches of mathematics that are beyond my comprehension, no matter how many degrees removed that pertinent growth is to my applicable life.For me, although it might seem like a stretch for others to empathize, I found Krauss's discussion on existence, space, energy, and states of non-being to find relavance in my professional life as a soccer coach and in my journey as a spiritual being.

WowI gotta admit I lost this guy about halfway through Chapter 2, but this was a page turner. I read all of it almost in one day just for the entertainment value of trying to keep up with the science.One of the biggest takeaways is from the last chapter:It’s important to recognize whether you’re asking “How?” Or “Why?”The domain of science is to try to develop theories of how things work. Those theories might be replaced with better theories and explanations, but the goal is to understand via testable data more about the universe: what is in it, how it fits together.This book really made me think about what I ask from God, and how to understand God in relationship to what we can know from science. How do we know things? What constitutes as “proof?” for God, or things in the world?

Eye opening and provocativeThe story of the brilliant experiments, the endurance of theoretical physicists, and the amazing results of their works will take you to a beautiful journey to find the origin of this universe. The theories put forward, explained comprehensibly for a layman like me, will occupy the mind and show you new possibilities in our universe, that can be discovered in a matter of decades.I'll recommend this for people who are looking for the latest views of modern physics on the origin of the universe, especially those looking for an alternative to the narrative that an almighty omnipotent creator out in the skies created the universe for us a while ago!

Interesting facts and theories explained by the amazing Lawrence Krauss. This book was the perfect mixture of information, explanation, and theoretical science. Loved it so much I listened to it 3 times!The book is narrated by Lawrence himself in the Audible Audiobook which makes it that much more interesting to listen to. You can really hear the excitement and passion he feels about the things he talks about.Also the explanation of "nothing" is the best part of the book. I've tried to explain this to other people so many times and I can never get it right. Buy this book just to read/listen to the science behind "nothing." That in itself makes the book worth whatever you buy it for, and then some.

My rating of this book is totally not fair, I'll admit. I should have read it in paper form rather than listened to the audiobook. I just couldn't follow it. I think I needed the time and quiet to be able to read at my own pace and really pay attention to the details, which I just couldn't do while driving. After about an hour, I considered quitting, but the book was only around 5 hours total so I felt like I'd already completed so much of the book. By about halfway through I felt I should have quit, but that obsessive drive to not leave books unfinished got the better of me. So I finished. I just really didn't absorb much.That said, I appreciate what he was trying to get at and am glad to know someone out there is thinking of this stuff!

Now my knowledge of physical cosmology is only eight years out of date.This was a fascinating book, although at times it was beyond me, as I am not well versed in cosmology. Krauss attempts to answer the question of how something arose from nothing, and is able to do so because of advances in the field over the last decades (some of which he is responsible for). We now know that something (dark energy) is constantly being created in the "nothing" that is space, and almost immediately ceases to exist. This book, and the science behind it, show that the typical person's understanding of "nothing" is limited and incorrect, and the creation of our universe from "nothing" is not inexplicable.

A crash course in theoretical physics with a sprinkling of sarcasm, A Universe from Nothing provided a stimulating, albeit occasionally overwhelming, listen. I chose the audiobook version - a five hour commitment - as opposed to the written text. I’m not sure I could have managed to get through the written version as it was often a bit too heady for my more poetic leanings. But it was well worth the listen, and to be fair, the difficult concepts were well explained for the open minded layperson. I came away from it with something, not nothing, and that is something! - a better appreciation of the scientific mind and a reminder of the infinitesimally wee spot I occupy in the grander scheme of things. Humbling, enlightening and tiring!

In the question "Why There Is Something Rather Than Nothing" that Lawrence Krauss addresses, his idea of "nothing" never seems to be the perfect "nothingness" but rather still "something" as in his "nothing" he still assumes the existence of laws of nature or the fact that the Universe may have some temporary existence (i.e. the picture in which the Universe comes from "nothing" and after some time ends up again in "nothing"), things which in themselves are something. The Physics content and arguments for why Science is the best tool to describe our Universe is still worth reading though. He makes a good point in rephrasing the question as "How There Is Something Rather Than Nothing" because this is the question that is actually addressed in the book.

An interesting read about fundamental physics and the processes by which something can arise out of nothing. This is within a universe that already exists though. It doesn't go back further to investigate how the nothing was there in the first place.I have knocked two stars off as the author often flexes his own work and tells you how he predicted something before anyone, but in a false modest way. He also criticises other scientists in a passive-aggressive way. It's not very professional, I've never known a science book previously where the author's bitterness shows through the writing. Also the afterword by Richard Dawkins is pointless and a bit cringey. He summarises the book you've just read, interspersed with praising the author.

'A Universe From Nothing' is a short read for two reasons: that the author is such a talented expositor of science he requires little space in which to effectively communicate challenging physics concepts; that the author is such a terrible philosopher he requires little space in which to perform naive generalisations whose metaphysical breadth far exceeds their worth. Thus, this book is not just short, it is also wonderful and woeful.Krauss' writing is so energetic, enthusiastic and earnest, particularly during the early chapters in which the breathtaking developments of cosmological understanding are presented in historical context, that his failure to resist the desire to dislocate and wrench the overarching narrative into congruence with his prejudices is a tragedy. Consequently, a wonderful picture is needlessly fractured by polemic. It is as if the driver of a tour bus pulls over at regular intervals, interrupting the flow of the idyllic landscape across the window, to remind us what he thinks of the Prime Minister. Where in the book the models and their evidence, some of which Krauss was personally involved with, are presented with impartiality, is where he shines.Eventually our tour approaches the present day, the province over which the cutting edge will always preside. Cutting edges are fraught with doubt, dispute, weird data and popularised conjecture. Insufficient notice is offered to the reader where the physics becomes contentious and/or speculative, such that the seamless narrative move from accepted cosmological orthodoxy into intellectually premature conceptions of cosmogenesis is misleading in its assumed authority. For instance, where chaotic inflation, a model whereby quantum fluctuations drive regions of the Universe to exit inflation at different times and decay into one of a number of possible causally-disconnected low-energy quantum states, is really one of a number of speculative eternal inflation models currently lacking substantiation beyond their mathematical or philosophical convenience.Sometimes it can appear as though a multiverse, as an assumed physical correlate to the extra-dimensional string landscape, or as assumed 'bubbles' causally disconnected by the exponential metric expansion of space in eternal inflation models, is posited merely to justify a probabilistic interpretation of the anthropic principle, thus circumventing the question of life-enabling 'fine-tuning'. Krauss struggles to convince that multiverse models entail scientific validity...because they don't, yet: a state of mathematical and sociological affairs Lee Smolin has been careful to chart in detail in his work. Ultimately science is not about what model might be optimal to refute theistic conceptions of reality (ironic that Krauss himself reminds us of and later reiterates the immortal principle regarding our worldviews conforming to nature and not the other way around), but what can be inferred is the case from evidence retrieved by experiment and observation. In his eagerness to score points against believers, Krauss has lost sight of the role of science in the quest for truth.It would be inattentive of me not to comment on the popular complaint regarding 'A Universe From Nothing'. The book makes an extraordinary claim to its contents on which it unsurprisingly fails to deliver. In summary: a model whose dynamical laws account for a change in state from relativistic quantum fields (or more fundamental precursors derived through quantum gravity) not arranged in accordance with our understanding of matter, to relativistic quantum fields arranged in accordance with our understanding of matter - or significantly more speculatively from something that isn't space to something that is - falls short of qualifying the book's tagline and marketing hyperbole. Despite Krauss' protestations to the contrary, his version of 'something from nothing', just isn't. Fundamentally, absolutely, and unequivocally, his theoretical prestidigitation constitutes merely a state change, a reconfiguration, albeit an especially interesting, counter-intuitive one, between states which once would have been regarded as ontologically incompatible before we knew our Universe better. That in his eagerness for his book to be the last word on cosmological creation he has exaggerated its metaphysical reach, diminishes what would otherwise have been a revelatory crescendo to the story of physics so far.Here is an example of Krauss-style philosophising in action:"[...]if potential to exist were the same as existence, then I am certain that by now masturbation would be as hot button a legal issue as abortion now is."Aside from the terminological ambiguity underpinning the assertion, it is curious that a physicist did not immediately catch the obvious natural analogy: the ontological equivalence, in mathematical terms, of potential versus kinetic energy, as we've learned from Einstein.It's not all this bad. He makes some decent enough criticisms of naive theological convictions, but such worldviews are rather an easy target and we've heard their refutations many times before.Eventually I suspect the interest in this book from physics-curious laypeople will be irreversibly outweighed by interest from academic historians studying the anti-theist vs theist social paradigm of the early 21st Century. Because the historical overview is so well communicated, engrossing and accessible, the book deserves at least three stars. Consider the missing two a caveat to the above criticisms.

This book suffers mainly from the author assuming the audience is going to be totally familiar with the complicated concepts, and thus his explanations are not broken down nearly enough for the common man to grasp. Also, considering the book is called "A Universe From Nothing: Why There is Something Rather Than Nothing" it doesn't really answer its question, nor does it spend much time on the question of what was there BEFORE the Big Bang, and how the Big Bang came into existence. That was my understanding of what the book was going to be about, and my whole reason for purchasing it. So I could have done without the history of cosmology and theorizing about its future.

I read it for fun, so a decent amount of it went over my head even though I read a few parts multiple times. Some of the concepts were pretty tough to grasp. But still it was an enjoyable read for a non physics major who likes physics. Not as layman friendly as Brian Green or Hawking or most of the pop culture physics books I read. The history of physics and the progression of theories was really interesting. Parts of the book were anti God/religion which I don't mind personally, but I think it prevents religious readers from giving the science a chance and possibly expand their understanding of the world.

I like Lawrence Krauss because he can really explain complicated topics in an easy to understand way. In this book, his goal is to explain the best ideas currently describing how the big bang might have happened--how it decided to "bang." I will say that "Nothing" in his title does probably not mean the "nothing" that you might be thinking of right now. He admits that there is, and always must have been, something. But that that something might be much more fundamental than even space and time itself. Regardless, the title does actually make sense when put in the context of his book. So, read it if you want to know how nothing is actually something.

This is up to date cosmological physics of a detailed nature. The author addresses what is known today of the subject discussed at a level such that if you didn't take several modern physics courses in college it would be way beyond you.He then addresses the big question of where did our universe come from and puts forth his hypothesis which is nowhere near the level of what can be called a theory. He says his hypothesis is "plausible."Frankly I have to stretch to give this book 3 stars because I hoping for something much more likely than just "plausible." Especially when you consider that the subject is one which will never have any practical concern to our species.

“The amazing thing is that every atom in your body came from a star that exploded. And, the atoms in your left hand probably came from a different star than your right hand. It really is the most poetic thing I know about physics: You are all stardust. You couldn’t be here if stars hadn’t exploded, because the elements - the carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, iron, all the things that matter for evolution - weren’t created at the beginning of time. They were created in the nuclear furnaces of stars, and the only way they could get into your body is if those stars were kind enough to explode. So, forget Jesus. The stars died so that you could be here today.”

I'm grateful to this book, mostly for its purpose as a scientific and religious challenge, encouraging me to explore the shallower end of the cosmology pool. The conclusion by Dawkins was very relatable to my experience of this book: I'm sure I didn't understand some of it, but I do understand that humanity's previous concept of "nothing" is scientifically outdated. "Empty space" is teeming with phenomena and is very far from nothing. As to the necessity of a prime mover, Krauss explains that cosmologists find "nothing to be a very unstable state" that wants to turn into something, maybe like our universe. Mostly a book on science, with some religious critique.

More of a 3 1/2 Stars as I was expecting it to be a bit more accessible than it ultimately was. That being said, I was surprised that I was able to follow as much of it as I was, and for a general population (such as I am), it is a fascinating look into the depths of cosmology that the average person so rarely cares to think about. The sheer provocative nature of the theories presented here and their merit I'm sure are lost on me, and yet I still walked away with a fundamentally new view of the nature of the universe. Hear more: https://soundcloud.com/geo-flores-709...

Short review: Especially the first half of the book is fascinating. It covers the history of cosmology, the most important theories in physics and builds towards an explanation of 'something from nothing'. The second half of the book was less interesting to me. Having already answered the question from the book's title, Krauss writes about debating creationists about the origin of the universe. While I believe that's important, I'm more interested in the mathematics and physics behind scientific theories than the logical fallacies of religious reasoning. I found myself struggling through the last parts of this book, after having thoroughly enjoyed the first part. 3.5 stars.

This book doesn't solve once and for all the matter of why there is something rather than nothing (and no one reasonable enough should have expected otherwise). Nonetheless, it gives a pretty comprehensive review of the physical phenomena that underlie the process of generating something starting from nothing, which is not really true nothingness, as the author itself mentions, considering it somewhat had the potential to become something in the first place.After reading these writings all I can [ignorantly] hold to is the anthropic principle, which states that there is something simply because if nothing existed no one would be there to question it to start with.

This book is not for the lay person. I read Krauss's book 'The Physics of Star Trek' years ago and found it very user friendly and easy to follow. This book is for students of astrophysics. One idea I did glean from listening to the entire book: We live in the infancy of the universe. We can measure the age of the universe at approximately 14 billion years. Because the universe is expanding, we will lose the ability to make measurements because everything outside of our solar system will have moved away from us and the distance will be insurmountable. Our descendants will be alone in a dark universe. Isn't that cheery?

I've listened to LK via podcasts and Youtube videos, so I had a head start understanding this book. He did a great job explaining these physics concepts -- but yeah, they're hard to grapple with. It'll take a few times to read it over to fully understand it. There was a part of the book that annoyed me, though... the whole religion-sucks-and-science-is-better. I'm basically agnostic, but I also believe that faith/religion plays a role in human society. We need something to fill in the void of the "unknowable." Science and religion don't have to be against each other; they can find ways to play nice.

What can i say about this book, it is simply amazing.Lawrence Krauss manages to take subjects such as inflation (of the universe, not money), quantum mechanics, the big bang, particles appearing and disappearing from nothing and present it in a readable format that the layman can digest.I have learned so much from this book i cannot wait to jump onto the next one, The Greatest Story Ever Told (so far). Excellent references, excellent examples and excellent explanations make this book one of the best physics references there is.If you're interested in where we actually come from, and why, then this is definitely what you're looking for. Read it!

Dr. Krauss has written an astonishing book on cosmology and astrophysics. He makes the abstract and abstruse somewhat simple and crystal clear. He covers the Big Bang Theory, which is something more than a scientific theory, since observable afterglow can be observed in the universe that establishes it. Nothingness is discussed at length, and how something came from it. Einstein's contributions to the field are covered, so are thinkers such as Planck, Feynman and Hawkins. Dr. Richard Dawkins, the noted atheist, follows up with an essay at the end. Recommended for anyone interested in astronomy, physics or space exploration. Or for that matter just science or philosophy.

I listened to this as an audiobook and I'm glad I did, or I probably wouldn't have been able to finish the book. I do not have a physics, quantum physics or cosmology background so, a good bit of what the author wrote was beyond my grasp. I do have a keen interest in this topic though, and I was able to understand enough to make listening to this book absolutely fascinating. I learned so much about the current theories of the origins of our universe. I'm glad I took the time to listen to it, even though it was difficult to get through.

Why is there 'something' instead of 'nothing'? As humanity inches ever closer to unravelling the hidden secrets of the universe it inhabits, the fundamental laws of physics as we understand them now reveal a universe that is astonishingly calculated and bewilderingly fragile. For if the values of the ‘cosmological constants’ were off just by a wee bit, the universe as we know it, could not have possibly existed. This leads us to the question of why should there be something when nothingness is infinitely more probable, a question that has been asked since the time of Aristotle and Socrates but one that’s become more pertinent in the age of quantum physics.  Dr. Lawrence Krauss, a theoretical physicist and cosmologist at Arizona State University is one of the key players in the ultimate quest to understand how our universe functions. In the current offering Dr. Krauss presents and defends the thesis that ‘something’ can indeed arise from ‘nothing’ and that this impossible-seeming scenario is a direct consequence of the quantum weirdness of the universe we are a part of. He starts slow with a short and simple historical narrative of the established bits of modern cosmology such as the Hubble expansion and the cosmic microwave background, then quickly switches gears to talk about the most fascinating discoveries of recent times; things such as dark matter, dark energy and the quantum properties of vaccuum. Krauss’ narrative genius shines through in this part of the book where he intelligibly describes the most plausible picture of the universe presenting solid evidence behind every aspect of this theory. He pauses sufficiently, reiterates the most important concepts and points out the potential problems/inconsistencies with each concept he describes. At the end of this part, you will be convinced that we live in a flat and accelerating universe that started as a tiny speck expanding 24 orders of magnitude in merely microseconds of its existence.  Here is where things start to take a turn, Krauss suddenly dons a profound and somewhat melancholic tone and speculates whether scientists living in a different time and era could ever possibly reach the same conclusions about the origins and fate of the universe as us. All of science and all of our understanding of the universe is limited by physical evidence and the evolution of the universe itself might erase some of this evidence leaving no avenues to find out what exactly happened. According to Krauss, we live in a special time and space, one that enables us to make the precise inferences about the origins and the fate of the universe; inferences that simply would not be possible given the physical evidence that will be available to the scientists of the distant past and future. With this argument, Krauss then introduces the ‘Anthropic principle’: a logical yet dull explanation for why things in the universe are the way they are. Simply put, the ‘anthropic principle’ states that had the universe been any different, we would not have been here to ponder this very question. Following this is a long and tiring tirade about atheism: an extrapolation about how the flatness of the universe is a proof of the non-existence of God. Being an ardent believer of science, I personally find arguments for atheism tiresome but I guess a thorough discussion is essential in today’s science-doubting world. Overall it is a very fun and accessible read about the origins of the universe with enough intellectual fodder for the philosophically-inclined. Just skip the final few chapters.

I think Krauss' editors bit off more than they could chew in picking this title. All of it is good, and some incredibly difficult physics is well explained. However, the whole book suffers from a classic physics problem, the lamplight. A man loses his wallet in an alley, and starts to look for it on an adjacent street under a street lamp. When asked why, he answers, "the alley is too dark to see anything." Why is there something rather than nothing is not answered. What is addressed is instead what is under the lamp on an adjacent street.

The best book I have read till date. Although I am not a physicist or probably not anywhere close to it, I was able to grasp most of the topics in the book, probably a little bit due to my scientific background in school. The best part of the book would have to be the illustrations that are in between certain paragraphs which help understand certain topics so clearly. I would definitely suggest this book to anyone who is interested in knowing how universe could have originated from big bang. Solid 10/10 book.

While the concepts are stirring, I felt mostly left in the dust. Complex physics that are not clearly described with appropriate analogies made me zone out frequently and wish for a more approachable method of presentation. In its current form "A Universe From Nothing" was difficult to follow and seemed hardly to attempt an answer to the central premise.If you're like me—not dumb but also not a physicist—you may find yourself somewhat bored at times. I feel this book was largely written for other physicists or students in that field.

The text is 180 pages, normally considered a short book. This text required my close, consistent attention in order to get much (anything) from it. Not that I am normally an inattentive reader. It is just that this subject matter is very unfamiliar to me.I have had the book for a while and can’t remember what prompted me to buy it. It became a grind to read, my interest level not matching the effort I found the book to require. Not without some amount of interest to me though, thus the 2 star rating.

Krauss is like give me one free miracle and I will explain the rest. And the free miracle is the appearance of all the matter and energy in the universe and all the laws that govern it, from nothing in a single instant. He tries to circumvent this miracle by trying to justify it but I think he fails. Although there are insights to be found in the book, I did not like it. Many parts are ambiguous and poorly explained. There are far better books on the topic.Moreover, Krauss's hopeless attempts to imply that he has contributed to Physics or science, in general, was pathetic.

This book does not justify a reason as to why the universe can exist from nothing, but rather it redefines "nothing" as the potential of everything according to quantum theory. There is no deep insight- just basic quantum mechanics. Nothing cannot produce something, but unstable quantum fluxuations can produce spacetime and matter. String theory and "bubble universes" is a dying theory that is becoming harder and harder to justify. Loop quantum gravity is the future. Never start with space or time, rather start with particular information.

Firstly, I must say that the title of this book is a little misleading, with which I was disappointed. Krauss pretty much redefines the word 'nothing' to mean SOMETHING: virtual particles which pop in and out of existence.Some of the ideas in the book were quite interesting, so it has some redeeming qualities. I liked how Krauss is talented at explaining complex concepts in easily graspable language. Overall however, I don't like the trickery Krauss employs with the title 'A Universe From Nothing'.

I can’t say it any better than Mr. Dawkins:  “Even the last remaining trump card of the theologian, “Why is there something rather than nothing?’ shrivels up before your eyes as you read these pages. If ‘On the Origin of Species’ was biology’s deadliest blow to supernaturalism, we may come to see 'A Universe from Nothing' as the equivalent from cosmology. The title means exactly what it says. And what it says is devastating.”  - Richard DawkinsIt is a challenging read if, like me, you are weak in math and physics skills.

This was a great book. It's so exciting that we are living in a time when we are discovering so many fascinating things. Even how the universe began! I'm so excited to live in a time when we may find some more answers from the James Web telescope. If they would ever launch the damn thing! Lawrence Krauss is another great thinker of our time, and like the other great thinkers, what he doesn't yet know, only excites and inspires him. As it should in all of us. It doesn't cause him to turn to thoughts of magic.

A fascinating dive into our current understanding of the universe, and how it could possibly have begun for nothing at all.Krauss makes an excellent attempt to explain some very complex ideas in a way that a non-scientist such as myself can understand, but even still there were parts that were hard to follow. I’m also aware of how quickly our knowledge of the universe is evolving, so some of the ideas presented here may have been confirmed or refuted in the years since this was written (2012).

So while I could just barely grasp the scientific posits Krauss shared, I am thinking others may not expect a heavy side of science when looking for an atheist read. Krauss actually does a very good job sharing these scientific discoveries and theories in a way pretty easily understood by the lay reader. From focusing on Einstein's Theory of Relativity, to some of his own discoveries, it was an enjoyable read. While this probably gives me no new ammo for my arguments with Christians, most would be well over their heads, it did do much to further entrench my beliefs.

I love to read this kind of book. The last books of this sort were from Feynman and Hawking, quite some time ago. So it is very refreshing that even with the fundamental questions we are making progress. Or did you know, we measured the shape, aka curvature of our space? I didn't before. The only problem I see is, that I have to attend a day job and cannot go down just another rabbit hole. Too many worthwhile things to do in such a small amount of time...But nothing to despair about, just let us go on, wherever this will take us!

I think Krauss does a great job of "dumbing down" this subject material for the lay reader. I do think that it requires some level of scientific understanding and probably would be difficult to understand for someone without any scientific literacy but he does a great job of keeping it simple. The subject material is fascinating and he takes a few jabs at theology and anti-science fanatics but I think they are fair and entertaining, though maybe not necessary in a book like this. I highly recommend for anyone interested in cosmology.

This book has so many concepts that are so complex, it's hard to understand it completely, but it really gives a perspective of how enormous this universe truly. What our limited senses consider nothing may just be another dimension. This universe us full of mystery and Lawrence Krause shows how beautiful and intricate the universe(s) is.http://www.10secondbooks.com/2017/02/...

Fascinating. I think that I understood the author's main points and conclusions but admit that I was unable to follow all of the arguments and proofs that lead up to the conclusions. Recommend that you watch some of the author's lectures and debates which are readily available on YouTube ... which serve as an excellent introduction to the book ... and will also inform you as to whether or not you want to read the book.

A great read, but the title can be somewhat misleading to mere science enthusiasts although still laymen such as myself. It never approaches the literal nothing one might be thinking of when purchasing this book.However, again, it's a great read - and although Mr. Krauss's pocket table might be a little complicated to wrap your head around, it should be a must for anyone who wants to better understand the place we currently exist in.

Amasing book. A very good introduction to the space works, however still overwhelming for me and I had a quantum chemistry class in college. There are of course opinions and facts, and was glad to know that most of Krauss's book is factual and he talks about research that has been done in the field. Also some opinions about the how and why of the universe which are of course up to the reader to interpret. Would recommend this book for anyone, and for myself definitely reading it again.

Equivocation defined...At the end of the book he declared the question meaningless. He simply avoided the real question. He used it as a trick to keep the reader reading (and to sell a book, apparently). But in the end, Krauss DID create something out of nothing. He created this book....and for the love of God…can we stop framing these debates against the idea of God? It's punching down. Let's move on to deeper framing.

the science is fascinating, but throughout the book the author is compelled to say how Religion is foolish, vapid, etc. There are several mocking references to angels dancing on the head of a pin. Ok I get it, but those who believe that the world was created in 6 days are probably NOT reading the book anyway. I don't fully understand the science, but I was annoyed at the straw theologian that the author felt needed to be leveled repeatedly.

I am not a science guy and my knowledge of quantum physics begins and ends at the spelling of it. I had hoped that this book might be slightly more accessible than it was, moreso once I had read it as some of the ideas and theories are compelling and I would have liked to have wrapped my head around the subject a bit more.It is worth a read, if only to get your own grey matter whirring, but it's not a light read. One tip: read it just prior to sleep for rather bizarre dreams!

This was a very challenging book to read that presupposes the reader has a background in physics and math. I only have high school physics and whatever random bits I have since accumulated. The book posits that ‘Why?’ Should really be ‘How?’ and that ‘nothing’ is not really nothing as we know it and that there can’t help but be something from nothing when quantum mechanics rules are applied. Also, our sense of time is limiting.

Good info much of went over my head for one sitting and I'll definitely have to research much of what he said as there are not many references or citations. A good book to put in the toolbox for future reading. I believe some of the information needs to be updated from 2010. The narration was dry and I found my mind wandering but mostly due to the material. I couldn't help but jump from the thought to thought and think of other data and/or information.

Despite the modest page count this book has a sweeping and majestic canvass that boldy aims to cover the universe, from its perceived genesis toward its perceived end, including all the theories that try to underpin this ambitious narrative. Unfortunately, there were many times I was bogged down by fascinating but high-minded scientific muddle that on hindsight could have been better told and better explained to readers outside the scientific community

Mind blown. We're all fucked. In a few trillion years from now. This book is nice to listen as audio since there are any complex mathematical formulae, or to be honest any other than E = mc². Due to my lack of knowledge I got lost somewhere in the middle of the book where concepts got more complicated, however I am still extremely grateful for the very simple explanations of complex cosmology problems.
